Leaders-only analysis involves a two-person joint-action task (leading vs following) which is inherently social—participants interact, interpret partner cues, and coordinate actions. This meets the Social Processing definition and inclusion I1.

The task probes role-specific motor coordination (leading/following) and expertise, not measures of affiliation, bonding, or attachment (no cooperation/competition or loved one vs stranger contrasts). Does not meet affiliation/attachment I1.

Leading and following require exchange of socially relevant information (haptic/kinesthetic signaling between partners). The analysis measures communication aspects of interaction (transmission/reception of partner cues), meeting social_communication I1.

Leading emphasizes agency, self-initiation, and self-monitoring (areas like SMA, DLPFC implicated). The leaders-only contrast directly probes self-related control/agency processes and thus meets perception_self I1.

While the task is social, the leaders-only analysis primarily highlights leader-related motor and self-control processes rather than explicit inference or perception of others’ mental states; it does not primarily test Theory-of-Mind/action perception constructs required by perception_others I1.
Followers-only analysis also uses the two-person joint-action task; following requires interpreting partner cues and coordinating behavior, satisfying Social Processing I1.
The analysis does not assess affiliation/attachment (no bonding/relationship contrasts or measures). Does not meet affiliation/attachment I1.

Following depends on reception and interpretation of partner signals (haptic/kinesthetic), which is an instance of social communication (receptive non-facial communication). Meets social_communication I1.

The followers-only analysis predominantly emphasizes externally-oriented processing (mentalizing, pSTS, TPJ) and action perception of the partner rather than self-related agency; it does not primarily assess Perception/Self constructs as defined by perception_self I1.
Following engages perception and understanding of others (TPJ, pSTS, PCC, mPFC reported), and the analysis probes action/mental-state perception of the partner, satisfying perception_others I1.
Whole-group Leading vs Following contrast examines interactive joint action and role-based social behavior; this is squarely within Social Processing I1.

Although interactive, the contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, loved-one comparisons, cooperation/competition contrasts). Does not meet affiliation/attachment I1.

The contrast captures bidirectional exchange of movement cues and signaling between partners (leading vs following), reflecting social communication (receptive and productive non-verbal signaling). Meets social_communication I1.

Leading vs Following contrast isolates processes related to agency, self-initiation and self-monitoring (leading engages SMA, CMA, DLPFC). Thus the analysis probes Perception/Understanding of Self aspects and meets perception_self I1.
The contrast also isolates follower-related processes (TPJ, pSTS, PCC, mPFC) that involve perception and inference about the partner’s actions and mental states, meeting perception_others I1.
Leaders-only (repeat of subgroup contrast) examines the social joint-action role of leading; it involves interacting with a partner and social coordination, meeting Social Processing I1.
No measures or contrasts of affiliation/attachment are present in this subgroup analysis; does not meet affiliation/attachment I1.

Leading involves transmitting signals to the partner and coordinating actions—this is social communication (productive non-facial communication). The leaders-only analysis measures that, meeting social_communication I1.
The leaders-only contrast emphasizes agency, motor planning, and self-initiated control (SMA, PMC, CMA), directly addressing Perception/Self constructs and meeting perception_self I1.

This subgroup analysis focuses on leader-related, self-generated motor processes rather than explicit perception/inference about the partner’s mental states; it therefore does not meet perception_others I1 as the primary target.
Followers-only contrast probes interactive following behavior (interpreting partner cues), which is social processing by definition and meets Social Processing I1.
No explicit measures of affiliation or attachment are used in this subgroup analysis; it does not meet affiliation/attachment I1.

Following requires reception and interpretation of partner signals—an instance of social communication (receptive non-facial communication). The followers-only analysis directly assesses this, meeting social_communication I1.

The followers-only analysis chiefly highlights externally-oriented/social-cognitive processing (TPJ, PCC, pSTS) rather than self-focused agency processes, so perception_self I1 is not the primary construct measured here.
This analysis emphasizes perception and understanding of the partner’s actions/intentions (mentalizing and action-perception regions reported), directly matching perception_others I1.
Whole-brain regression of Leading>Following with leader skill examines how social interactive role expertise modulates social interaction-related activations—fits Social Processing I1.
The regression tests role-expertise effects, not affiliation/attachment constructs; no attachment-related contrasts or measures are present, so affiliation_attachment I1 is not met.

Leader-skill regressions identify areas (insula, STG, dPMC) involved in transmitting/planning signals to a partner—this reflects social communicative aspects of coordinating with another person, meeting social_communication I1.

Regions whose activity during leading covaries with leader skill (SMA, pre-SMA, dPMC) index agency and self-generated motor planning; the analysis probes Perception/Self constructs per perception_self I1.

This regression focuses on leader-related (self/agency) enhancements with expertise rather than perception/inference about the partner’s mental states; it does not primarily target perception_others I1.

Leader-skill deactivation analysis is part of the social joint-action regression set and still pertains to how role expertise modulates social interaction-related activation patterns, meeting Social Processing I1.
Deactivation analysis for leader skill does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs; no affiliation I1 present.

Even deactivations with leader skill relate to aspects of coordinating and signaling in interpersonal interaction, and thus are relevant to social communication (exchange of partner-relevant information). Meets social_communication I1.

Deactivations associated with leader skill still index modulation of self-related/agency networks (e.g., DLPFC, SMA) by expertise; analysis addresses Perception/Self constructs per perception_self I1.

This analysis centers on leader-skill-related decreases (self/agency networks) rather than explicit measures of perceiving or inferring others’ mental states; it does not primarily meet perception_others I1.

Regression of Leading>Following with follower skill examines how expertise at following modulates social-interaction-related activations (mentalizing/action perception), satisfying Social Processing I1.
This regression targets follower expertise and mentalizing/action-perception networks, not affiliation/attachment measures; affiliation_attachment I1 is not met.
Follower-skill regressions implicate regions (TPJ, pSTS) involved in perceiving partner signals—this is receptive social communication and meets social_communication I1.

Regression with follower skill highlights externally-oriented social-cognitive regions (mPFC, TPJ, PCC, pSTS) related to perceiving others rather than self/agency, so perception_self I1 is not the primary construct here.
Regions whose activity during following covaries with follower skill (TPJ, pSTS, PCC, mPFC) are canonical action-perception/mentalizing areas; this directly matches perception_others I1.

Contrast compares emotional vs neutral autobiographical videos requiring participants to perceive, interpret and respond to social-emotional cues—directly measuring broad social processing (empathy, mentalising).
The task examines empathic tracking of emotional intensity rather than affiliation, bonding, or relationship-related processes (no loved-one vs stranger or attachment manipulation).
Participants decode communicative cues (spoken autobiographical narratives, facial/vocal affect) to infer others' emotions, meeting the social communication (reception) construct.

Contrast targets processing of others' emotions; it does not assess self-judgment, agency, or self>other comparisons. Although participants report their own affect after clips, the primary contrast is not a self-perception contrast.
Empathic accuracy and watching others' emotional videos directly probe perception and understanding of others' emotional states (ToM/empathy), satisfying this annotation.
The neutral>emotional contrast still involves processing of social stimuli (videos of people) and comparisons of social-emotional engagement, relevant to social processing.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship/bonding manipulations.

Both emotional and neutral videos convey communicative information (narratives, facial/vocal cues); the contrast isolates communicative/social signal processing differences, aligning with social communication (reception).
Contrast addresses responses to others' narratives, not self-reflection or self>other judgments.
Comparing neural responses to emotional versus neutral portrayals of others' experiences assesses perception/understanding of others' emotional states.
Modulation of BOLD by intra-individual empathic accuracy directly indexes social cognitive processing required for understanding others—core social processing.
Empathic accuracy reflects tracking others' emotions and mentalising, not affiliation/attachment-specific processes or bonding measures.
EA depends on decoding communicative cues (speech, facial expression, prosody) to infer others' states; modulation by EA maps onto social communication (reception) mechanisms.
Analysis relates neural activity to accuracy in perceiving others, not to self-knowledge, agency, or self-referential judgments.
Empathic accuracy is an explicit measure of perceiving and understanding others' emotional states (ToM/empathy), matching this construct.
Negative modulation by EA still pertains to social cognitive processing (regions whose activity inversely relates to accuracy), so it remains within social processing domain.
Negative relations to EA do not indicate affiliation/attachment processes; no bonding/cooperation manipulation present.
Regions negatively modulated by EA likely reflect aspects of processing communicative/social signals or alternate strategies; the analysis pertains to social communication mechanisms.
This analysis concerns accuracy in perceiving others (inverse relation), not self-focused judgments or agency.
Because the modulation concerns empathic accuracy (understanding others), this analysis maps onto perception and understanding of others (ToM/empathy).
Temporal correlation between BOLD and participants' continuous ratings of targets' emotional intensity probes dynamic social processing of others' affect—central to social processing.
Moment-to-moment intensity tracking indexes empathic/emotional perception, not affiliation/attachment or bonding measures.
Tracking emotional intensity over time requires decoding communicative information (speech, expression, prosody), fitting the social communication (reception) construct.
Although participants report their own affect after clips, this analysis models ratings of others' intensity and associated BOLD, not self-reflective judgments or self>other contrasts.
Continuous ratings index perception and understanding of others' changing emotional states (empathy/ToM), directly matching this construct.
Negative correlations between BOLD and participants' ratings still concern social-emotional processing of others and therefore fall under social processing.
Negative covariation with perceived intensity indexes emotional/perceptual processes, not affiliation/attachment constructs.

Regions negatively tracking rated intensity likely reflect aspects of communicative/social signal processing (e.g., regions downregulated during intense social engagement), so social communication applies.
This analysis concerns neural correlates of perceiving others' emotional intensity, not self-judgment or agency processes.
Negative correlations with ratings remain directly tied to perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy/ToM).

The main effect of modality analysis tests how facial, vocal, and bimodal stimuli influence emotion perception — a core social processing task involving perception and interpretation of social/emotional cues. It therefore measures Social Processing.

The study does not assess affiliation or attachment (no tasks or contrasts involving kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger). The modality main effect does not measure affiliation/attachment.
The modality main effect involves reception of facial and vocal emotional signals (viewing faces, listening to prosody) and thus directly measures Social Communication (receptive communication).
Analyses concern perception of others' emotional expressions rather than self-related judgments or self-referential processing; thus they do not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The modality main effect evaluates participants' ability to perceive and discriminate others' emotional states from faces and voices, meeting the criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.
The main effect of emotion examines neural/behavioral responses to emotions (anger, happiness, neutral) — explicitly a social-emotional perception task and thus Social Processing.
This analysis contrasts emotion categories but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/attachment measures), so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Emotion category effects arise from perception of facial and vocal emotional signals (receptive aspects of social communication), so this analysis measures Social Communication.
The analysis concerns perception of external emotional stimuli (others) rather than self-related judgments or self-knowledge; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Contrasting emotional categories indexes participants' perception and understanding of others' emotional states, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
The Emotion × Modality interaction probes how modality (face/voice/bimodal) and emotion interact in social-emotional perception — clearly a Social Processing measure.

The interaction analysis evaluates perceptual/emotional differences across modalities and emotions but does not assess affiliation or attachment-related constructs, so Affiliation/Attachment is not applicable.
The interaction identifies differences in receptive social communication (face vs voice vs bimodal) for emotion recognition, meeting Social Communication criteria.
This interaction concerns perception of others' expressions; it does not involve self-judgment or self-related processing, so Perception/Self is not met.
The interaction directly indexes how participants perceive and interpret others' emotional states across modalities, fulfilling Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis explicitly targets social processing: a NeuroSynth meta-analysis of studies containing the term 'social' and an independent fMRI contrast comparing social versus non-social images. The contrast (social > non-social) directly measures social processing. Thus both inclusion criteria (task is social-related and the contrast measures social processing) are met.

The study manipulated ‘socialness’ broadly (social vs non-social scenes) and did not specifically measure affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship scenarios, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). Although social images may include interacting people, the task was valence appraisal rather than an affiliation/attachment task, so I1 is not satisfied.

While some stimuli contained faces and social cues, the experimental task required valence appraisal of complex scenes rather than explicit measures of social communication (e.g., face-processing, gaze, expression recognition, communicative production). Therefore the analysis does not meet the criterion of a task measuring Social Communication (I1).

The task did not involve self-referential judgments, viewing the self, or other self-focused measures. It contrasted social versus non-social images during valence appraisal, so it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion (I1).

Although stimuli depicted other people and interactions, the task did not require explicit perception/understanding of others' mental states (e.g., theory of mind, empathy) or related measures. The contrast isolates general socialness rather than specific processes of perceiving others' mental states, so it does not meet the Perception/Others inclusion criterion (I1).

The contrast (Self vs. Celebrity) is a social task probing self-referential and person-related processing; it measures social processing broadly (self and other representations).

This contrast targets self-referential processing (Self vs. Celebrity) rather than measures of affiliation/close-relationship processing per se; although social, it does not specifically index affiliation/attachment like close-other vs stranger contrasts or kinship scenarios.

The task involves trait judgments about roles (self vs celebrity), not receptive or productive social communication (faces, emotion recognition, gaze, etc.), so it does not meet the Social Communication criteria.
Self vs. Celebrity is a canonical self-referential contrast assessing perception/understanding of the self (self-judgment vs other), directly matching the inclusion examples.
This contrast specifically contrasts self to a celebrity and is focused on self-representation; it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
Friend vs. Celebrity is a social task probing representation of others (close other vs a non-close other) and thus falls under general social processing.

Friend vs. Celebrity directly contrasts a close other (friend) with a non-close public person (celebrity), which indexes affiliation/attachment and close-relationship processing as in the inclusion examples.

The contrast concerns trait judgments about persons (friend vs celebrity) rather than communication-related processes (facial/affective reception or expressive communication), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
Friend vs. Celebrity targets perception/understanding of others (close other) rather than self-related processes, so it does not meet the Perception of Self inclusion.

Friend vs. Celebrity directly assesses representations of another person's traits (a close other vs celebrity), which matches Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., theory of mind/other trait judgments).

This analysis tests how interdependence moderates neural responses in the Self vs. Celebrity contrast — still squarely a social processing analysis (self/other representations and cultural modulation).

Although it examines moderation by interdependence, the contrast is Self vs. Celebrity (self-referential) and does not specifically index affiliation/attachment to close others, so it does not meet the Affiliation/Attachment criterion.
The moderated contrast concerns self-referential trait judgments rather than communicative processes (facial/affective reception or production), so Social Communication is not applicable.
This analysis probes how interdependence moderates self-referential processing (Self vs. Celebrity), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Self.
The modulation analysis is on the Self vs. Celebrity contrast and therefore does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
This analysis examines moderation of neural responses in Friend vs. Celebrity — a social cognition contrast involving close-other representations — and thus fits broad social processing.

Friend vs. Celebrity with a moderation test of interdependence directly probes close-relationship (affiliation/attachment) processing, matching the listed examples (close other vs stranger/celebrity).
The task and contrast are trait judgments about persons (friend vs celebrity), not communication/face or emotion processing, so Social Communication is not met.
Friend vs. Celebrity targets representation of another person (friend) and is not a self-perception contrast, so Perception of Self is not applicable.
Friend vs. Celebrity directly measures representations and judgments about another person (a close other), which fits Perception and Understanding of Others (theory of mind/other traits).
This analysis examines functional connectivity during Self vs. Celebrity — a social task assessing self/other representations and network interactions — so it falls under general social processing.

The connectivity analysis is tied to Self vs. Celebrity (self-referential network interactions) rather than explicit affiliation/close-relationship contrasts, so it does not specifically index Affiliation/Attachment.
The connectivity analysis concerns self-referential trait judgments and network coupling, not communicative processes (face/emotion/gaze), so Social Communication does not apply.
Functional connectivity seeded from MPFC during Self vs. Celebrity pertains to self-referential processing and thus meets Perception and Understanding of Self.
This connectivity analysis is specific to the Self vs. Celebrity contrast, so it is not primarily measuring Perception/Understanding of Others.
This analysis examines functional connectivity during Friend vs. Celebrity — a social contrast probing network interactions when representing others — therefore counts as social processing.
Functional connectivity differences for Friend vs. Celebrity assess close-other network interactions (friend vs non-close other), which indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Although this is a social network connectivity analysis, it does not probe communicative reception/production (faces, gaze, emotion), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The analysis focuses on Friend vs. Celebrity connectivity (other-related), not self-perception, so Perception of Self is not applicable.
Connectivity changes during Friend vs. Celebrity reflect neural processing and representation of others (close other) and meet the Perception and Understanding of Others criterion.
This analysis tests modulation of functional connectivity in the Self vs. Celebrity contrast by interdependence — still within social processing of self/other representations and network effects.

Although this is a moderation of connectivity, the contrast is Self vs. Celebrity, focusing on self-related processing rather than explicit affiliation/attachment to close others, so Affiliation/Attachment is not met.
The moderated connectivity analysis concerns self-referential processing rather than communicative or face/emotion processing, so Social Communication does not apply.
Modulation of functional connectivity during Self vs. Celebrity by interdependence directly probes neural mechanisms supporting self-referential processing, matching Perception of Self.
Because this analysis focuses on the Self vs. Celebrity connectivity modulation, it is not primarily a Perception/Understanding of Others contrast.

This analysis examines modulation of functional connectivity during Friend vs. Celebrity by interdependence — a social-network-level test of other-related representations — so it is social processing.
Friend vs. Celebrity connectivity modulation specifically targets close-other vs non-close other processing (affiliation/attachment), consistent with inclusion examples.
The analysis focuses on trait-judgment-related connectivity for friend vs celebrity, not communication-specific processing (faces, gaze, emotion), so Social Communication is not applicable.
This analysis is about Friend vs. Celebrity connectivity modulation (other-related) rather than self-perception, so it does not meet the Perception of Self criterion.
Modulation of connectivity during Friend vs. Celebrity directly reflects processing and representation of others (close other) and therefore meets Perception and Understanding of Others.

Participants viewed erotic pictures of other people (male vs. female), which involves perceiving and responding to social stimuli (bodies, faces, interpersonal sexual context). This contrast measures social-related neural processing across groups (gendered social cues), meeting the broad Social Processing construct.

The task does not assess affiliation or attachment (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation, or loved-one vs. stranger contrasts). It is focused on sexual/visual interest in others rather than attachment processes.

Viewing pictures of other peoples' faces/bodies and evaluating them engages receptive social-communication processes (facial/body perception and implicit communicative cues). The contrast (female>male pictures) indexes differential social-communicative perception of actors.
The contrast does not involve self-related judgments or viewing the self; it concerns perception of others, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The analysis involves perceiving and evaluating other people's bodies/actions (animacy/action perception and judgments about others), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Male>female picture contrast involves perception of social stimuli (other people’s bodies/faces) and differential social processing; it fits the Social Processing construct.
No measures or contrasts related to attachment or affiliation (e.g., loved-one vs stranger, cooperation) are present in this task.
Differential responses to pictured actors’ faces/bodies implicate social-communication processes (receptive facial/body information); the contrast indexes such processing.
This task does not assess self-related cognition or self-judgment; it focuses on others’ stimuli.
The contrast involves perceiving others (bodies/actions) and thus relates to Perception/Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception).
Female>male picture contrast in bisexual women examines neural responses to social stimuli (others’ bodies/faces) and is therefore within Social Processing.
The task does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no close-relationship or bonding measures).
Viewing and differentially responding to pictured actors involves receptive social-communication processes (faces/bodies), satisfying Social Communication criteria.
No self-focused judgments or self-referential processing are measured here; the contrast focuses on others.
This contrast assesses perception of other people (their bodies, actions), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Male>female picture contrast in bisexual women involves social stimulus processing (perception of other people), placing it in Social Processing.
No measures of attachment or affiliation are present; stimuli are sexual/visual rather than relational/attachment-focused.
Differential neural responses to pictured actors imply processing of faces/bodies and other communicative cues—meeting Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Contrast does not involve self-related processing or judgments about the self.
This contrast captures perception/action-related processing of other people (animacy/action perception), fitting Perception/Understanding of Others.

Female>male picture contrast in homosexual women examines perception and neural responses to other people (preferred-sex vs non-preferred), which is social in nature and falls under Social Processing.
The experimental contrasts do not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship or bonding tasks).
Viewing actors’ faces/bodies and differentially responding (female vs male pictures) taps receptive social-communication processes (face/body perception).
No self-referential or self-judgment tasks are included; the focus is on perceiving others.
The contrast involves perceiving others’ bodies/actions and associated attributes, consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Male>female picture contrast in homosexual women entails processing social stimuli (other people), thus meeting Social Processing inclusion criteria.
No affiliation or attachment-specific measures or contrasts are present in this task; it assesses sexual/visual interest rather than bonding.
Differential responses to pictured actors engage receptive social-communication processes (faces/bodies), so Social Communication applies.
This analysis does not involve self-perception or self-referential processing; it focuses on others’ stimuli.
Perception of other people (their bodies and actions) is central to this contrast, aligning with Perception/Understanding of Others.

Videos depict sexual stimuli but do not operationalize affiliation or attachment constructs (no relationship/bonding tasks).
Videos include vocalizations and facial/body motion; receptive social-communication (auditory and visual cues) is strongly engaged, matching Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast measures responses to others (actors in videos) rather than self-related processes or self-judgments.
Video viewing involves perception of others’ actions, motions, and social vocalizations, consistent with Perception/Understanding of Others (action/animacy perception).
Male>female video contrast taps processing of social stimuli (actors’ behaviors/vocalizations) and thus qualifies as Social Processing.
The videos are sexual in content but do not probe attachment/affiliation constructs (no bonding or relationship contrasts).
Video stimuli include auditory cues and body motion that convey social-communicative information; the contrast indexes such receptive communication processes.
There are no self-focused tasks or contrasts; participants view others rather than themselves.
The contrast involves perceiving and interpreting other people’s actions and cues (action perception/animacy), meeting Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.

Contrast examines partnered vs non-partnered movements (Leading+Following+Mutual > Solo+Alone). This directly probes social interaction and networks (pSTS, TPJ, mPFC) involved in perceiving and engaging with another person, so it measures broad social processing.

Partnered movement is a cooperative, dyadic interaction and the contrast reveals reward/limbic regions (e.g., nucleus accumbens, amygdala, mPFC) consistent with social reward and affiliation; thus it measures affiliation/attachment-related processes.

The paradigm emphasizes haptic exchange of information (signalling and reception of force cues) and the contrast isolates brain areas for interpersonal communication via touch (pSTS, S1/S2), meeting the social communication definition.

Partnered interaction engages self-related somatosensory and interoceptive processing (MCC, insula) and requires self-monitoring of one’s own movements in relation to a partner, so the contrast taps into self-perception/agency-related processes.

Partnered > non-partnered activates mentalizing and action-perception regions (pSTS, TPJ, mPFC) implicated in representing others’ actions and intentions, so it measures perception/understanding of others.

This contrast isolates Leading-specific activations within a dyadic interaction. Leading is a social role in joint action and the analysis investigates brain systems supporting that social behavior (self-oriented social role), so it meets the social processing criterion.

Leading-specific activations are dominated by motor-planning and self-initiation circuitry (PMC, SMA, IFG, cerebellum) and do not specifically probe affiliation, bonding, or social reward; thus it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criterion.

Leading involves sending haptic cues/intention-signals to a partner; this contrast targets brain areas involved in producing the interpersonal signals required for coordination (motor planning and sensorimotor mapping), so it is relevant to social communication.

Leading is characterized as self-oriented and self-initiated movement; the contrast highlights regions tied to agency and self-initiated action (SMA, PMC, CMA), so it measures aspects of self-perception/agency.

The Leading-specific pattern emphasizes internally-driven motor planning rather than representation or inference about others’ mental states or actions; the contrast does not principally target perception/understanding of others.

This contrast isolates Following-specific activations within a dyadic interaction. Following is a social role and the analysis probes networks supporting interpersonal responsiveness to another’s actions (pSTS, S2, MT+/V5), so it measures social processing.

Following recruited ventral mPFC and reward-related regions (vACC, nucleus accumbens/caudate) associated with monitoring outcomes and social valuation; given the cooperative nature of the task, this is consistent with affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Following specifically indexes the reception and use of haptic cues from a partner (sensory and motion-tracking regions); this is a form of social communication (receptive channel), meeting the annotation criteria.

Following is characterized as externally-driven and sensory-oriented; the contrast emphasizes responsiveness to others rather than internal self-monitoring or agency, so it does not primarily measure self-perception.

Following activates regions involved in perceiving others’ dynamic actions and intentions (pSTS, MT+/V5, aIPL) and outcome-monitoring of externally-triggered actions, thus it measures perception/understanding of others.

The Mutual-specific contrast isolates an egalitarian, reciprocal interaction and shows engagement of mentalizing and reward circuitry (mPFC, TPJ, PCC, nucleus accumbens), so it clearly measures broad social processing.

Mutual interaction produced activity in reward-related and emotional areas (nucleus accumbens, amygdala) and reflects cooperative, reciprocal behavior; this maps onto affiliation/attachment processes and social reward.

Mutual interaction requires reciprocal exchange and coordination (shared timing/agency) and engages social-perceptual systems; thus the contrast indexes interpersonal communication and coordination processes.

Mutual recruits mPFC and PCC and requires balancing self and other perspectives (agency ambiguity), implicating self-related processing and self-other representations; therefore it measures aspects of self-perception.
Mutual strongly engages mentalizing regions (TPJ, mPFC, PCC) linked to representing others’ intentions and ambiguous agency, so it measures perception/understanding of others.

This contrast targets improvisation per se (Leading+Solo > Mutual+Alone) across partnered and non-partnered conditions to isolate generative motor and working-memory networks; it is primarily about motor/cognitive processes rather than social interaction specifically, so it does not meet the social-processing inclusion criterion.

Improvisation contrast isolates motor-planning and working-memory systems (SMA, DLPFC, PMC) and is not designed to measure affiliation/attachment or social reward, so it does not meet the affiliation criterion.

Although one improvised condition (Leading) is partnered, the contrast combines partnered and solo improvisation and is aimed at generative processes rather than exchange of social signals; it does not specifically measure social communication.

Improvisation engages self-generation, self-initiation and working-memory resources (SMA, DLPFC, SPL) related to agency and self-guided action, consistent with perception/understanding of self processes.

The improvisation contrast is focused on internal generation of actions and sequence complexity and does not primarily assess representation or inference about others, so it does not meet the perception-of-others criterion.

The self-initiation contrast ([Leading+Solo+Mutual+Alone] > Following) indexes self- versus externally-triggered action within a social interaction context (Following is an externally-driven social role). Because it directly examines self-driven action in social exchanges, it is relevant to social processing.

The contrast is designed to isolate self-initiated versus externally-triggered movement and targets agency-related motor and cognitive circuits rather than affiliation or bonding, so it does not measure affiliation/attachment specifically.

This analysis targets the distinction between self-initiated and externally-triggered actions (agency) and is not explicitly probing exchange of social signals or communicative reception/production, so it does not meet the social-communication inclusion criterion.

By contrasting self-initiated actions against externally-triggered (Following), this contrast directly probes agency and self-related action monitoring (SPL, left DLPFC), meeting the perception_self criterion.

Although the contrast includes social elements, its primary aim is to isolate self-initiation and agency rather than representations of others’ mental states or actions, so it does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.

This analysis (Joint improvisation / Leading > Solo) compares partnered versus solo improvisation to find regions related to signalling intentions to a partner; it interrogates social aspects of joint improvisation and interpersonal coordination, thus meeting the social processing criterion.

The contrast was intended to identify signalling to a partner and largely yielded sensorimotor/partnership activations (S1, S2, MCC) without specific markers of affiliation or bonding, so it does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment.

Joint improvisation/Leading>Solo aims to isolate brain regions involved in signalling movement intentions to a partner (haptic communication). This directly targets social communication (production of non-facial, haptic signals), so it meets the annotation criteria.

Comparing Leading to Solo involves self-initiation and agency within an interpersonal context (how self-generated signals are produced to influence a partner), implicating self-related processing and thus meeting perception_self.

Although the contrast concerns interaction with a partner, the empirical results did not identify specific regions uniquely representing others’ mental states (no additional mentalizing activations beyond partnership), so the analysis does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.

Analysis 1a ('Observation of social interactions') explicitly involves observing social interactions and measures neural processing of social scenes; it directly assesses social processing across multiple social constructs.

The contrast is a broad observation of social interactions (all social scenes vs baseline) and is not specifically targeted to measure affiliation/attachment (cooperation vs bonding) as a primary contrast.
The task involves perception of socially relevant scenes (affective and cooperative interactions) and affect recognition/interpretation, fitting Social Communication (receptive social information).
The study does not include self-related judgments, self vs other contrasts, or tasks probing self-awareness; it instead focuses on perceiving others' interactions.
The analysis targets perception and understanding of others' intentions from observed social interactions (action/mental-state inference), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis 1b (Cooperativity > Affectivity) contrasts social interaction types and therefore measures social processing specific to cooperative interactions.
This contrast directly isolates cooperativity (cooperative interactions) versus affective interactions, which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/social bonding).
Viewing cooperative interactions involves reception of socially relevant cues (intentions, shared goals), fitting Social Communication (receptive social information).
The contrast pertains to perception of others' cooperative actions and does not probe self-related processes or self-judgments.
The contrast tests how observers decode others' intentions in cooperative interactions (action perception, shared goals), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis 1c (Affectivity > Cooperativity) isolates affective social interactions and measures neural responses to social-affective cues, thus indexing social processing.

Affective interactions (e.g., affective contact, gazing) relate to social bonding and affiliative behaviors; the contrast emphasizes affectivity over cooperativity, consistent with affiliation/attachment constructs.
Affective scenes require reception and interpretation of affective social signals (faces, gaze, contact), fitting Social Communication (receptive aspects).
The contrast focuses on perceiving others' affective interactions rather than self-related judgments or self-referential processing.
This contrast taps into inferring others' affective/mental states (mentalizing, empathy-related processing), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Analysis 3 (unnamed) is part of the same study's set of analyses (DCM/network analyses) investigating processing of social interactions and their modulatory dimensions, thus indexing social processing.

The DCM/network analysis examines modulatory effects of cooperativity and affectivity on connectivity; since cooperativity is specifically modeled, this analysis addresses affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The effective connectivity analyses address how brain regions exchange socially relevant information (intention/affect decoding), consistent with Social Communication (reception/integration of social cues).
The DCM focuses on inter-regional connectivity for decoding others' intentions and affect, not on self-referential or self-judgment processes.

The connectivity analysis explicitly tests mechanisms for perceiving and inferring others' intentions and mental states (mirror and mentalizing systems), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast directly compares retrieval of collaboratively encoded labels versus arbitrarily learned labels. The collaborative condition is a social communicative encoding context and the reported fMRI effects (medial PFC, TPJ, precuneus) reflect social processing/mentalizing. This contrast therefore measures social processing.

The collaborative condition involves cooperation and establishing shared labels with a partner (a cooperative, affiliative interaction). The contrast isolates retrieval of information learned in a cooperative/partnered context, matching tasks that measure affiliation/attachment-like cooperative behavior.

The task requires producing labels in a communicative referential game; the contrast isolates retrieval of labels established in an interactive communicative context, directly measuring social communication production and its neural correlates.

While the paper discusses autobiographical memory/self-projection, the contrast primarily targets social/mentalizing processes and communicative memory rather than explicit self-judgment or self-referential processing (no self>other manipulation). It does not meet the examples for Perception/Self.

Authors report engagement of theory-of-mind regions (right TPJ, medial PFC, precuneus) for collaborative > arbitrary, indicating processing/understanding of others’ perspectives/mental states. This matches Perception and Understanding of Others (Theory of Mind) criteria.

Individual > Arbitrary contrasts self-generated versus arbitrary labels; both are non-collaborative encoding contexts. The contrast primarily reflects semantic vs hippocampal memory processes rather than social processing.
This contrast does not involve cooperation, bonding, or affiliation manipulations (both conditions are individual encoding); it does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Although retrieval occurred in a communicative scanner task, the contrast isolates effects of self-generated semantic associations versus arbitrary associations rather than social communication per se; it does not test reception/production of social communicative signals.

The contrast compares self-generated versus arbitrary labels but does not include an explicit self-related judgment or self>other manipulation required by the Perception/Self construct; effects were interpreted as semantic memory, not self-awareness.

This contrast does not probe theory-of-mind or understanding others; it contrasts individual (self-generated) versus arbitrary encoding and is interpreted as semantic vs hippocampal memory engagement, so it does not meet Perception/Others criteria.

Collaborative > Individual directly contrasts collaboratively encoded labels with individually encoded labels; the authors report increased activation in social cognition regions (medial PFC, right TPJ, precuneus). The contrast therefore measures social processing.

The collaborative condition entails cooperative joint label generation and agreement with a partner. Comparing collaborative to individual encoding isolates effects of cooperative interaction, which maps onto affiliation/attachment-related cooperative tasks.

The manipulation contrasts labels created in an interactive communicative setting versus a solo setting; the contrast taps communicative production and partner-oriented message formation, matching Social Communication.

Although collaborative encoding may involve autobiographical memory or self-projection, the primary interpretation and reported activations concern understanding others/mentalizing rather than explicit self-judgment or self-awareness; no self>other task was used.

The Collaborative > Individual contrast produced activity in theory-of-mind network (right TPJ, medial PFC, precuneus) consistent with processes for representing others’ mental states; this fits Perception/Understanding of Others.

Arbitrary > Individual highlights greater hippocampal and domain-general memory/effort-related activations for arbitrary associations. Both conditions are non-collaborative encoding contexts; the contrast does not target social processing.
The contrast does not involve cooperative or affiliative interactions; it contrasts two individually encoded conditions and is interpreted in terms of memory systems, not affiliation.

Although the scanning task involved communicative output, this contrast isolates differences in hippocampal/effortful retrieval for arbitrary associations versus self-generated ones, not social communication per se.
The contrast indexes hippocampal engagement for arbitrary associations rather than explicit self-referential processing or self>other comparisons; it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
This contrast does not probe processes of understanding others or theory of mind; it contrasts types of individual learning (arbitrary vs individual) and is interpreted as memory-system differences.

Individual > Collaborative isolates regions more active for individually encoded labels relative to collaboratively encoded ones; this does not measure social processing and instead reflects non-social differences (e.g., semantic retrieval, efficiency).
The contrast does not probe cooperation/affiliation; it identifies areas stronger for individual encoding and therefore does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

The contrast does not specifically measure social communicative processes; it identifies areas relatively more active for individual encoding compared to collaborative encoding, interpreted as non-social or semantic effects.

Although individual encoding involves self-generated labels, the contrast was not designed as a self>other manipulation nor interpreted as explicit self-referential processing; it does not meet the Perception/Self examples.
This contrast does not tap theory-of-mind or understanding others; it reflects greater activation for individually encoded labels and thus does not meet Perception/Others criteria.

Arbitrary > Collaborative contrasts arbitrary (non-social) encoding against collaborative encoding; effects reflect hippocampal and memory-related activity for arbitrary labels rather than social processing, so it does not meet Social Processing criteria.
The contrast does not measure affiliation or cooperative bonding; it highlights memory-system engagement for arbitrary associations and thus does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
Although behavior occurred in a communicative context, this contrast isolates retrieval differences driven by arbitrary associations and hippocampal demand, not social communication processes per se.

This contrast highlights arbitrary-label retrieval (hippocampal-dependent) relative to collaborative retrieval and does not index explicit self-related perception or self-judgment processes as defined by the Perception/Self construct.

Arbitrary > Collaborative does not probe theory-of-mind or other-understanding processes; instead it reflects increased memory/effort demands for arbitrary labels, so it does not meet Perception/Others criteria.

The analysis comes from a social decision-making fMRI task (iterated prisoner's dilemma) involving interactions with cooperative, competitive, and random partners; the contrast(s) reflect social processing broadly (mentalizing, social exchange).

The task directly probes cooperation and competition between partners (formation and adaptation of social bonds/affiliation), so contrasts reflecting task > control capture affiliation/attachment processes.

Although faces are presented, the task does not probe communicative exchange, facial expression/gaze processing, or other social-communication-specific behavior; the contrasts measure decision-making and mentalizing rather than receptive/expressive communication.
Analyses concern inferring others' intentions and adapting behavior, not self-judgment, self-referential processing, or agency; thus they do not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The contrasts reflect Theory of Mind and inference about others' intentions (competitive vs cooperative partners), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The 'Competitive>Cooperative' contrast isolates social processing differences when interacting with a noncooperative vs cooperative partner during an interpersonal game, representing social cognition broadly.
This contrast directly compares competitive versus cooperative interaction, which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition).
The contrast targets ToM and decision-making processes rather than explicit communication (facial/emotional expression, gaze, or communicative production/reception).
The contrast is about perceiving and responding to others' intentions (not self-related judgments or self-processing).
Competitive>Cooperative isolates neural responses linked to inferring and processing others' noncooperative intentions (ToM), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.
The 'Cooperative>Competitive' contrast concerns social interaction dynamics (responses during cooperative partner interaction) and thus reflects social processing broadly.
Cooperative vs competitive contrast probes affiliation-related processing (positive social interaction, bonding/cooperation).
The analysis focuses on cooperative decision-making and reward/valuation rather than communication-specific processes like face/gaze/emotion recognition or production.
Contrast addresses processing of others' behavior and outcomes, not self-referential judgments or self-perception.
Cooperative>Competitive involves understanding others' cooperative intentions and mental states, fitting Perception/Understanding of Others (ToM-related).
This analysis (Competitive>Cooperative) again targets social decision-making and mentalizing differences and thus meets broad social processing criteria.
Direct contrast of competitive vs cooperative interactions taps affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition).
The contrast reflects Theory of Mind and strategic decision-making, not communication-focused processes such as facial expression or gaze processing.
No self-reflective judgments or self-referential processing are assessed in this contrast; it focuses on other-directed inference and behavior.
Competitive>Cooperative isolates neural correlates of inferring others' noncooperative intentions (ToM), satisfying Perception/Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.
The 'Early phase Competitive>Cooperative' analysis examines time-dependent social processing (early interactions where mentalizing and learning are engaged) and thus reflects broad social processing.
This contrast focuses on early-stage responses to competitive vs cooperative partners—relevant to affiliation dynamics and formation/updating of social bonds and strategies.
Although faces mark partners, the analysis probes early ToM and learning rather than communicative reception/production; it does not target facial/emotional communication per se.
This contrast examines inference about others and social learning, not self-perception or self-related judgments.
The early-phase competitive>cooperative contrast specifically targets Theory of Mind and the perception/understanding of others' intentions during initial interactions.

The 'Dynamic ToM-Value Competitive>Cooperative' analysis links behavioral adaptation (understanding multiple partners) with neural connectivity—this reflects broad social processing and social learning.
Dynamic ToM captures adaptive affiliative behavior (differential responding to cooperative vs competitive partners), fitting affiliation/attachment inclusion (cooperation/competition).
The analysis examines behavioral adaptation and connectivity related to mentalizing and learning rather than communication-specific processes (no measures of facial or vocal communication).
The dynamic ToM value indexes understanding of others and adaptation across partners, not self-focused perception or self-judgments.
This analysis explicitly operationalizes the representation and differentiation of multiple partners' intentions (dynamic ToM), directly matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

The task required participants to judge whether point-light displays or human-like walkers were facing towards or away, which directly involves perceiving and interpreting social cues and potential for social interaction. The contrast FT>FA measures differences in social processing related to movement direction.

The task does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of kinship, bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons). The contrast probes orientation/social involvement rather than attachment.

Judging facing direction from biological motion conveys socially relevant communicative information (non-facial body cues). PLD and HL stimuli serve as social signals; this contrast examines communicative/social cue processing.
The contrast does not involve self-referential judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; participants judged properties of observed agents rather than themselves.
The contrast examines perception of others’ actions/direction and infers social involvement — fits Animacy/Action Perception and Understanding Mental States examples (point-light biological motion).
FA>FT contrasts neural responses to movement direction (away vs towards) for PLD/HL, reflecting social cue interpretation and potential for social involvement.
No measures or conditions indexing affiliation or attachment; the contrast isolates directional social cues rather than bonding or cooperation.
Direction of motion is a communicative social cue (approach/avoidance); FA>FT examines processing of non-facial social signals conveyed by body motion.
No self-related processing or judgments are involved in this contrast.
Contrasts of directionality probe action perception and attribution about others (animacy/action perception), matching the inclusion examples (point-light biological motion).
HL>PLD contrasts human-like video stimuli against point-light displays; both involve social perception and interpretation of others’ actions and social meaning.
The contrast compares stimulus format (HL vs PLD) and does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation tasks).
Human-like videos provide richer social communicative cues (body kinematics, context) than PLD; the contrast assesses processing of communicative social information.
No self-referential or self-evaluative judgments are performed in this contrast; it concerns perception of others.
Directly assesses perception/understanding of others by comparing responses to HL vs PLD; meets examples (point-light biological motion and action perception).
PLD>HL examines greater MNS/MS engagement for sparse biological motion versus human-like stimuli — a social-processing contrast probing how social cues are encoded.
This contrast manipulates stimulus type and does not assess affiliation/attachment measures (no bonding/cooperation comparisons).
PLD carry non-facial communicative information via body motion; the contrast evaluates processing of such social communicative signals.
No self-related processing is required by this contrast; it targets perception of external agents.
Comparing PLD to HL probes action/animacy perception and inference about others’ intentions — directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others.
The STIMULUS*DIRECTION interaction tests how stimulus type and movement direction jointly modulate social-network activity (MNS/MS), directly measuring social processing.
Interaction concerns stimulus features and directionality, not affiliation/attachment constructs; no cooperation/attachment conditions present.
Interaction probes how communicative cues (body motion type and approach/away) affect neural processing of social signals, fitting Social Communication.
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are part of this interaction contrast.
Examines how perception of others (action direction and stimulus realism) affects neural responses — aligned with Animacy/Action Perception and understanding others’ intentions.
Post-hoc analyses further parse condition-specific social effects (e.g., which stimulus/direction combinations drive MNS/MS differences), thus directly addressing social processing.
Post-hoc contrasts concern stimulus/direction combinations; they do not measure affiliation or attachment constructs.
Post-hoc contrasts examine communicative content of specific conditions (e.g., how PLD vs HL in FT/FA influence social signal processing), matching Social Communication.
No self-related measures in post-hoc contrasts; analyses focus on perception of others.
Post-hoc tests specifically identify condition differences in perceiving others’ actions and intentions (e.g., PLD_FA>HL), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
FT_PLD>HL compares facing-towards PLD to HL, probing social cue processing when stimuli are interpreted as approaching — a social-processing contrast.
This specific contrast concerns stimulus type under FT direction and does not address affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.
FT_PLD>HL examines communicative body cues for approaching agents, assessing non-facial social communication from motion signals.
No self-related processing; participants judged others’ orientation, not self-properties.
Contrast assesses perception of others’ actions and social intent (approach) comparing PLD vs HL — directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others.
FT_HL>PLD contrasts HL vs PLD when facing toward the observer; this probes social processing of richer social cues in approaching human-like stimuli.
Although FT HL stimuli may signal social approach, the task does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation measures).
HL facing-toward provide strong social communicative signals (approach); the contrast examines processing of those communicative cues relative to PLD.
No self-related assessments; the contrast focuses on perception of other agents’ motion.
Directly probes perceiving others (approach direction) with human-like stimuli; aligns with action/animacy perception and inferring intentions.
FA_PLD>HL compares PLD vs HL in the facing-away condition, testing how social processing differs when social involvement potential is reduced/ambiguous.
The contrast manipulates stimulus format under FA direction and does not index affiliation or attachment constructs.
FA_PLD>HL evaluates communicative information derived from body motion even when agent is facing away; PLD can still convey non-facial social cues relevant to communication processing.
Participants judged others’ orientation; no self-referential processing is involved in this contrast.
This contrast directly addresses perception of others’ actions and the inference of social involvement when agents face away — fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
FA_HL>PLD contrasts human-like vs PLD when facing away; this tests social-processing differences linked to stimulus realism under reduced social involvement.
No measures of affiliation or attachment are present; contrast focuses on stimulus type and directionality only.
FA_HL>PLD assesses processing of communicative cues present in HL even when agent is facing away; examines social communication via body motion cues.
The contrast does not involve self-judgments or self-related processing.
Directly relevant to perception of others’ actions and intentions under FA conditions, matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.
PLD_FT>FA contrasts PLD facing-toward vs away, probing how direction modulates processing of social cues in point-light stimuli.
This contrast assesses orientation effects within PLD and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.
Contrast inspects communicative information in PLD across directions (approach vs away), reflecting social-communicative processing of non-facial cues.
No self-related tasks or judgments are involved; focus is on perceiving others’ motion direction.
Directly probes action/animacy perception of others using PLD and how direction affects inferred social involvement — fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
PLD_FA>FT compares PLD away vs toward, examining social-processing modulation by direction for point-light stimuli (social involvement inference).
Contrast deals with stimulus orientation and not affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation or bonding measures).
The comparison evaluates communicative cues in PLD when facing away versus toward, relevant to social communication via body motion.
No self-related processing; participants judge others’ orientations only.
Assesses perception and interpretation of others’ actions (PLD) and inferred social involvement — aligns with Perception and Understanding of Others.
HL_FT>FA contrasts HL approaching vs receding, testing social-processing sensitivity to movement direction for explicit human-like agents.
Although HL FT may signal social approach, the study does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs; no bonding/cooperation measures are present.
HL directionality conveys communicative approach/avoidance cues; this contrast probes processing of such social-communication signals in rich (HL) stimuli.
No self-focused judgments or self-reflection tasks are included in this contrast.
Directly examines perception of others’ actions (approach vs away) using HL stimuli and inference about social intent — meets Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
HL_FA>FT contrasts HL away vs toward; tests social-processing differentials when human-like agents are oriented away, assessing perceived social involvement.
This contrast manipulates stimulus direction and type but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or cooperation assessments).
HL facing-away still transmits communicative body cues; contrast assesses social-communication processing differences for away vs toward HL stimuli.
No self-referential judgments or self-knowledge tasks are involved in this contrast.
Directly relevant to action perception and inference about others’ intentions when facing away; aligns with Perception and Understanding of Others.

Movie-viewing ISC contrasts directly probe social cognition: subjects watched a moral dilemma between sisters and ISC differences reflect synchronized social-cognitive processing (mentalizing, moral evaluation). This fits Social Processing (broad social perception and response).

The contrast specifically manipulates perceived kinship (genetic vs adoptive sisters) and tests responses to kin-related social scenarios (kinship/attachment), directly measuring affiliation/attachment-related processing.

The movie stimulus contains interpersonal dialogue, emotional exchanges and nonverbal cues; ISC of these viewings captures shared processing of communicative social signals (receptive social communication), so the analysis engages social communication processes.

This analysis focuses on observers’ processing of others (the two sisters) and kinship/moral evaluation; it does not measure self-judgment, agency, or self-knowledge as defined by Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast examines mentalizing and evaluation of others (sisters’ actions and moral conflict) and the reported overlap with ToM/moral regions supports that it measures Perception and Understanding of Others (empathy, theory-of-mind).

The non-genetic>genetic ISC clusters (occipital visual areas) arise from the same movie social paradigm; the analysis is part of the social-processing experiment comparing kinship contexts and thus falls under broad Social Processing.

This contrast is the reverse of the kinship manipulation (non-genetic>genetic) and still probes responses tied to perceived kinship/attachment (how affiliation modulates processing), meeting the affiliation/attachment construct.

Even where ISC is stronger in occipital cortex for the non-genetic condition, the underlying task is a communicative movie (dialogue, social signals). The analysis derives from viewing social interactions and thus involves receptive social communication processes.
The contrast contrasts two views of others (genetic vs non-genetic sisters) and does not target self-related judgments or self-referential processing.
The manipulation targets observers’ representations and interpretation of the sisters’ mental states and actions (moral evaluation/mentalizing), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The moral-dilemma decision GLM localizes brain regions engaged when subjects choose between saving sister, friend, or strangers — a classic social-cognitive task probing moral/social decision-making, satisfying broad Social Processing.

The decision task explicitly probes kin-preference (choosing sister vs friend/strangers) and demonstrates a clear kin/affiliation effect (93% chose sister), so it measures affiliation/attachment processing.

The moral decision task is primarily about making evaluative choices (moral/affiliation preference) rather than measuring receptive or productive social-communication processes (e.g., face/gaze or communicative signal perception). The paradigm localizes moral/decision regions rather than social-communication per se.

Although decisions involve personal values, the task does not operationalize self-judgment or self-knowledge contrasts (e.g., Self>Other) and thus does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The decision task requires representing and evaluating others (sister, friend, strangers) and engages mentalizing/empathy-related regions; it therefore measures Perception and Understanding of Others.

The IAT contrast ('Incongruent vs. Congruent') probes implicit attitudes about monogamy vs. adultery, which are social constructs involving perception, interpretation, and regulation of social information relevant to relationships. This meets the Social Processing definition and the inclusion criterion (task is social-related).

The IAT specifically targets attitudes toward monogamy and adultery (romantic/attachment-related constructs). The contrast therefore measures processes relevant to affiliation and attachment (implicit evaluations about relationship fidelity). This matches the inclusion criterion for affiliation/attachment tasks.

Although the stimuli are social, the IAT contrast indexes implicit attitudes about relationship concepts rather than explicit reception or production of social communicative signals (e.g., facial expression or gaze). The task is not primarily a face/communication perception task, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion.

The contrast reflects implicit attitudes about adultery/monogamy and conflict processing, not explicit self-referential judgments or self vs. other comparisons. It therefore does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion (self-judgment or self-focused tasks).

While the stimuli depict social interactions, the IAT contrast is not designed to probe empathy, theory-of-mind, or detailed representation of others' mental states. It indexes implicit attribute associations rather than perception/understanding of others' emotions or intentions, so Perception/Others criterion is not met.

The 'Congruent vs. Incongruent' IAT contrast is derived from the same social task measuring implicit attitudes about monogamy/adultery and thus indexes social processing related to relationship judgments.

This contrast contrasts the social-affiliation related pairings (monogamy–positive / adultery–negative) and therefore pertains to affiliation and attachment constructs (attitudes toward romantic fidelity).

As above, the contrast reflects implicit evaluative associations rather than processing of communicative facial or gaze cues; it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criterion focused on reception/production of social signals.
The contrast does not measure explicit self-referential processing or self-judgment; it assesses implicit social attitudes, so it does not satisfy the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.

Although stimuli depict others, the contrast is not designed to probe understanding of others' mental states or empathy (Theory of Mind); it indexes implicit associations about social behavior rather than perception/understanding of others, so Perception/Others is not applicable.

The analysis tests phonological short-term memory and neural responses to letters vs. fingerspelling within a memory task. Although fingerspelling uses a communicative modality (sign language), the task probes memory/linguistic processing rather than social processes (affiliation, social interaction, perception of others’ emotions or intentions). It does not operationalize or measure social processing per the inclusion criterion I1.

The task does not measure affiliation or attachment (no paradigms involving bonding, cooperation, loved one vs stranger, or kinship scenarios). It is a memory/linguistic task and thus does not meet inclusion criterion I1 for this construct.

While the stimuli include fingerspelling (a communicative handgesture), the experimental contrast targets phonological maintenance and modality-specific neural substrates of memory/processing, not social-communicative behavior per se (e.g., emotion recognition, gaze, face/hand communication as social signals). The analysis does not operationalize social communication measures as required by inclusion criterion I1.

The analysis does not assess self-related processing (agency, self-judgment, viewing self, or self vs other contrasts). It is focused on memory maintenance of syllable sequences, so it fails inclusion criterion I1 for perception/self.

Although participants view another person’s finger movements (fingerspelling), the task does not probe perception/understanding of others’ emotions, intentions, or mental states (e.g., ToM, empathy, animacy judgments). It targets phonological STM and modality-specific visual/visuomotor processing rather than 'perception of others' constructs required by inclusion criterion I1.

The contrast (Letter > Fingerspelling) examines modality-specific neural activations related to letter perception and phonological maintenance. This is a language/memory contrast and does not measure social processing (affiliation, social interaction, or perception of self/others), so it does not meet inclusion criterion I1.

No measures or tasks related to affiliation, attachment, cooperation, or close-relationship processing are present in this contrast. It is a sensory/linguistic memory contrast, not an affiliation task (I1 not met).

The Letter > Fingerspelling contrast targets visual letter-processing and phonological memory rather than social communicative behavior. It does not operationalize receptive/expressive social communication constructs (faces, emotion, gaze, social hand gestures) required by inclusion criterion I1.

This analysis does not involve self-related judgments or contrasts (self vs other, agency), but instead probes letter perception and phonological maintenance; thus it does not meet inclusion criterion I1 for perception_self.

Although letters and fingerspelling are visually perceived, the contrast does not assess perception/understanding of others’ mental states, animacy, or action-intent inference. It reflects sensory/linguistic processing rather than constructs specified in inclusion criterion I1 for perception_others.

The contrast (romantic > neutral) uses images of couples and probes responses to social/romantic stimuli and group differences in social-affiliative processing; thus it clearly measures social processing at the neural level.

The task explicitly presents romantic (pair-bonding) stimuli and the contrast isolates neural responses to romance versus neutral images; this directly tests affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Viewing images of couples engages perception of social interactions and affective cues (receptive aspects of social communication); the contrast involves processing socially communicative visual information.
The contrast does not involve self-referential tasks (no self-judgment or viewing of the participant's own images); it probes responses to others/romantic scenes rather than self-perception.
Romantic images require perceiving and interpreting others' emotional/relational states (animacy/action/mental state cues), matching perception-of-others constructs.
The contrast (romantic > sexual) examines differential neural processing of social/romantic versus sexual stimuli, reflecting broader social processing differences in non-monogamous men.
The contrast isolates romantic (affiliation-related) processing relative to sexual stimuli; findings (increased cortical processing for romantic images) pertain to attachment/affiliation processing.

Comparing romantic to sexual images engages perception of social interactions and affective cues (receptive social-communication processes), and the contrast captures differences in processing those cues.
This contrast contrasts two external stimulus categories (romantic vs sexual) and does not involve self-referential judgments or tasks about the participant's own state.

Romantic images require inferring others' relational/emotional states; the romantic > sexual contrast highlights processing of others' affiliative behaviors and mental states, fitting perception-of-others criteria.
