Select > content contrast involves a social-related task: selecting articles engaged ROI sets including social-cognition regions (VMPFC, DMPFC, TPJ, PC, rSTS) and the authors state social considerations were engaged during selection. This meets I1 and the analysis measures social processing.

The select > content contrast measures decisions to read articles for oneself and does not specifically test affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship comparisons). Task is not designed to measure attachment, so I1 is not met.

Social communication focuses on exchange of socially relevant information (e.g., face/voice processing, communicative production/reception). The select > content contrast is about personal selection rather than communicative exchange; although social cognition ROIs are engaged, the task does not measure social-communication subconstructs, so I1 is not met.

Select > content robustly engages self-related processing ROIs (MPFC, PCC) and involves judgments about whether to read for oneself, matching the Perception/Self inclusion examples (self-judgment, thinking about self). Meets I1.

Although the contrast is self-focused, the authors report activation in social-cognition ROIs during selection and argue participants considered social implications; this engages understanding of others' mental states (ToM), matching Perception/Others inclusion criteria. Meets I1.
Share > content clearly probes social-related processing: deciding to share articles engages value, self-related, and social-cognition ROIs and is explicitly a social task. Meets I1.

Sharing decisions (broadcast and narrowcast) are explicitly social and linked by the authors to interpersonal bonding, reputation, and connection, which align with affiliation/attachment constructs (positive interactions and social bonds). The task measures sharing to social others, so I1 is met.

The share condition operationalizes communicative behavior (deciding to transmit information to others), fitting Social Communication (exchange of socially relevant information). The contrast measures communicative intent and thus meets I1.

Authors report MPFC/PCC engagement during sharing and link sharing to self-related motives (self-presentation, reputation). The task involves self-related processing (deciding to share relates to self-enhancement), meeting I1.
Sharing with others requires consideration of others' perspectives; the study reports activation in ToM/social-cognition ROIs and discusses perspective-taking, satisfying Perception/Others I1.

Share > select isolates increased social-related processing when considering sharing versus personal reading; authors report greater activation across value, self, and social ROIs in sharing, so this contrast measures social processing. Meets I1.

Share > select highlights processes more engaged for sharing (social bonding, reputation concerns) relative to selection; authors explicitly relate sharing to affiliation and interpersonal connection, which aligns with affiliation/attachment measurement. Meets I1.

This contrast compares communicative (sharing) to non-communicative (selecting) judgments, directly probing social-communication processes (information transmission). Thus it meets Social Communication I1.
Share > select shows greater MPFC/PCC engagement for sharing; authors interpret this as increased self-related processing during sharing (self-presentation motives), which fits Perception/Self I1.
Share > select recruits ToM/social-cognition regions more strongly (DMPFC, TPJ), indicating increased perception/understanding of others when sharing; this matches Perception/Others I1.

Parametric modulation of Select trials by preference examines how social/self/value ROIs scale with selection likelihood; authors report social-cognition ROI involvement during selection, so this analysis measures social processing. Meets I1.

Modulation of select-by-preference probes personal selection preferences rather than explicit affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/close-relationship contrasts). Does not meet affiliation I1.

This analysis concerns preference to select for personal reading and its neural correlates; it does not test communicative exchange per se (not a faces/voice/communication task), so Social Communication I1 is not met.
Select preferences scaled with activity in self-related ROIs (MPFC/PCC) per authors' report, matching Perception/Self examples (self-judgment). Meets I1.

Authors report that social-cognition ROIs also scaled with preference to select, indicating engagement of processes related to understanding others or social implications even for selection; thus Perception/Others I1 is met.

Parametric modulation of Share trials by preference directly probes social-related processes tied to willingness to transmit information; authors report scaling in value, self, and social ROIs for sharing, so this measures social processing. Meets I1.

Preference-to-share modulation targets the propensity to connect with others via sharing; authors link sharing preferences to social bonding and reputation, consistent with affiliation/attachment constructs. Meets I1.

This analysis examines neural scaling with propensity to communicate/share information (production of social communication), fitting Social Communication inclusion (exchange/production of social information). Meets I1.
Authors report MPFC/PCC activity scaling with share preferences (self-relevance/self-presentation motives), so this matches Perception/Self I1.
Share preference modulation engaged DMPFC and TPJ subregions linked to social cognition/ToM, reflecting perception/understanding of others; this meets Perception/Others I1.

The SELF vs OTHER contrast was derived from a social interactive task (telling jokes and hearing listener responses). It directly probes social processing (self-relevant vs other-relevant outcomes) and is part of the study’s social interaction framework.

Although this contrast isolates self-related activity, the task context is a positive social interaction (eliciting laughter) that indexes social reward and bonding; thus the contrast is relevant to affiliation/attachment processes (self actions leading to affiliative responses).

The task involves production (reading/telling jokes) and perception of non-facial auditory social signals (laughter). The SELF minus OTHER contrast distinguishes self-related communicative context and therefore pertains to social communication.
This contrast is the canonical Self > Other comparison (SELF minus OTHER), explicitly measuring self-related processing (mPFC activation). It matches the Perception/Self inclusion examples.

The contrast specifically isolates self-related activation (SELF > OTHER) and does not primarily measure representations of others or their mental states; therefore it does not meet the Perception/Other inclusion criteria.
The Group vs No Laughter contrast indexes responses to social auditory feedback (laughter) during an interactive social task, and thus measures social processing.

Group laughter is a strong affiliative social signal and the contrast (Group vs No Laughter) probes reward/positive bonding associated with social feedback, consistent with affiliation/attachment constructs.
This contrast isolates neural responses to auditory social communication (laughter), i.e., reception of non-facial communicative signals, matching the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
The Group vs No Laughter contrast is collapsed across SELF and OTHER and does not specifically test self-related representations or self-judgment; it therefore does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
This contrast measures perception/processing of others’ responses (laughter) and auditory cues indicating others’ behavior, fitting the Perception/Other inclusion criteria.
Single vs No Laughter contrasts neural responses to an interpersonal social signal (single-person laughter) within the interactive task; this indexes social processing.
Single laughter is a positive social response (albeit weaker than group laughter) and the contrast probes social reward/interaction relevant to affiliation processes.
The contrast isolates reception of non-facial auditory social communication (single laughter) and therefore meets Social Communication criteria.
The contrast collapses across speaker (SELF and OTHER) and therefore does not specifically probe self-related representations or judgments.
This contrast measures processing of another’s auditory response (single laughter) and thus targets perception/understanding of others’ responses or states.
Group vs Single Laughter contrasts two types of social auditory feedback within the interactive social task, indexing social processing of differing social feedback magnitudes.
Comparing group to single laughter assesses differences in the strength of affiliative/social reward signals; this directly relates to affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast involves reception of non-facial auditory communicative signals (different laughter types) and therefore falls under Social Communication.
This contrast focuses on types of listener responses and is collapsed across SELF/OTHER; it does not specifically index self-related representation.
Group vs Single contrasts processing of others’ behavioral responses (different laughter types) and therefore matches Perception/Other inclusion criteria.
The action-outcome contingency interaction explicitly addresses social interactive processing (how self-actions vs others’ actions influence reward-related responses), central to social processing.

This interaction captures how self-generated actions that produce affiliative responses (group laughter) drive reward (ventral striatum) — directly relevant to affiliation/attachment and social bonding.

The contrast operationalizes how communicative outcomes (laughter) contingent on agent (self vs other) modulate brain responses — a core Social Communication process (reception of non-facial cues within interaction).

The interaction explicitly contrasts self-related outcomes vs other-related outcomes (SELF_Group vs OTHER_Group interactions) and was associated with self-related region (mPFC) and VS; it therefore measures Perception/Self processes tied to agency and self-monitoring.

Because the interaction involves the listener’s responses (others’ laughter) and their differential effect when contingent on self vs other, it also probes perception/processing of others’ responses and states.

The Single-laughter action-outcome contingency interaction is a social-interaction contrast probing whether self-contingent single laughter modulates reward processing; it therefore indexes social processing.

Though this contrast specifically targets single-person laughter (weaker affiliative cue), it still probes whether self-contingent social feedback influences reward/attachment-related processing, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
The contrast tests processing of communicative auditory feedback (single laughter) contingent on agent (self vs other) and therefore pertains to social communication.
This interaction contrasts self- vs other-contingent responses specifically for single laughter, thus addressing self-related outcome monitoring and agency-related processes (Perception/Self).
The contrast explicitly involves others’ responses (single laughter) and their differential impact when contingent on self vs other, so it probes perception/understanding of others’ responses.

The PPI between mPFC and right auditory cortex tests interactions among brain regions supporting self-relevance, auditory social feedback, and reward processing — a distributed social processing network.

The PPI identified modulation of ventral striatal activity by mPFC–auditory cortex interactions that correlated with subjective pleasure — linking to affiliative/social reward processes and thus affiliation/attachment.

The analysis explicitly examines interaction between a self-related region (mPFC) and an auditory region processing communicative laughter — directly addressing reception/processing of non-facial social communication and its integration.

The PPI uses an mPFC seed identified by the SELF effect (self-related processing), so the analysis probes how self-related signals modulate connectivity and thus measures Perception/Self processes (agency/self monitoring).

The PPI uses an auditory cortex seed reflecting perception of others’ laughter; the interaction term therefore probes how representations of others’ responses are integrated — meeting Perception/Other criteria.

The PPI between mPFC and left auditory cortex examines the network-level integration of self-relevance and auditory social feedback with reward processing, squarely within social processing constructs.
As with the right-AC PPI, connectivity among mPFC, auditory cortex, and VS relates to subjective pleasure from contingent social feedback, linking to affiliation/attachment-related reward.

The analysis tests interactions between self-related and auditory social-signal regions (left AC), addressing reception and integration of non-facial communicative cues — a Social Communication measure.
Using the mPFC seed (self-related region) the PPI assesses how self-signals modulate connectivity; this directly addresses Perception/Self processes.
The left auditory cortex seed indexes perception of others’ auditory responses; the PPI therefore probes representation and integration of others’ responses, satisfying Perception/Other criteria.

The contrast examines mentalizing (Theory of Mind) with similar vs dissimilar others — a canonical social processing task involving perception, interpretation and reasoning about social information and relationships. This directly meets the Social Processing definition.

Although the study includes affiliation/likability ratings, this specific analysis is the Mentalizing Task contrast (Dissimilar > Similar) focusing on mental state attribution processes rather than on affiliation/attachment measures or direct cooperative/attachment behavior. The Mentalizing Task involves inferring mental states from statements and photos rather than measuring receptive/expressive social communication (e.g., facial emotion recognition, gaze, or mimicry). Thus it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast isolates mentalizing about others (Dissimilar > Similar). It does not index self-perception or self-judgment processes (Self > Other contrasts were modeled separately but are not this analysis).

The contrast explicitly targets understanding and reasoning about others' mental states (mentalizing with dissimilar vs similar targets), directly matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct, including the 'Understanding Mental States' subconstruct.

The working memory maintenance analysis includes both competition and no-competition conditions and reports activity in mentalizing/default-mode regions (mPFC, PCC/precuneus) related to social comparison and distraction. The task manipulates a social context (competition), so it measures social processing.

The task directly manipulates competition (a form of social comparison/cooperative-competitive context) during working memory maintenance; thus it assesses affiliation/attachment-related social processes tied to competition.

The paradigm does not involve communication signals such as facial expressions, gaze, or explicit communicative exchanges; it manipulates competition and social comparison but not receptive/expressive social communication stimuli.

Results implicate self-referential processing (mPFC deactivation/activation linked to performance and social comparison), indicating that analyses probe perception/understanding of the self in a social context.

Competition requires representing and updating information about another person (the confederate/opponent) and the paper reports activation in mentalizing regions (precuneus/PCC, STS, mPFC) consistent with perceiving/understanding others.

The performance parametric modulator in the no-competition condition still sits within the overall social task context (comparison across social vs nonsocial conditions) and measures neural responses related to task performance/attention; social processing is a primary focus of the study and contrasts include social context.

Although this analysis is the no-competition condition, it is part of the larger study manipulating competition and social comparison; performance-related effects are interpreted relative to the competition condition, so affiliation/competition-related constructs are relevant.
The no-competition performance parametric analysis does not involve communicative stimuli (faces, gaze, or explicit social signals), so it does not meet criteria for social communication.

Performance-related deactivation in mPFC and PCC across conditions (including no-competition) indexes self-referential/task-related processes; thus the analysis addresses aspects of self-perception/monitoring.

Even in the no-competition condition, the contrast is part of comparisons with the competition condition and the study interprets midline activity in social/other-referential terms; the region-of-interest and correlations relate to social/other processing.

The performance parametric modulator for the competition condition directly probes neural responses when participants believe they are competing, engaging social processing (mentalizing, social comparison) as reported in the paper.
This analysis explicitly measures competition, a form of social comparison/cooperative-competitive interaction, matching the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria (competition tasks).
The competition performance parametric modulator does not involve communicative signals like faces or gaze; it manipulates competition and social comparison but not social communication per se.

Competition-related activity in mPFC and PCC during working memory maintenance indicates engagement of self-referential processes (e.g., performance monitoring, self-other comparison), so perception_self applies.

Competition requires representing/updating information about an opponent; observed activation in mentalizing regions (precuneus/PCC, STS) during competition indicates processing of others' states and performance.

The event-related feedback analysis contrasts feedback processing with and without competition, directly tapping social processing (responses to social feedback, mentalizing) as discussed in the paper.

Feedback in the competition condition includes information about an opponent's performance (social comparison/competition), so this analysis measures affiliation/attachment-type constructs (competition-related social processing).

Although feedback is social (comparing to an opponent), the stimuli are numeric performance indicators rather than communicative signals like faces, gaze, or expressions; thus it does not meet the operationalization of social_communication.
Feedback evokes self-referential processes (mPFC engagement) and comparisons that reflect perception/understanding of one's own performance; the analysis probes self-related processing at feedback.

Feedback contains information about the opponent and requires updating knowledge about another person; the analysis shows activation in regions (precuneus/PCC, STS) implicated in understanding others, so include.
The Competition > No competition contrast at feedback isolates social processing elicited by competitive feedback (greater mPFC, PCC/precuneus, STS activity), directly measuring social processes.
This contrast specifically compares competition to no competition during feedback, directly targeting competition/social comparison—matching affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Although the contrast isolates social effects, the stimuli are performance feedback rather than communicative signals (faces/gaze/etc.), so it does not meet the examples for social_communication.
The Competition > No Competition feedback contrast engages self-referential processing (mPFC differences) related to social comparison and self-monitoring, so perception_self applies.
The contrast reveals greater activation in regions involved in representing others (precuneus/PCC, STS) when viewing competitor-related feedback, indicating perception/understanding of others.

The No Competition > Competition contrast examines feedback-related activity favoring the noncompetitive context; because the study centers on social effects of competition, this contrast still informs social processing differences between contexts.

This contrast is the inverse comparison of competition effects and therefore relates to affiliation/attachment constructs by comparing social vs non-social feedback contexts (competition vs no competition).
As with other contrasts, stimuli are performance feedback without explicit communicative signals (faces/gaze/emotion), so social_communication does not apply.

Differences favoring no-competition involve midline regions tied to self-referential/task engagement; thus this contrast informs perception/self processes related to task focus and performance monitoring.

Even in the No Competition > Competition contrast, interpretive comparisons with the competition condition and observed midline/mentalizing regions make this contrast informative about processing of others and social context.

Contrast CC > average(other outcomes) derives from a one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma social interaction (mutual cooperation vs other social outcomes). This directly measures social processing (perception, interpretation and response in social interaction).

The contrast isolates mutual cooperation (CC) which indexes affiliation/attachment-related behavior (cooperation) in the PD game; the task is explicitly a cooperation paradigm (example task listed in I1).

The task involves exchange of socially relevant information (decisions to cooperate/defect) and includes partner face presentation; CC > others reflects communicative social interaction outcomes (fits I1 examples such as cooperation and face stimuli).

CC > others engages regions (dMPFC/rACC) and is discussed in the paper as involving self-referential/moral evaluation and subjective feelings (happiness/trust), indicating processes related to perception/understanding of the self in the social outcome context.

The contrast reflects representations and valuation of another agent’s cooperative behavior (partner choice), i.e. understanding others’ actions and intentions in the PD game; thus it measures perception/understanding of others.
The A > CC contrast is from the same PD social task and indexes neural responses to non-CC social outcomes; it therefore measures social processing.

Although this is the reverse contrast (other outcomes > CC), it still derives from the cooperation/competition PD task and therefore pertains to affiliation/attachment processes (responses to non-cooperative outcomes within an affiliation paradigm).

This contrast reflects processing of social interaction outcomes (partners’ cooperative/defective behavior) and comes from a task that involves face stimuli and social exchange—consistent with social communication.

Non-CC outcomes include DC and CD which the authors link to self-directed emotions (shame/guilt for DC; anger/disappointment for CD); thus this contrast captures self-relevant emotional/moral processing tied to participants’ own actions and outcomes.
The contrast indexes responses to partner behavior (e.g., partner defecting vs cooperating) and thus taps into representation/assessment of others’ actions and intentions in the social exchange.
Gain > Loss is computed across trials of the PD social task; it captures how social processing differs under gain vs loss context and therefore measures social processing.

The contrast compares contexts for the same cooperation task (gain vs loss) and thus pertains to affiliation/attachment processes by modulating cooperative behavior and its valuation (task is cooperation-based as per I1 examples).

Contextual modulation (gain vs loss) affects processing of social interaction outcomes and is based on a task that uses partner faces and communicative choices; this falls under social communication measures.

Gain > Loss is a context modulation across the social task rather than a contrast explicitly probing self-referential judgments or self > other comparisons; the contrast primarily indexes contextual effects on social valuation, not explicit self-processing.

The contrast reflects how participants represent and respond differently to others’ actions/outcomes under gain vs loss frames, i.e. modulation of understanding others’ behavior by context (fits I1/I2 for perception of others).
Loss > Gain is derived from the Prisoner’s Dilemma social paradigm and indexes social processing differences under loss vs gain contexts, so it meets the social processing criterion.
Because the analysis concerns the same cooperation task (PD) and compares contexts that modulate cooperative behavior/valuation, it is relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.

The contrast concerns contextual modulation of social interaction outcomes (partner behavior and participant responses) within a task that involves face presentation and social exchange; thus it falls under social communication.
The Loss > Gain contrast indexes contextual effects on social outcome processing rather than explicit self-judgments or self > other contrasts, so it does not primarily measure Perception of Self.

Loss > Gain captures how contextual framing alters representation and evaluation of others’ actions in the PD task (i.e. understanding others under different outcome frames), fitting perception-of-others criteria.
The interaction (cooperation-specific effect in Gain vs Loss) isolates how social cooperation representations differ by context; it directly probes social processing tied to cooperative outcomes.
This interaction specifically tests how the neural signature of mutual cooperation (an affiliation/attachment behavior) is modulated by context (gain vs loss), so it measures affiliation/attachment.

The contrast examines context-dependent neural responses to cooperative social exchanges (partner behavior and outcome communication), consistent with social communication processes and the task's face/social-exchange elements.

The interaction isolates context modulation of reward-related responses to cooperation (ventral striatum) rather than explicitly probing self-referential judgments; it therefore does not primarily index Perception/Self processes.

The interaction identifies regions where sensitivity to others’ cooperative acts (and their value) differs by context, reflecting representation and evaluation of others’ behavior under different frames.
The reverse interaction ((CC–A)loss–(CC–A)gain) is still a social-task-derived contrast examining context-modulation of cooperation processing, thus indexing social processing.

Even as the reverse interaction, the contrast pertains to the cooperation/affiliation PD paradigm and so relates to affiliation/attachment processes (contextual modulation of cooperation-related activity).
This contrast concerns context-dependent differences in neural responses to social exchange outcomes from the PD task and therefore qualifies as social communication-related.

Like the forward interaction, the reverse interaction primarily indexes modulation of reward-related cooperation signals rather than explicit self-evaluation contrasts, so it does not primarily measure Perception of Self.
The contrast pertains to how representations of others’ cooperative/defective behavior differ by context (loss vs gain) and thus measures perception/understanding of others.

Grasping vs faces involves social stimuli (actions and faces) and addresses social perception and processing of others' behavior.

This contrast examines perception of others' actions and faces, not self-related processes or judgments.

Faces > Grasping directly targets reception of facial communication (emotion/face perception), matching social communication criteria.
This contrast compares perception of others' faces to actions and does not involve self-related judgments or agency.
Faces > Grasping measures perception and understanding of others' emotional facial states (perception of others).
Interaction between grasping and neutral grasping across emotion runs probes how social context modulates perception of others' actions — a social processing analysis.
The interaction addresses contextual modulation of action perception, not affiliation or attachment constructs.
The interaction involves facial expressions and action contexts, relevant to reception of facial/non-facial social cues (social communication).
Analysis examines perception of others and contextual effects, not self-related processing.
Interaction tests how context (angry vs joyful runs) alters perception of others' grasping actions, directly assessing perception of others.
ROI/PPI analysis contrasts Angry > Joyful runs, examining network changes during social-emotional perception of others; this is a social processing analysis.
PPI analysis examines anger-related connectivity; it does not assess affiliation or bonding constructs.
Analyses probe connectivity between insula and STG during perception of emotional faces/actions — relevant to reception of facial/non-facial social cues (social communication).
Connectivity analyses concern processing of others' emotional actions, not self-related processes.
PPI with right insula seed shows coupling with STG during angry grasping — this directly indexes perception and neural representation of others' emotional actions.
Angry grasping vs joyful grasping isolates social-emotional modulation of observing others' actions, a social processing effect.
This contrast contrasts emotional contexts of actions but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs.
Comparison of emotional action conditions (angry vs joyful grasping) pertains to reception of socially communicative emotional cues in faces/actions.
Contrast focuses on perceiving others' emotional actions rather than self-related judgments or agency.
This contrast measures perception and understanding of others' emotional action (angry vs joyful), matching perception_others criteria.
PPI seed in right insula examines connectivity changes during social-emotional conditions (anger vs joy), reflecting social processing of others.
PPI connectivity analysis focuses on emotion-related network changes, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Seed-based connectivity with STG during emotional face/action perception addresses receptive social communication processes (facial/non-facial cues).
Analysis probes inter-regional coupling during perception of others, not self-related cognition.
PPI examines how insula connectivity with STG changes when perceiving others' angry vs joyful actions — a direct measure of perception of others.

Contrast compares Social scenarios requiring contextual adjustment vs Physical scenarios without adjustment (SocAdj > PhyConf). This directly targets social cognitive processing (Theory of Mind) and reproduces classical ToM localizer effects.
Task and contrast probe mental state inference and contextual integration, not affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition).
REMICS probes mentalizing and context integration via written scenarios rather than communication-specific processes (faces/gaze/expression production or reception).
Contrast concerns understanding others' mental states and contextual adjustments, not self-related judgments or self-monitoring.
Contrast isolates social mental-state inferences (Soc) relative to non-social baseline and therefore probes perception/understanding of others (Theory of Mind).
Response-period contrast SocAdj > PhyConf engages full ToM network during explicit social inference and context integration at response, indexing social processing.
No measures of affiliation/attachment (no bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition contrasts).
Task involves reading and inferring mental states rather than communication-specific reception/production (faces, gaze, vocal communication).
Designed to probe others' mental states and contextual adjustments, not judgments about self.
Response-period contrast strongly involves inferring others' intentions and beliefs and thus maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others (ToM).
Time-point 1 contrast (Soc > Phy) compares reading social vs physical scenario sentences that evoke intention inferences, engaging social processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs being measured in the Soc > Phy contrast.
Contrast taps mentalizing from written scenarios, not communication-specific channels like faces/gaze/expression production or reception.
Contrast concerns others' mental states (social scenarios) rather than self-related processing.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 1 elicits regions associated with understanding others' intentions and beliefs, fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (ToM).
Time-point 2 Soc > Phy compares social vs physical scenarios after context presentation and taps social cognitive processing (mental-state representation).
No affiliation/attachment specific measures or contrasts (not about bonding or cooperation).
Task involves inferring mental states from text rather than communication-specific reception/production.
Contrast targets representation of others' mental states, not self-related judgments.
Soc > Phy at Time-point 2 activates regions implicated in Theory of Mind and understanding others, meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
Response-period Soc > Phy reflects explicit social inference processing during decision making and engages ToM network, indexing social processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs assessed in this response-period Soc > Phy contrast.
Contrast measures mentalizing and context integration rather than communication-specific behaviors (faces/gaze/etc.).
Contrast concerns judgments about others' mental states, not self-related processing.
Response-period Soc > Phy engages mental state inference and ToM-related regions, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Time-point 2 Adj > Conf contrasts trials requiring contextual adjustment vs confirmation across social and physical scenarios. Although mixed, the contrast includes social trials and probes processes (context integration) relevant to social cognition in the REMICS task.
Adj > Conf manipulation addresses contextual updating rather than affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast concerns contextual updating and inference adjustments, not communication-specific reception or production.
Contrast addresses contextual adjustment processes across scenario types, not self-related judgments.

Adj > Conf includes social adjustment trials (SocAdj) as part of the contrast and thus probes updating of inferences about others; it is relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others in the REMICS context.

Response-period Adj > Conf isolates contextual adjustment-related processing at decision time across social and physical trials; because social trials are included and ToM processes are central to the study, this contrast is relevant to social processing.
Contrast taps contextual updating and cognitive control rather than affiliation or bonding measures.
Focus is on contextual adjustments and inference updating rather than social communication channels (faces/gaze/exchange).
Contrast concerns updating of inferences (including about others) at response, not self-judgments.
Although Adj > Conf pools social and non-social trials, it includes SocAdj and thus probes updating of representations about others (relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others).
Condition SocAdj is explicitly social (mental-state inferences requiring contextual adjustment) and directly measures social cognition/processing.
SocAdj involves mentalizing and context integration but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
SocAdj uses written scenarios to probe mental state inference rather than communication-specific signals or behaviors.
SocAdj targets understanding others' mental states, not self-related processing.
SocAdj explicitly involves inferring others' intentions/beliefs and adjusting them with context, meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
SocConf is a social condition (social scenarios with contextual confirmation) and involves representing others' mental states, thus indexing social processing.
SocConf does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation contrasts).
SocConf measures mentalizing from text rather than communication-specific reception/production channels.
Condition focuses on others' mental states rather than self-related judgments.
SocConf requires understanding others' mental states (albeit confirmed by context) and therefore fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
PhyAdj is a physical scenario condition (contextual adjustments for non-social events) and does not primarily probe social processing or mental-state attribution.
Physical adjustment condition does not involve affiliation/attachment constructs.
PhyAdj involves non-social physical event inference and not social communication processes.
This condition involves reasoning about physical causes rather than self-related processing.
PhyAdj concerns physical events without a character; it does not assess understanding others' mental states.

SA vs SC contrasts agentic vs communal trait ratings during self-evaluation — a social-cognition task (self-related social trait judgments). Meets social processing inclusion (task is social-related).
Contrast compares two types of trait self-evaluation (agency vs communion) during self-judgment; it does not measure affiliation/attachment (no kinship, cooperation, or clear social-bond measure).

Task involves trait judgments (self-evaluation) rather than communicative behavior or perception/production of facial/non-facial communicative signals, so it does not match Social Communication criteria.
This is a self-evaluation contrast (self-judgment of agentic vs communal traits) — directly probes perception/understanding of the self. Meets Perception_Self inclusion (self-judgment).
Contrast concerns self-evaluation rather than reasoning about others' mental states or attributes; does not target perception/understanding of others (ToM/empathy).
SC vs SA is a self-evaluation contrast of communal vs agentic traits — a social-cognition task involving trait judgments about the self.
The contrast contrasts trait types during self-judgment and does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/social-bond measure).
This task is trait self-evaluation, not an exchange or perception/production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, emotion recognition), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
SC vs SA involves judgments about the self (self-referential trait evaluation), directly meeting Perception_Self inclusion criteria (self-judgment).
Contrast is centered on self-evaluation rather than understanding or inferring others' states or traits, so Perception_Others criteria are not met.
OA vs OC contrasts endorsement of others' agentic vs communal evaluations of the self — a social task involving processing of social feedback and social trait information.

Endorsement of others' evaluations involves processing of social feedback/social comparison with peers (classmates). This maps onto affiliation/social comparison aspects of affiliation/attachment inclusion examples.

Although it involves others' evaluations, the task is not about perceiving/producing communicative signals (faces, gaze, vocal emotion). It is an evaluative judgment task rather than Social Communication per the specified examples.
Endorsing others' evaluations of oneself requires self-referential judgment (agreeing with others about oneself), so it meets Perception_Self inclusion (self-judgment/reflected self-assessment).

This contrast requires consideration of others' evaluations of the participant (processing what others think about the participant) and thus involves aspects of perceiving/understanding others' judgments; it fits Perception_Others inclusion (representations about others' traits/mental states).
OC vs OA contrasts endorsement of others' communal vs agentic evaluations of the self — clearly a social-cognition task involving processing social feedback.
Task involves endorsement of peers' evaluations (social feedback/social comparison), which relates to affiliation/attachment processes as described in inclusion examples.
The contrast centers on evaluative judgments of trait words, not communicative signal perception/production (faces, gaze, etc.), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
Endorsing others' evaluations about the self is a form of reflected self-judgment, fitting Perception_Self inclusion (self-judgment/reflected self-knowledge).
This contrast requires representing/considering others' evaluations of the participant (understanding others' judgments), so it meets Perception_Others inclusion criteria.
SA vs Fixation regression examines neural responses during agentic self-evaluation and their relationship to self-esteem — a social-cognition/self-related analysis.
This contrast focuses on agentic self-evaluation and its correlation with self-esteem, not on affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation/social-bond manipulation).
The analysis is about trait self-evaluation and brain–behavior correlations, not communicative signal perception/production; it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
SA vs Fixation directly indexes self-evaluation (agentic trait judgments) and is therefore within Perception_Self (self-judgment/self-knowledge) criteria.
This analysis concerns self-evaluation and its relation to self-esteem rather than reasoning about others' mental states or traits, so Perception_Others is not met.
PPI with dlPFC seed (SA > Fixation) examines connectivity during agentic self-evaluation — a social-cognition/self-related processing analysis.
This connectivity analysis is specific to self-evaluation (SA) and does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/social-bond contrasts).
The PPI probes functional connectivity during self-evaluation of trait words, not communicative signal perception/production, so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The seed-based connectivity analysis concerns dlPFC activity during the self-evaluation (SA) condition, directly indexing self-referential processing (Perception_Self).
Although social in context, this PPI examines self-evaluation connectivity and not explicit representations or inference about others' mental states; thus Perception_Others is not met.
dlPFC seed Fixation > SA connectivity contrast is derived from the same social self-evaluation paradigm and is part of social-cognition analyses (contrasts involving SA and Fixation).
This contrast reflects connectivity differences with fixation relative to self-evaluation and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no social-bond/cooperation manipulation).
The contrast addresses connectivity during non-communicative task conditions (fixation vs self-evaluation) and is not a Social Communication task per the defined examples.

Even though this is the inverse contrast (Fixation > SA), it is part of the self-evaluation connectivity analysis and relates to Perception_Self because it indexes networks engaged (or disengaged) during self-judgment.
This connectivity contrast is not targeting representations or inferences about others' states/traits, so Perception_Others criteria are not met.
Thalamus seed PPI (SA > Fixation) examines connectivity during agentic self-evaluation — clearly part of social/self-related processing.
This thalamic connectivity analysis is anchored in self-evaluation and information-integration/attention processes, not explicit affiliation/attachment measures.
The analysis probes connectivity during trait self-evaluation rather than communicative signal perception/production, so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion examples.
Thalamic connectivity during SA (agentic self-evaluation) indexes networks engaged while evaluating oneself, meeting Perception_Self criteria.
This PPI examines self-evaluation processes and thalamic coupling, not explicit understanding of others' mental states or traits, so Perception_Others is not met.
Thalamus seed Fixation > SA contrast is derived from the social self-evaluation paradigm and therefore part of social processing analyses.
This inverse connectivity contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no social-bond/cooperation manipulation), so it does not meet affiliation criteria.
The contrast pertains to connectivity differences between fixation and self-evaluation; it is not a Social Communication task as defined (faces, gaze, emotion recognition, etc.).
Although an inverse contrast, it is part of the analyses probing networks engaged during self-evaluation (thalamic connectivity relative to fixation), thus meeting Perception_Self inclusion.
This connectivity contrast does not examine representations of others' mental states/traits and therefore does not meet Perception_Others criteria.

Contrast compares aggressive vs non-aggressive reactions within a social interaction paradigm (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) involving opponents; therefore it probes social processing (perception, interpretation and response to social provocation).

The task is a competitive social interaction (provoking vs non-provoking opponent). Competition is listed as an example under affiliation/attachment constructs; the contrast probes social bonding/competition dynamics.

The paradigm involves exchange of socially-relevant information (choices of aversive feedback, outcome feedback) and interactive decisions; the contrast reflects production/reception of socially relevant signals in an interaction.
This contrast does not probe self-judgment or explicit self-related processing (no self > other or self-evaluation task).
Contrast directly involves responses to another agent’s provocative versus non-provocative behavior and thus taps representation/understanding of others’ actions/intentions in a social context.
Reverse contrast of analysis_0; still a social interaction contrast within the TAP, probing responses to others and social behavior.
Contrast reflects competitive/social relationship dynamics (non‑provoking vs provoking opponent) which falls under cooperation/competition examples of affiliation/attachment.
Involves interactive exchange (choice of feedback, social outcome), so captures social communication processes in the task.
No explicit self-related judgments or self‑other comparison are assessed in this contrast.
Contrasts behavior toward different opponents and thus implicates representation/understanding of others’ behavior (provoking vs non‑provoking).
Won > lost is an outcome contrast within the TAP, a social interaction paradigm, and thus relates to social processing (responses to social outcomes).
Winning and losing in a competitive social task index social comparison/competition aspects relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition example).
Outcome phase communicates socially-relevant information (opponent choices, feedback); the won>lost contrast captures processing of that interpersonal exchange.
Contrast does not assess self-awareness, explicit self-judgment, or agency; it contrasts outcomes rather than self-referential processing.
This contrast addresses outcome valence (win vs loss) across opponents and does not specifically probe representation or mental-state understanding of others (no opponent-specific mentalizing).
Lost > won is an outcome contrast within the TAP social interaction and thus involves social processing of negative outcomes and anticipated social feedback.
Losing in a competitive social interaction engages social comparison/competition processes relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Outcome phase contains communicated feedback from opponents; lost > won reflects processing of that interpersonal communication (including anticipation of aversive feedback).
No explicit self-related judgment or self-referential processing is isolated in this contrast.
Contrast focuses on outcome valence (loss) rather than explicit representation or inference about the opponent’s mental states or traits; not a targeted ToM/empathy contrast.
Contrast compares winning against provoking vs non‑provoking opponent — an explicitly social/opponent‑specific contrast in the TAP, engaging social processing.
Opponent-specific winning involves competitive dynamics and social comparison relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition example).
Outcome information and opponent behavior are exchanged; this opponent‑specific contrast reflects processing of communicated social signals and their effects.
No self-evaluation or self‑referential judgement is directly measured by this contrast.
Directly contrasts outcomes depending on opponent type (provoking vs non‑provoking), implicating perception/representation of others’ behavior and its meaning.
Opponent-specific winning contrast (non-provoking > provoking) within the TAP — involves social processing of interactions and outcomes.
Reflects competitive/social relationship dynamics (winning against different types of opponents) relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Outcome phase conveys social information and opponent-specific differences; this contrast captures processing of that communicated social content.
Does not probe explicit self-related judgments or self-other comparisons in the sense required by the perception_self construct.
Contrasts outcomes across opponent types and thus involves representation/understanding of others’ behavior (provoking vs non‑provoking).
Lost against provoking > lost against non-provoking is an opponent-specific outcome contrast within a social interaction, engaging social processing.
Losing against different opponents indexes competitive/social relationship dynamics relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Outcome phase contains communicated opponent feedback; opponent-specific loss contrasts capture processing of that social communication.
No explicit self-focused evaluative processing is isolated in this contrast.
Directly involves differences in others’ behavior (provoking vs non‑provoking) and thus taps representation of others’ actions/intentions in the social context.
Opponent-specific loss contrast (non‑provoking > provoking) in the TAP; relates to social processing of outcomes and opponent behavior.
Reflects competitive/social comparison dynamics (losing against different opponents) relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
Outcome information is communicated by the opponent; opponent-specific contrasts index processing of that interpersonal exchange.
No self-referential judgments or agency assessments are explicitly isolated here.
Contrast depends on opponent identity and behavior, implicating perception/understanding of others’ actions and intentions.
Retaliation independent of opponent probes decision-making about others within the TAP social interaction and thus indexes social processing.
Choosing punishments (retaliation) in a social competitive context implicates social comparison/competition processes relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Decision phase entails producing communicative social signals (chosen feedback) and receiving outcome feedback; the contrast captures social communicative behavior.
Contrast indexes decision-making in social interaction rather than explicit self-evaluation or self-knowledge constructs.
Although independent of opponent, the modulation of retaliation reflects how participants represent and respond to other agents in the task (understanding others’ provocations/expectations).
Retaliation interacting with provoking opponent is an explicitly social/opponent‑specific decision contrast, directly probing social processing of provocation and response.
This contrast captures competitive/retaliatory dynamics in response to a provoking opponent — an instance of social relationship/competition relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Decision to retaliate against a provoking opponent reflects communicative social behavior (sending a punitive signal) and processing of exchanged social information.
No direct measures of self-judgment, agency, or self-knowledge are isolated by this contrast.
This contrast specifically involves responding to another agent’s provocative behavior and thus taps perception/understanding of others’ actions/intentions in the interaction.
Retaliation interacting with non‑provoking opponent is a social decision contrast within the TAP and relates to social processing of interactions with a benign other.
Decision-making toward a non‑provoking opponent reflects competitive/social relationship dynamics (choices toward different social partners) relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Choosing feedback to a non‑provoking opponent remains an act of social communication (producing a signal in an interpersonal exchange), so the contrast indexes social communication processes.
No explicit self-referential processes or self-judgments are isolated in this contrast.
Although non-provoking, the contrast concerns responses to another agent and thus involves perception/representation of others’ behavior and intentions in the interaction.
General 'Won' outcome in the TAP is embedded in a social interaction and therefore engages social processing of outcomes and reward in an interpersonal context.
Winning in a social competitive game involves social comparison/competition relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Outcome information (win) is communicated in the task and has interpersonal significance; this contrast reflects processing of that communicated social outcome.
The contrast does not isolate self-focused judgments or self-knowledge (no explicit self‑evaluation task).

This general win contrast is not opponent-specific and does not directly probe representation or inference about others’ mental states; thus it does not meet the perception_others inclusion example criteria.
Won against provoking opponent is an opponent-specific outcome contrast in the TAP and clearly involves social processing (responses to an opponent).
Opponent-specific winning entails competitive/social relationship processes and social comparison (competition example) relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Outcome and feedback are part of an interpersonal exchange; this opponent-specific win contrast captures processing of socially communicated signals.
No self-referential processing (self-judgment or self-knowledge) is isolated by this contrast.
Contrast depends on the provoking opponent’s identity and behavior, implicating perception/understanding of others’ actions and the meaning of their provocations in the interaction.
Won against non‑provoking opponent is an opponent-specific TAP outcome and thus engages social processing in an interpersonal context.
Winning against a non‑provoking opponent involves competition/social comparison processes relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Outcome feedback and opponent behavior are components of the interpersonal exchange; this contrast reflects processing of that social communication.
No explicit self-focused judgments or self-knowledge assessments are isolated here.
Contrasts involve different opponent types and therefore implicate perception/representation of others’ behavior and intentions in the social interaction.

The contrast Social-Reg > Social-Look isolates effects of socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation delivered by a psychotherapist (video instruction). This is a clearly social task engaging social cognition and DMN nodes; the analysis directly measures social processing during regulation.

The study explicitly measured attachment security (Adult Attachment Scale) and correlated attachment scores with Social-Reg-related activations (OFC). The Social-Reg contrast was used in these brain–behavior correlations, so the analysis relates to affiliation/attachment.

Social-Reg trials used a psychotherapist's video instructions (spoken communicative guidance) to induce reappraisal. The contrast captures processing of this socially conveyed regulatory communication and its neural effects.

The task probes participants' own emotional experience and regulation (ratings of affect; self-focused reappraisal implementation), so the contrast measures processes related to perception/understanding of the self (self-referential emotion regulation).

Social-Reg requires understanding and following the psychotherapist's intentions and perspective (mentalizing), and the Social-Reg > Social-Look contrast revealed activations in mentalizing-related regions (dmPFC, TPJ, precuneus), so it measures perception/understanding of others.

This conjunction identifies regions commonly engaged by Social-Reg and Self-Reg, capturing shared social/cognitive processes involved in regulation. Because one of the tasks is Social-Reg and the conjunction includes its social components, this analysis measures social processing.

The conjunction isolates common neural substrates of Social- and Self-Reg but does not directly test affiliation or attachment constructs (no contrast of loved vs stranger or attachment-specific task). Although attachment was measured elsewhere in the study, this specific analysis does not operationalize affiliation/attachment.

Both tasks present regulatory instructions (video vs written cue) and the conjunction likely captures processing related to instruction reception and regulation implementation; thus it engages social-communication-related processes tied to receiving regulatory cues.

Self-Reg explicitly engages self-referential regulation processes and the conjunction isolates regions shared with Social-Reg, reflecting neural systems supporting perception/understanding of one's own emotional state and regulation.

Because the conjunction includes Social-Reg, which requires understanding the therapist's perspective, some of the common regions may reflect processes relevant to perceiving others; the analysis therefore partially indexes perception of others in the social regulation context.

This analysis identifies areas specifically more engaged during Social-Reg than Self-Reg (dmPFC, precuneus, TPJ), i.e., social-cognitive and DMN regions. It therefore directly measures social processing unique to socially-induced regulation.

The contrast isolates social-cognitive (mentalizing) regions specific to Social-Reg but does not directly operationalize affiliation or attachment per se (no affiliation-specific stimuli or contrasts). Attachment was assessed elsewhere but is not the direct focus of this distinct-areas contrast.

Distinct Social-Reg activations reflect processing of the psychotherapist’s social guidance and perspective-taking demands, i.e., socially communicated reappraisal; thus the contrast indexes social communication processes relevant to regulation.

The distinct Social-Reg regions (dmPFC, TPJ, precuneus) are primarily associated with mentalizing and social cognition (perception/understanding of others) rather than tasks explicitly probing self-judgment or self>other contrasts; this specific contrast therefore does not primarily operationalize self-perception.

The distinct Social-Reg areas correspond to canonical mentalizing regions (TPJ, dmPFC, precuneus) involved in representing others' mental states; the contrast directly measures perception/understanding of others in the social regulation context.

This analysis identifies regions preferentially engaged by Self-Reg (e.g., left IFG, inferior parietal cortex) in a self-initiated reappraisal task presented with written cues. The task is intrapersonal and not social in nature, so it does not meet the social-processing inclusion criteria.

Self-Reg does not operationalize affiliation or attachment (no attachment-specific stimuli or contrasts), and the distinct Self-Reg activations are not tied to the attachment measures used elsewhere; therefore this analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Self-Reg used written cues and pre-learned distancing strategies without an interpersonal communicator; the contrast isolates intrapersonal regulation and is not a social-communication task (no face-to-face or communicative exchange).

Self-Reg is explicitly an intrapersonal reappraisal task relying on self-generated regulation and self-referential processes; the distinct Self-Reg activations therefore index perception/understanding of the self (self-focused regulatory mechanisms).

The Self-Reg-specific contrast isolates brain regions supporting self-implemented regulation and does not probe perception or reasoning about others’ mental states; thus it does not meet the perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast isolates increased frequency of social interaction in a Cyberball ball-toss task (ball-toss high-frequency > normal-frequency, contrasted with button-press), directly measuring social processing—enjoyment and neural responses to social inclusion/exchange (ventral striatum, precuneus). This meets I1 (social-related task) and measures Social Processing.

The Cyberball manipulation probes affiliation/belonging and positive social bonding (increased tosses to participant produce greater-than-anticipated enjoyment and reward-system activation). The task therefore measures affiliation/attachment constructs (belonging, cooperative/affiliative interaction). This meets I1.

Although the task is minimalistic, ball-tosses function as nonverbal social exchange/attention signals; the contrast isolates responses to increased social exchange. The analysis therefore indexes social communicative exchange (receptive/reciprocal nonverbal communication) and meets I1.

The study reports precuneus activation and interprets it as positive self-image/self-related processing triggered by increased inclusion. The contrast therefore involves self-related perception/representation processes. This meets I1.

The task requires monitoring others’ tossing behavior and inferring others’ attention/intention (representation of others’ actions and social states). The contrast captures perception/understanding of others in a social interaction context, meeting I1.

Contrast 'Meaning > Physical' explicitly manipulates interpretive attitude to elicit social-cognitive processing (activations in mPFC and TPJ), so this analysis measures social processing related constructs (mentalizing/social cognition).

This contrast compares meaning vs physical properties across stimuli in general and does not assess affiliation, attachment, or social bonding (no measures like loved one vs stranger or cooperation/competition).

The meaning task elicits regions (IFG, TPJ) associated with semantic/communicative processing and the authors describe reading models as communicative signs; thus it taps aspects of social communication (receptive interpretation of communicative object meaning).
The contrast addresses meaning vs physical properties generally and is not a self-related (self>other) contrast or explicit self-judgment task, so it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion.

The meaning judgment engages brain regions (mPFC, TPJ) commonly implicated in understanding others' mental states/mentalizing; although stimuli are objects, the task invokes social inference processes about socially constituted meanings, meeting the Perception/Others criterion.

The 'Physical > Meaning' contrast emphasizes perceptual and motor/object-processing regions (fusiform, precentral) and does not probe social or mentalizing processes; it does not meet the social-processing inclusion.
No measures of affiliation, bonding, or cooperative/competitive social scenarios are present in this contrast.

This contrast focuses on physical/perceptual processing of objects (fusiform, motor areas) rather than receptive or productive social communication, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion.
The contrast does not involve self-related judgments or ownership (no Self>Other manipulation), so it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion.
The analysis does not assess understanding of others' mental states or social interactions; it targets object perception and motor-related processing.

Contrast 'Own > Other' (within meaning task) elicits dmPFC, ACC, TPJ and precuneus—regions linked to social cognition, autobiographical memory and agency. This directly involves social processing (self-related social cognition).
While this contrast distinguishes self-generated versus other-generated models, it does not specifically measure affiliation/attachment (no cooperation/kinship/close-relationship manipulation).

The contrast targets self- versus other-related responses to one's own models (episodic/self-referential processing) rather than explicit social communication (e.g., face/gesture/language communication).
This is an explicit Own > Other contrast in the meaning-related task, activating areas associated with self-referential processes and agency (mPFC, precuneus), meeting the Perception/Self inclusion.
The contrast contrasts self > other and is centered on self-referential processing; it does not target representation or reasoning about others' mental states per se.

The interaction (own>other × collective>individual) isolates neural responses related to socially embedded, collective self-relevant artifacts and implicates ACC, IFG, insula—regions linked to social salience and emotion—so it measures social processing.

The interaction effect specifically relates to collective/own models and is further modulated by participants' self-reported relatedness to group members (insula activity correlates with relatedness), directly indexing affiliation/attachment-related variance.

Although IFG is engaged, the effect is described as relating to social salience/emotion and affiliation rather than explicit communicative exchange or reception/production of communicative signals; the task does not directly measure social communication.
The interaction contrasts own vs other specifically (and is driven by own collective models), indexing self-relevant perception/agency and thus meets the Perception/Self inclusion.
The analysis focuses on self-relevance within collective contexts and on affiliation-related modulation; it does not measure representation or reasoning about others' mental states in isolation.

Task involves perceiving and evaluating faces and links neural responses to later social behavior (trustworthiness), meeting broad social processing criteria.
Analysis predicts racial trust disparity (evaluative judgments of trustworthiness), which directly relates to affiliation/approach and social bonding processes (approachability/trust).
Task involves viewing faces and decoding social signals (trustworthiness), matching Social Communication inclusion (reception of facial communication).
Task and contrasts concern perception and evaluation of other faces (trustworthiness), not self-related judgments or self-perception.
Analysis concerns representing and evaluating others' traits (trustworthiness) and differences by race, directly fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
PPI connectivity predicting racial trust disparity concerns social perception and subsequent social behavior, fitting broad social processing.
Connectivity between OFC and fusiform predicts later trustworthiness disparity (approachability/trust), relating to affiliation/attachment processes.
Connectivity during viewing of faces examines reception/processing of facial cues relevant to trustworthiness, matching Social Communication.
Analyses address perception/evaluation of other faces and not self-related processes or judgments.
Connectivity effects predict how participants perceive and evaluate others' trustworthiness, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis links neural responses during face perception to later racial differentiation disparity, a social perception process, meeting the broad social processing definition.
This analysis targets perceptual differentiation of faces (individuation) rather than affiliation/attachment or trust-related judgments, so does not meet affiliation-specific criteria.
Task involves viewing faces and assessing perceptual differentiation (reception of facial information), consistent with Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Measures concern perception of others' faces and differentiation, not self-knowledge or self-judgment.
Analysis measures perception and individuation of others (differences in perceived trustworthiness across faces), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis of neural activation predicting less differentiation disparity concerns social perception processes and later social-cognitive behavior—fits social processing.
This contrast addresses perceptual/cognitive differentiation (individuation) rather than affiliation/attachment or trust-based bonding measures.
Involves viewing faces and the reception of facial information relevant to differentiation, aligning with Social Communication inclusion.
Contrast pertains to perception of others and cognitive control (dlPFC), not self-related processing.
Predicts individual differences in perceiving and differentiating other people (faces), meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
PPI between dlPFC and cingulate predicting differentiation disparity reflects social perceptual and cognitive processes, fitting broad social processing.
Connectivity predicting perceptual differentiation (individuation) is not an affiliation/attachment measure (no cooperation/relationship bonding tasks), so excluded.
Connectivity during face perception involves reception of facial cues and individuation relevant to social communication constructs.
Connectivity effects concern perception and differentiation of others' faces rather than self-related processes.
PPI predicts how participants perceive and individuate others (faces) across race, aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task directly involves social evaluation (positive, neutral, negative videos) requiring perception and interpretation of social cues; the contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunction) measure social processing across valences.

Positive videos contain affiliative content (praise/compliments) and negative videos express social hostility/rejection; the contrasts probe responses to affiliative vs. non-affiliative social signals relevant to attachment/affiliation.

Participants viewed audiovisual sentences delivered by posers communicating social-evaluative content; this is a receptive social communication task (affective speech/facial/body cues) so the contrasts measure social communication processing.

Participants were instructed to imagine a real interaction and results emphasize MPFC/rACC self-referential processing; contrasts implicate self-related appraisal and thus measure perception/understanding of self.

Stimuli require reasoning about posers’ intentions and emotions (mentalizing/empathy) and reported activations (temporal, MPFC, insula) reflect perception and understanding of others; contrasts therefore measure perception of others.
Same experimental paradigm and contrasts as analysis_0 (positive/negative vs. neutral); all probe social processing of evaluative videos.
Analyses contrast responses to affiliative (praise) and non-affiliative/hostile stimuli; measures are directly relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
Analyses derive from viewing and processing of audiovisual social-evaluative sentences (receptive social communication), satisfying criteria for social_communication.
Task instructions and observed MPFC/rACC engagement indicate self-referential appraisal during the contrasts, matching perception_self construct.
Contrasts require and evoke representations of the poser’s mental/emotional states (mentalizing, empathy), so they measure perception and understanding of others.
This conjunction analysis (positive>neutral & negative>neutral) identifies common social processing networks engaged by evaluative social stimuli, meeting social_processing_all criteria.
The conjunction isolates regions responsive to both affiliative (positive) and aversive (negative) evaluations; involvement of social valuation/affiliation processes justifies inclusion.
The conjunction reflects common neural responses to communicated social-evaluative content across valences, thus indexing social communication processing.
Conjunction results emphasize MPFC/rACC common to both contrasts, regions linked to self-referential processing, indicating perception_self relevance.
Common activation across valences reflects regions supporting mentalizing and understanding others’ evaluations; thus perception_others is measured by this analysis.
