The negative vs. positive feedback contrast is embedded in a social context (verbal performance feedback and financial loss) and probes affective responses to social feedback; therefore it assesses social-related processing at the level of social evaluation and emotion.

This contrast indexes negative versus positive performance feedback and associated emotion/arousal rather than measures of affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment per se; it does not directly test attachment or affiliation constructs.
The feedback was delivered verbally and constitutes social/auditory communication; the contrast therefore involves processing of communicated social information.

The contrast reflects participants' internal affective state in response to feedback (valence, physiological changes) and thereby involves perception/awareness of self-relevant emotional state (self-focused affective processing).

This contrast primarily probes the participant's own affective response to feedback rather than representations or inference about another person's mental states; it does not directly measure perception/understanding of others.
EE>EN compares emotionally empathic vs unempathic verbal comments, directly probing social processing (empathy, social support) and its neural correlates.

Emotionally empathic vs unempathic comments test processes relevant to social bonding/feeling understood; authors report mOFC (reward/valuation) engagement, consistent with affiliation/attachment relevance.
This contrast involves reception and evaluation of verbal social communication (compassionate vs uncaring utterances), matching the social communication construct.
EE>EN targets processing of received empathic communication and associated social-cognitive/emotion networks rather than explicit self-judgments or self-referential cognitive evaluation.

Evaluating another's empathic versus unempathic verbal response requires representing the speaker's communicative intent and hence understanding others' social-emotional behavior (ToM/empathy-related processes).
EN+CN > EE+CE contrasts unempathic vs empathic comments overall, a direct social-processing contrast assessing reactions to different social responses.

Aggregating unempathic vs empathic comments taps social connectedness/being supported vs rejected, relevant to affiliation/attachment processes (authors report temporal/putamen activations associated with negative social processing).
This contrast evaluates reception of socially relevant verbal communications that differ in interpersonal attitude, therefore directly indexing social communication processing.
The contrast concerns processing of others' communicative attitudes rather than explicit self-judgment or introspective appraisal as the main construct.
Discriminating unempathic vs empathic utterances requires inferring others' attitudes/intentions and thus engages perception/understanding of others (empathy/mentalizing).
CN>CE (cognitive unempathic > cognitive empathic) contrasts different social responses (verbal indications of understanding vs lack thereof) and probes social processing.
Cognitive unempathic statements (e.g., “I don’t understand what you feel”) can undermine perceived social connection; this contrast probes signals relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast evaluates reception of differing verbal communicative acts (paraphrasing vs denial of understanding), fitting social communication criteria.
The focus is on processing the communicator's stance rather than on explicit self-related judgments or self-reflection.
Distinguishing whether the speaker indicates understanding vs not requires representing the other's mentalizing and communicative intent, i.e., perception/understanding of others.
EE+CE > baseline contrasts empathic interventions during distress against a non-distress baseline and therefore probes social support processing and related social cognition.

Receiving empathic support while distressed is directly relevant to affiliation/attachment and perceived social support; authors link empathic responses to feeling understood and reward-related regions.
Contrast involves reception of verbal empathic communications versus baseline and thus assesses processing of social communicative signals.
Although participants' feelings change, the contrast is focused on processing empathic input (others' communication) rather than explicit self-referential judgments as the primary construct.
Processing empathic interventions requires understanding the speaker's communicative intent and mental states (empathy/mentalizing), so perception of others is engaged.
EE > baseline examines neural responses to emotionally empathic comments compared to a non-distress baseline, directly probing social/empathic processing.
Emotionally empathic (compassionate) comments are tightly linked to affiliation and perceived social support; the authors report mOFC engagement, consistent with reward/affiliation processing.
This contrast assesses reception of affect-laden verbal social communication (compassionate comments) vs baseline, fitting social communication criteria.
Primary focus is on processing the other's emotionally empathic communication rather than on explicit measures of self-judgment or introspection.
Evaluating emotionally empathic utterances requires representing the speaker's affective stance and intent (mentalizing/compassion perception), so perception of others applies.
CE > baseline contrasts cognitively empathic comments (paraphrasing/understanding) vs baseline; this probes social cognitive processes related to being understood and social support.
Cognitive empathy (feeling understood) relates to perceived social connectedness and validation; authors report fronto-parietal engagement consistent with social bonding processes.
This contrast tests reception of verbal communicative acts that convey understanding (paraphrase) versus baseline, directly mapping onto social communication.
Although participants' self-reported feelings change, the contrast primarily evaluates processing of another's communicative act (understanding) rather than self-reflection per se.
Cognitive empathy implies inferring/representing the speaker's understanding and intent; hence this contrast engages perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).
(EE+EN) > (CE+CN) contrasts emotional versus cognitive interventions and probes differential social processing of two types of empathic communication.
This contrast tests differences between emotional and cognitive communicative styles rather than directly measuring affiliation/attachment or bonding; it does not explicitly index attachment.
The contrast compares two forms of verbal social communication (emotional vs cognitive empathy), directly relevant to reception/processing of social communicative content.
The contrast assesses processing style differences in received social communications rather than self-judgment or self-referential processing.
Differentiating emotional vs cognitive empathy requires representing the communicator's affective intent and mental-state stance (mentalizing/other-perception), so perception of others applies.
EE > CE (emotionally empathic > cognitively empathic) directly contrasts two social responses and probes social/empathic processing differences.

Emotional empathy (compassion) compared to cognitive empathy may more strongly engage affiliative/reward processes (authors report mOFC engagement); thus this contrast is relevant to affiliation/attachment.
This contrast concerns reception of two distinct verbal social communicative styles (compassionate vs paraphrase) and therefore maps onto social communication processes.
Primary emphasis is on processing the speaker's style and its neural correlates rather than on explicit self-focused judgments.
Distinguishing emotional vs cognitive empathic utterances requires representing the speaker's affective mentality and communicative intent (mentalizing), so perception of others is involved.
EN > CN (emotional unempathic > cognitive unempathic) contrasts different forms of unempathic social responses and probes social processing of negative interpersonal signals.
This contrast compares two kinds of unempathic utterances and is not primarily designed to index affiliation or attachment processes (no direct measure of bonding).
It evaluates reception and differential processing of verbal unempathic communications (affective vs cognitive denial), fitting the social communication construct.
The contrast focuses on processing of others' unempathic statements rather than explicit self-evaluation or self-related cognitive processing.
Discriminating emotional vs cognitive unempathic utterances necessitates representing the speaker's attitude/intent, engaging perception/understanding of others.
CN > EN (cognitive unempathic > emotional unempathic) contrasts different forms of unempathic social responses and probes social processing of these verbal signals.
This contrast pits two types of unempathic utterances against each other and does not directly operationalize affiliation/attachment or bonding measures.
The contrast concerns processing of differing verbal communicative content (denial of understanding vs dismissal) and thus qualifies as social communication processing.
The contrast is focused on the communicator's stance rather than explicit self-focused cognition or self-judgment measures.
Evaluating cognitive vs emotional unempathic remarks requires inferring the speaker's stance and intentions, i.e., perception/understanding of others.

Study uses affective Theory of Mind (ToM) cartoon stories and emotional facial expressions (EFE) to probe social cognition; this analysis belongs to the overall set and is therefore measuring social processing.
Tasks probe affective ToM and EFE detection, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation/competition manipulations).
Analyses involve perception of facial expressions and affect recognition (receptive facial communication), matching the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Tasks focus on inferring others' emotions (ToM) rather than self-referential judgments or self-perception; therefore Perception of Self is not measured.
The paradigm explicitly tests understanding others' emotional states (affective ToM), directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
EFE > no EFE contrast examines social cue (facial expression) effects during affective ToM—core social processing.
Contrast tests emotion inference from faces, not affiliation/attachment (no measures of relationships or bonding).
Contrast directly contrasts presence vs absence of facial expressions (receptive facial communication), meeting Social Communication criteria.
Contrast addresses perception of others' emotions, not self-related processing.
EFE > no EFE during affective ToM measures representations and inference about others' emotional states (ToM).
No EFE > EFE contrast examines brain regions more engaged when facial cues are absent during social inference—still social processing.
Contrast reflects cognitive demand in ToM without facial cues, not affiliation/attachment processes.
Although this contrast emphasizes absence of facial cues, it still pertains to social communication processes (how facial signals affect processing).
Contrast concerns inference about others rather than self-perception or self-judgments.
No EFE > EFE identifies neural substrates recruited to represent others' affect when perceptual cues are absent—directly relevant to Perception/Understanding of Others.
Correlation of differential activation (EFE>no EFE) with RT reduction examines how social cues (faces) affect social-cognitive performance—falls under social processing.
Correlation targets processing speed and neural response to facial emotion during ToM, not affiliation/attachment metrics.
Correlates neural sensitivity to facial expressions with behavioral facilitation—directly relevant to Reception of Facial Communication (social communication).
Analysis links neural/behavioral responses to others' facial cues, not self-related judgments.
Correlation probes how neural markers of perceiving others' emotions relate to task performance in inferring others' states, meeting Perception of Others criteria.
Correlation of no EFE > EFE differential activation with RT reduction still investigates social inference processes (how absence of faces modulates processing).
Focus is on cognitive demands of inferring others' emotions without facial cues, not affiliation/attachment.
Even as a contrast emphasizing lack of facial cues, the analysis addresses social communication mechanisms (how facial information affects communication/inference).
This analysis is about representations of others' emotions and task performance, not self-perception.
Examines neural correlates of inferring others' affect in the absence of facial cues—meets Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.
Interaction analysis tests how EFE effects depend on explicit affective ToM demand — a social-cognitive interaction, thus social processing.
Interaction concerns task demands and facial cues in ToM, not measures of affiliation/attachment.
Examines modulation of face-derived signals (communication) by ToM demand, fitting Social Communication (reception) criteria.
Interaction focuses on processing others' emotions under different task demands, not self-related processing.
Interaction explicitly tests how perception/representation of others' affect depends on presence of facial cues and task demand — directly Perception of Others.
Complementary interaction contrast also addresses social inference with/without facial cues — part of social processing domain.
Contrast again addresses cognitive and perceptual aspects of ToM, not affiliation/attachment behaviors or relationships.
This contrast evaluates how facial communication interacts with task demand — relevant to reception of facial communication.
Analysis centers on others' emotional states and task-modulated processing, not self-related judgments.
Contrast pertains to how perception/representation of others' emotions varies by presence of facial cues and ToM demand — fits Perception of Others.
PPI tests connectivity between right basolateral amygdala and ToM network modulated by EFE—investigates network-level social processing.
PPI examines neural connectivity during EFE-modulated ToM, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Connectivity changes relate to processing of facial expressions (EFE) and their impact on communication of affect—meets Social Communication criteria (reception and network-level effects).
PPI addresses interactions relevant to inferring others' emotional states, not self-perception.
PPI specifically targets modulation of amygdala-to-ToM-network connectivity during perception/inference of others' emotions—directly within Perception/Understanding of Others.
Positive correlation between affective ToM matching and PPI effects links neural connectivity and accuracy in social inference—core social processing.
Correlation concerns performance in ToM and connectivity, not affiliation/attachment measures.
Correlation assesses relation between network responsiveness to facial/affective signals and successful reception/interpretation—meets Social Communication criteria.
Focus is on matching others' affective states with consensus, not self-related processing.
Correlation links connectivity to successful inference about others' emotions (matching consensus), directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others.
Negative correlation between matching and PPI effects still probes social inference performance and neural connectivity—part of social processing.
This analysis connects neural connectivity and ToM consensus matching, not affiliation/attachment constructs.
Negative correlations indicate network aspects of processing facial/affective signals that relate to communication/perception of emotion—meets Social Communication criteria.
Analysis pertains to inference about others and its neural correlates, not self-perception.
Findings relate connectivity to accuracy in inferring others' emotional states (consensus matching) and so map to Perception/Understanding of Others.

Contrast (Attitude > Age) tests control of interpersonal trust/distrust — clearly a social task measuring social processing of interpersonal attitudes.
Task manipulates trust/distrust (formation and change of interpersonal bonds/attitudes), which maps onto affiliation/attachment constructs (trust as core of social bonding).
Stimuli are faces and participants evaluate/mentalize about others (face-based social judgments), matching Social Communication (reception of facial communication).
Contrast targets perception/attitudes about others (trust/distrust) rather than self-related judgments or self>other contrasts; does not measure self-perception.
Contrast probes representation and evaluation of others’ trustworthiness and mental states (theory-of-mind/other understanding), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Trust > Age directly tests deliberate control of interpersonal trust — a social processing task.
The contrast isolates attempts to increase/endorse trust, a process central to affiliation and relationship formation.
Participants view faces and form social judgments (trust), aligning with reception of facial communication.
This contrast concerns judgments about others’ trustworthiness rather than self-related processing or self>other contrasts.
Trust judgments require representing others’ traits/intentions (mental state inference), meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
Distrust > Age examines control of negative interpersonal attitudes — a social processing contrast.
Distrust manipulation affects social bonding/avoidance and negative affiliation-related evaluation, relevant to attachment/affiliation constructs.
Faces are the stimuli and participants infer negative social intent (distrust), fitting Social Communication (face reception) inclusion.
Focus is on perceiving and evaluating others (distrust), not on self-related judgments or self-referential processing.
Distrust judgments require attributing intentions/traits to others (theory-of-mind/other understanding), matching this annotation.
Individual-differences analysis links PrC activity with change in trust — directly about social attitude change and social processing.
Individual differences in increasing trust reflect variability in affiliation-related processes (willingness to form social bonds), fitting affiliation/attachment.
Analysis concerns responses to faces and social judgments (trust) — falls under reception of facial social communication.
This regression examines variation in responses to others (trust change), not self-evaluation or self>other contrasts.
Change-in-trust scores index how participants represent and update beliefs about others’ trustworthiness — core to Perception and Understanding of Others.
Individual-differences analysis linking IFG activity to change in distrust addresses social attitude control and social processing.
Change in distrust pertains to negative affiliation/avoidance and modulation of social bonds, relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Distrust analyses involve face-based judgments and likely inner speech/cognitive labeling of social cues — within Social Communication (reception of facial communication).
Analysis concerns updating evaluations of others (distrust) rather than self-related processing; does not meet self-perception criteria.
Linking IFG activity to distrust-change reflects processes of attributing negative traits/intentions to others (understanding others), matching this annotation.
PrC connectivity analysis examines networks associated with changing trustworthiness evaluations — clearly social processing related.
PrC connectivity with mPFC/dlPFC/ACC relates to neural substrates underpinning forming/updating trust and affiliation, fitting affiliation/attachment.
Seed connectivity derived from face-based trust manipulation (reception/processing of faces) aligns with Social Communication.
Connectivity relates to representation and updating of others’ trustworthiness rather than self-referential processing; does not measure self-perception.
PrC connectivity analysis addresses neural interactions involved in representing and consolidating social attitudes about others, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
IFG connectivity-negative analysis tests networks associated with changing distrust — a social processing functional connectivity result.
IFG negative connectivity with dmPFC/temporal pole during distrust manipulation reflects circuits modulating social avoidance/affiliation-related processing, so affiliation/attachment applies.
Seed region derived from face-based distrust task and examines communication/attribution networks tied to face evaluation — fits Social Communication.
This connectivity analysis indexes networks for perceiving/controlling evaluations of others (distrust) rather than self-related judgments, so Perception_Self not met.
Negative IFG connectivity reflects regulation of representations about others’ intentions/traits (theory-of-mind/other understanding), matching this annotation.

Contrast compares speech-containing trials (Words) to Faces-only controls within interactive communicative videos. Task probes comprehension of communicative interactions and recruits social cognition regions (e.g., right TPJ), so it measures social processing.

The contrast does not probe affiliation, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship processing; it contrasts linguistic vs face-only stimuli in communication contexts, not bonding measures.
The analysis isolates responses to words (speech acts) versus faces, directly indexing social communication (receptive language/face processing in interactive contexts).

The task involves observing interactions between others and does not ask subjects to judge or reflect on themselves (no self > other contrasts or self-judgment), so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.

The contrast engages regions implicated in theory-of-mind and social perception (e.g., right TPJ) and involves understanding others' communicative acts, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
Request > Naming directly contrasts two communicative speech-act types in interactive social contexts; the task probes social processing of communicative intentions and action predictions.

The contrast targets differences in speech-act comprehension (Requests vs Naming) and action prediction/theory-of-mind networks, not affiliation or bonding constructs (no measures of attachment/cooperation).
This contrast isolates communicative function (directive Requests vs referential Naming) using identical utterances in different contexts, directly indexing social communication processes.
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are involved; participants observed others' interactions without self-evaluation demands.
Request understanding recruited action-prediction and ToM-related regions (premotor, IFG, TPJ/pSTS) and hence reflects perception/understanding of others' actions and intentions.
Duplicate Request > Naming analysis similarly probes social processing of communicative actions and intentions in the interactive speech-act paradigm.
Same rationale as analysis_1: contrast concerns communicative intent/action prediction, not affiliation/attachment measures.
As with analysis_1, this contrast isolates communication type (Requests vs Naming) and therefore meets the social communication inclusion criteria.
No self-related processing required by the task; participants passively observed interactions.
The contrast implicates understanding others' intentions and predicting their actions (mirror/action and ToM systems), fitting perception/understanding of others.
Naming > Request (even if not significant at FDR threshold) is part of the same speech-act manipulation probing social communicative processing (referential aspects of communication).
The Naming > Request contrast targets referential/semantic aspects of communicative acts, not attachment or affiliation constructs.
Naming is a communicative speech act and the contrast examines communicative processing (linking words to referents), meeting the social communication criteria.
No self-related tasks or contrasts (self-judgment, viewing self) are involved in Naming > Request; participants observed others.

Naming involves perceiving and understanding others' communicative acts and reference linking; the study reports TPJ involvement across speech acts, consistent with perception/understanding of others.

This contrast examines activation for agentic and communal trait-word processing versus implicit baseline; the task is explicitly social (processing social trait content) and measures social processing broadly (mentalizing and social-cognitive networks).

The analysis includes communal (affiliation-related) trait words as part of the conjunction with agentic words; communal content targets affiliation/attachment-related constructs (warmth/morality), so the contrast measures affiliation-related processing.

Task is valence classification of trait words, not an exchange or perception/production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, vocal emotion); it does not measure social communication per the inclusion examples.
Participants performed valence classification of trait words without self-judgment or explicit self-focused instructions; the contrast does not index perception/understanding of the self as required.

Processing trait-descriptive words engages representations relevant to perceiving and understanding others (mentalizing-related activations reported); thus the contrast relates to perception/understanding of others.
This contrast (agentic and communal blocks vs fixation baseline) evaluates processing of social trait words and associated social-cognitive networks, meeting the broad social processing construct.
Communal (affiliation-related) words are part of the contrasted conditions; the analysis therefore probes affiliation/attachment-related content processing relative to baseline.
The task is not a social communication paradigm (no face/gaze/expressive communication stimuli or production), so it does not meet the social communication inclusion criteria.
No self-judgment or self-referential instruction was used; the contrast does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self.

Trait-word processing and the reported engagement of mentalizing regions indicate relevance to representing others’ traits and intentions, so this contrast maps onto perception/understanding of others.

This contrast (Agency > Communion) compares two social-content conditions (agentic vs communal trait words) and probes social-cognitive processing tied to agency, thus falls under broad social processing.
The contrast tests agentic > communal (agency-biased activity); it is not aimed at measuring affiliation/attachment per se and does not primarily index affiliation processing.
Contrast compares social trait content dimensions during a valence classification task, not communicative signal perception/production; it does not meet social communication criteria.
The contrast does not involve self-judgment or explicit self-referential processing (it contrasts agentic vs communal word processing), so it does not meet perception_self criteria.

Although focused on agency, the contrast involves social trait content and engages regions implicated in understanding others’ traits/intentions; thus it is relevant to perception/understanding of others.
This contrast (Communion > Agency) directly tests processing differences for communal (affiliation-related) versus agentic trait words; it clearly measures broad social processing.

The contrast emphasizes communal (affiliation/warmth/morality) content relative to agency, directly indexing affiliation/attachment-related processing and attentional engagement with communal information.

The contrast concerns social trait content (valence classification) rather than communicative signal reception or production (faces, gaze, imitation), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
No self-referential or self-judgment task was performed; this contrast does not measure perception/understanding of the self.
Communal vs agentic contrasts involve representations of social traits and recruited mentalizing/mirror-system regions, supporting inclusion under perception/understanding of others.

The contrast examines racial bias in perception of disgusted faces ((disgusted out-group–neutral out-group)–(disgusted in-group–neutral in-group)) during a passive face-viewing task. This is a social task probing perception and interpretation of social cues (emotion and group membership), so it measures broad social processing.

The task and contrast probe prejudice and emotion perception for in-/out-group faces rather than affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes (no measures of kinship, cooperation, or relationship closeness). Therefore it does not meet criteria for affiliation/attachment.

The analysis involves viewing facial expressions (disgust vs neutral) and group membership, directly indexing reception of facial communication (emotion recognition). This matches criteria for social communication tasks (viewing faces/emotion).

The contrast probes perception of others' facial expressions and group-related prejudice rather than self-referential processing, self-judgment, or viewing one’s own face, so it does not meet criteria for perception/self.
The contrast measures representations and evaluation of others' emotional states (disgust) as modulated by group membership, which fits the perception/understanding of others construct.

This analysis reports positive task-dependent functional connectivity (insula with amygdala/fusiform) during out-group disgust perception. It concerns neural mechanisms engaged when processing social stimuli (faces, racial group cues and emotions), thus indexing social processing broadly.
The PPI examines connectivity related to prejudicial disgust perception, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or relationship processes, so it does not satisfy affiliation/attachment criteria.

Connectivity was assessed in the context of viewing facial expressions (disgusted faces) and group membership, directly tied to reception of facial communication and emotion processing, meeting the social communication inclusion criteria.
The connectivity analysis targets processing of others' faces/emotions and prejudice, not self-referential or self-knowledge processes, so it does not meet perception_self criteria.
The PPI identifies neural coupling underlying how participants perceive and evaluate others' emotional states (disgust in out-group faces), mapping onto perception/understanding of others.

This analysis reports negative task-dependent connectivity (insula–ACC) during biased disgust perception of out-group faces. It concerns regulation and processing of social-emotional responses to others’ faces, thereby indexing broad social processing.

The insula–ACC negative connectivity pertains to regulatory processes during prejudice-evoked perception, not to affiliation/attachment tasks or measures of social bonding, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The connectivity is modulated by viewing facial expressions of disgust from in-group vs out-group members, which is a form of reception of facial communication (emotion cues), satisfying social communication criteria.

This analysis focuses on neural regulation of responses to others' emotional faces and implicit prejudice, not on self-referential processing or self-judgments, so it does not meet perception_self criteria.
The negative connectivity reflects processes relevant to perceiving and regulating responses to others' emotional states (disgust) and prejudice, mapping onto perception and understanding of others.

This contrast isolates self-referential > social activity (self > social). Although the experiment includes social stimuli, the contrast tests greater activation for self-related processing rather than measuring social processing per se. Thus it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measures social processing.
The task does not probe affiliation or attachment (no loved-one vs stranger, bonding, cooperation/competition manipulations). The contrast (self > social) does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Although social stimuli (people/faces) are present, this contrast (self > social) is designed to detect self-referential effects and not to measure social communication (e.g., faces > non-faces or emotion recognition).
The contrast explicitly isolates self-referential processing (Self > Social), matching the example Self > Other and thus directly measures perception/understanding of the self (self-judgment).
The contrast is focused on self-related activation (self > social) and therefore does not measure perception/understanding of others as the primary effect.
This contrast isolates social > self activity (social > self). It directly measures social stimulus processing (pictures with humans) and therefore meets the criteria for Social Processing.
The task uses social pictures of humans but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition manipulations).

The social > self contrast involves viewing human stimuli (faces/bodies) and produced activations in face/body and social perception regions (TPJ, FFA, EBA), matching Social Communication (reception of facial/non-facial communication).
This contrast is focused on social (others) > self and therefore does not measure self-perception or self-judgment as the primary effect.

The contrast directly isolates processing of others (social stimuli) and activated regions related to animacy/face/body perception and mentalizing (TPJ, pSTS, FFA), meeting the Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.

Contrast is Pain vs Neutral from an empathy-for-pain paradigm; this measures social processes (perceiving others' pain, empathic responding).
Main effect of pain contrast does not test group membership, affiliation, or attachment (it collapses across ingroup/outgroup), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
Task requires perception and evaluation of another person's affective state (pain) from visual stimuli — receptive social communication (affect recognition).
Contrast indexes perception of others' pain rather than self-related judgments or self>other comparisons; does not meet self-perception criteria.
Pain vs Neutral directly measures representations of others' emotional/pain states (empathy), matching perception/understanding of others.
Main effect of condition (ingroup vs outgroup) comes from the same empathy task with experimentally-induced groups; this probes social processing of group membership and empathic responses.
This contrast explicitly tests ingroup vs outgroup (minimal group paradigm), directly assessing affiliation/attachment-related processes tied to group membership.
Distinguishing ingroup/outgroup involves processing social cues and recognizing others (visual social stimuli); it falls within receptive social communication.
Contrast compares others (ingroup vs outgroup) rather than self-referential judgments; does not meet self-perception inclusion criteria.
Ingroup vs outgroup comparisons involve representing and assessing others' traits/states (social categorization and empathy modulation), fitting perception/understanding of others.
Main effect of gender in this empathy task indexes social-processing differences between male and female participants while perceiving others' pain; thus it is social processing-related.
This contrast tests gender-related differences, not affiliation/attachment or group-bond measures (no loved-one/stranger or cooperation task), so it does not meet affiliation criteria.
Gender effects on responses to observed pain reflect differences in receptive social communication/affect recognition and were derived from viewing social stimuli, so inclusion is appropriate.
Contrast examines between-subject gender differences in response to others, not self-judgments or self>other contrasts; does not meet self-perception criteria.
Gender-related modulation of neural responses to others' pain indexes representations/understanding of others' emotional states and thus meets perception_of_others criteria.
Pain × Condition interaction tests how empathy-related neural responses differ for ingroup vs outgroup when viewing pain vs neutral — a core social processing question.
This interaction directly probes how group membership (ingroup/outgroup) modulates empathy — a manipulation of affiliation/ingroup processes, matching the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
Interaction involves differential perception of others' affect (pain) depending on social category; this is receptive social communication (affect recognition modulated by group cues).
Analysis concerns understanding others' pain across groups rather than self-related processing; no self-judgment or self>other contrast present.
Pain×Condition indexes representations and differential processing of others' emotional/pain states as a function of social group, directly matching perception/understanding of others.
Pain × Gender interaction examines social-processing differences (how empathy for others' pain varies by observer gender) and therefore qualifies as social processing.
This contrast tests gender modulation, not affiliation/attachment or group-bond measures; it does not meet the affiliation inclusion criterion.
The interaction reflects differences in how observers of different genders perceive others' pain — receptive social communication (affect recognition) — and is therefore included.
Analysis focuses on observer gender differences in responses to others, not self-referential processing or self>other contrasts; thus excluded.
Pain×Gender examines how representations of others' pain differ by observer gender, which is within perception/understanding of others.

The ToM > R contrast uses a well-established Theory of Mind paradigm (animated triangles) that directly probes social processing and attribution of mental states. This meets both I1 (social-related task) and I2 (contrast measures social processing).

The task involves attribution of mental states to moving shapes but does not specifically measure affiliation or attachment (no kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Does not meet I1 for this construct.

Social communication constructs target exchanges of socially relevant information (e.g., face/gaze/emotion perception or production). The moving-triangles ToM task measures mental state attribution rather than communicative signal reception/production, so it does not meet I1 for social communication.

Perception_self pertains to self-related processes (self-judgment, viewing self, self > other contrasts). The ToM > R contrast assesses understanding of others, not self-related processing, so it does not meet I1 for this construct.

The contrast directly targets Theory of Mind/understanding others (animacy and mental state attribution to other agents). This matches I1 (ToM task) and I2 (contrast measures perception/understanding of others).

The Bayesian VOI analysis evaluates responses in mPFC versus right posterior STG specifically for the ToM > R contrast, which probes social processing (Theory of Mind). Thus it measures social processing (meets I1 and I2).

This VOI/Bayesian analysis compares regional responses during a ToM contrast but does not assess affiliation or attachment-specific processes (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one contrasts). Does not meet I1 for this construct.
The analysis addresses Theory of Mind neural responses rather than reception/production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, vocalizations), so it does not meet I1 for social communication.
The VOI analysis concerns neural responses to others' interactions (ToM) and does not probe self-referential judgments or self > other contrasts, so it does not meet I1 for perception_self.

The analysis explicitly evaluates neural responses underlying Theory of Mind (understanding others' mental states) across VOIs, meeting I1 (ToM task) and I2 (analysis measures perception/understanding of others).

The study uses a gaze-following task with in-group/out-group political personages and examines neural activity related to social attention, perceived similarity, and ideological attitudes, directly measuring social processing. The main fMRI contrasts (incongruent>congruent) and ROI/regression analyses probe social-cognitive modulation (FEF activity) by social variables (PS, SDO).

The design explicitly manipulates political group membership (in-group vs out-group), measures in-group bias, perceived similarity to political personages, and relates these affiliation measures to behaviour and brain activity, matching affiliation/attachment constructs.

The task centers on gaze following (reception and production of eye-gaze signals) using faces of political figures; contrasts and behavioural measures index gaze-based social communication and its neural correlates, satisfying social communication criteria.

Participants completed self-descriptions (25 adjectives) and similarity (self vs personage) indices that were used as predictors in regression/moderation analyses with FEF activity, indicating the study measures self-perception and links it to neural responses.

The experiment required participants to perceive and evaluate others (political personages' gaze, personality ratings, emotional valence, influence) and used these assessments in analyses of neural responses, directly addressing perception and understanding of others.

The EmpaToM contrasts directly probe social cognition (empathy, compassion, Theory of Mind). This meets inclusion criteria: a social-related task and measurement of social processing.

Although the task elicits compassion, it does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved‑one vs stranger contrasts). Thus it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The paradigm uses spoken autobiographical videos but is designed to assay empathy and mentalizing rather than social-communication processes (e.g., facial/gaze processing, expressive production/reception). It does not meet the examples for Social Communication tasks.

Although participants provide self-ratings (valence, confidence), the contrasts (emotional>neutral video) index responses to others and ToM; the analysis does not target self‑judgment or self>other contrasts required by this annotation.
The contrasts directly measure perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy, compassion) and mental states (ToM), matching the inclusion criteria for this construct.
The ToM vs non‑ToM question contrast probes social cognition (mentalizing), satisfying the social processing inclusion criteria.
This contrast targets Theory of Mind (mentalizing) rather than affiliation/attachment processes; no measures of bonding, cooperation, or attachment are present.
The contrast indexes cognitive mentalizing, not communication-specific reception/production (faces, gaze, prosody); it does not meet the social communication inclusion examples.
The ToM>nonToM contrast reflects inference about others' mental states rather than self‑focused judgments or self>other contrasts, so it does not meet this annotation's inclusion criteria.
Theory of Mind contrasts are a canonical measure of perception and understanding of others' mental states, directly matching this annotation's inclusion criteria.
This Experiment 2 empathy contrast (emotionally negative > neutral videos) measures social-affective processing (empathy/compassion) and thus meets the social processing criteria.

Despite measuring compassion, the contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no relationship or bonding manipulations), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The analysis examines affective responses to stories, not communicative reception/production (faces, gaze, vocal emotion identification) as required by this annotation.
Although participants rate their own affect, the contrast indexes responses evoked by others' videos (other‑focused) rather than self‑referential processing or explicit self>other contrasts.
The contrast assesses empathy and compassion—understanding others' emotional states—directly fitting the perception_of_others construct (includes Empathy/ToM examples).
This ToM > nonToM questions contrast in Experiment 2 indexes social cognition (mentalizing), satisfying the social processing inclusion criteria.
The contrast measures Theory of Mind and does not probe attachment/affiliation constructs (no cooperation/relationship manipulations), so it does not meet affiliation criteria.
The contrast taps cognitive inference about others rather than social-communication processes like facial/gaze/prosodic reception or production.
Although confidence ratings are collected elsewhere, this contrast specifically targets inference about others' mental states, not self‑judgment or self>other contrasts required here.
The ToM contrast is a direct measure of understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind), matching the perception_of_others inclusion criteria.
The differential contrast (emotional>neutral video) > (ToM>nonToM questions) contrasts social‑affective vs social‑cognitive processing—clearly within social processing.
This differential contrast isolates empathy vs ToM networks; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship/bonding manipulations.
The contrast differentiates affective vs cognitive social processing rather than communication-specific reception/production measures; it does not meet social communication examples.
The contrast contrasts two other‑focused processes (empathy vs ToM) and does not target self‑referential judgment or self>other contrasts required for this annotation.
This contrast explicitly differentiates networks for perceiving others' affective states (empathy) versus cognitive states (ToM), directly addressing perception and understanding of others.
The reverse differential contrast (ToM>Empathy) isolates social cognitive processing (mentalizing) versus social affect, and therefore meets social processing criteria.
This contrast targets mentalizing networks rather than attachment/affiliation constructs; there are no bonding/cooperation manipulations in the task.
The contrast focuses on cognitive inference about others (ToM), not on communication-specific reception/production (faces, gaze, vocal cues), so it does not meet social communication criteria.
The contrast indexes understanding others' mental states rather than self‑focused judgments or explicit self>other contrasts, so it does not satisfy perception_self inclusion criteria.
The contrast measures Theory of Mind—understanding others' mental states—directly matching the perception_of_others construct.

The contrast 'Positive vs. Neutral' uses a social-reputation task (faces + evaluative comments) requiring subjects to imagine receiving social feedback and rate pleasantness. This is a social task that directly measures social processing (per Study Methods and behavioral aims).

The task measures responses to social reputation/evaluative comments but does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). The contrast does not target affiliation/attachment per the inclusion examples.
Stimuli combine faces and verbal comments and require reception of socially relevant facial/linguistic communication; this fits Social Communication (reception of facial and verbal social signals).

Subjects imagine being directly addressed by comments and rate their own pleasantness, a self-referential judgment about internal state in response to social feedback, meeting Perception/Self criteria.
Although the primary rating concerns the self, the task requires processing comments uttered by others (inferring others' evaluations/traits), which involves Perception and Understanding of Others.
The 'Negative vs. Neutral' contrast uses the same social-reputation task (faces + negative evaluative comments) and therefore measures social processing.
The contrast focuses on processing negative evaluative comments vs neutral instructions but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
Participants view faces paired with verbal negative comments (reception of facial/verbal social cues), which fits Social Communication.
Subjects imagine being told negative comments about themselves and rate pleasantness, engaging self-referential evaluation (Perception/Self).
Processing negative comments involves representing others' evaluations/opinions about the participant, engaging Perception/Understanding of Others.
The conjunction mask [(Positive > Neutral) ∩ (Negative > Neutral)] examines areas commonly responsive to social evaluative feedback; this is clearly social processing.
Although the conjunction identifies regions responding to social feedback generally, it does not target affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding or relationship comparisons).
The conjunction isolates regions responding to reception of face+comment stimuli (facial and verbal social communication), matching Social Communication criteria.
Common activity for positive and negative social feedback reflects self-referential responses to being evaluated by others, satisfying Perception/Self inclusion.
Regions commonly engaged by positive and negative feedback reflect processing of others' evaluative input about the participant, implicating Perception/Understanding of Others.
The contrast '(Positive vs. Neutral) vs. (Negative vs. Neutral)' isolates neural responses specific to positive social reputation; this is a social-processing contrast by design.
This contrast identifies positivity-specific responses to social feedback but does not assess affiliation/attachment per se (no bonding or relationship-level measures).
Isolating regions responsive to positive evaluative face+comment stimuli involves reception of social communication (faces and verbal praise), fitting Social Communication.
The contrast probes brain regions encoding subjective pleasantness of positive social feedback to the self (self-evaluation), meeting Perception/Self criteria.
Although focused on positive feedback, this contrast still represents processing of others' evaluations directed at the subject and thus involves Perception/Understanding of Others.
The contrast '(Negative vs. Neutral) vs. (Positive vs. Neutral)' targets negative-specific responses to social evaluative feedback; it is a social-processing contrast.
Although isolating negative-specific responses, the analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship comparisons).
Negative evaluative face+comment stimuli require reception of social communication (facial and verbal cues); thus Social Communication is relevant.
Participants' responses to negative evaluations about themselves engage self-referential processing (Perception/Self).
This contrast still reflects processing of others' negative evaluations directed at the participant, involving Perception/Understanding of Others.

The contrast Eye Contact > Averted Gaze examines perceiving social gaze relations between two people (observed eye contact), which is a social task and measures social processing of attentional relations and face/gaze cues.

The task manipulates observed eye contact and averted gaze but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., no measures of bonding, cooperation, kinship, loved one vs stranger). Does not meet inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.
Eye contact and gaze are canonical social-communication signals; this contrast directly addresses processing of gaze/face cues and thus measures social communication (receptive aspects).
The contrast concerns perception of others' gaze relations, not self-referential processing or judgments about the self; it does not meet inclusion criteria for perception/self.
The contrast probes representations of others' attentional states (eye contact vs averted gaze) and thus measures perception/understanding of others (action/animacy perception, social attention).
Averted Gaze > Eye Contact examines social perceptual processing of gaze patterns between agents; it is a social task measuring social processing.
Although averted gaze may carry social meaning, the contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation measures), so inclusion criteria are not met.
The contrast involves processing of face/gaze cues (communication signals) and therefore indexes social communication processes.
This contrast does not involve self-referential judgments or self-related tasks; it does not meet perception_self inclusion criteria.
Averted gaze processing concerns understanding others' attentional states and social intent, meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.
Congruent > Incongruent contrasts examine gaze-following and social attention, a social processing task measuring how social cues guide attention.
Gaze congruency contrasts index attentional orienting, not affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding or relationship), so it's not an affiliation task.
Gaze following and congruency are core social-communication phenomena (production/reception of gaze signals); the contrast directly measures social communication.
The contrast compares responses to external gaze cues (others' gazes) and does not probe self-perception or self-related judgments.
Congruent vs incongruent gaze cues test perception of others' attentional direction and social intent, satisfying perception_others inclusion criteria.
Incongruent > Congruent targets elicit increased attentional shifting in response to others' gaze — a social processing effect related to gaze following.
This contrast reflects attentional/cognitive demands of conflicting gaze information, not measures of affiliation or attachment.
Contrasting incongruent vs congruent gaze cues addresses processing of communicative gaze signals and thus falls under social communication.
No self-referential judgments or self-processing are involved in this contrast.
This contrast indexes perceiving and responding to others' gaze (action perception/attentional states), meeting perception_others criteria.
EC congruent > AG congruent tests how observed eye contact between others modulates processing of shared gaze to a target — clearly a social processing contrast.
Although eye contact might imply social connection, this contrast does not directly measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no scales or bonding manipulation).
This interaction contrast assesses communicative value of eye contact and subsequent gaze (receptive/social-communicative processing), meeting social_communication criteria.
The contrast concerns observers' processing of others' interaction and not self-related cognition.
Comparing congruent gaze processing following observed eye contact versus averted gaze probes understanding of others' attentional relations and intentions, meeting perception_others criteria.
Averted Gaze incongruent > Averted Gaze congruent contrasts gaze congruency within the no-attentional-relation condition, addressing social attention/gaze-following processing.
This is a perceptual/attentional contrast about gaze congruency, not an affiliation/attachment task or measure.
Contrasting incongruent vs congruent gaze when faces looked away still examines communicative gaze cues and social attention, satisfying social_communication inclusion criteria.
No self-related processing or self-judgment tasks are involved here; does not meet perception_self criteria.
This contrast indexes perceiving others' gaze directions and the need to reallocate attention—core to perception/understanding of others' attentional states.

Contrast Incongruent > Congruent indexes regulation of automatic imitation (mimicry) in a task that includes facial stimuli and social-affective context; it directly measures social processing (perceiving and responding to social cues, action observation, and social interaction processes).

The study and this contrast investigate mimicry as an affiliative signal and its regulation (reciprocation/appeasement). The Incongruent>Congruent contrast captures processes tied to affiliation-related modulation of imitation.

The task presents faces and hand movements (receptive and production aspects of social communication) and this contrast isolates neural control of imitative tendencies during social stimulus presentation.

Incongruent>Congruent taps processes of self–other distinction/agency (supported by rTPJ activation reported), thus indexing perception/understanding of self-related representations in the context of action control.
Contrast involves representing and responding to others' actions (observed hand movements) and social cues (faces), directly engaging perception/understanding of others.
This contrast isolates mimicry regulation specifically when happy faces are shown, a clear social-affective manipulation measuring social processing.
Happy expressions are affiliative signals; the contrast was designed to capture mimicry modulation related to reciprocation of affiliation, directly mapping onto affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast involves processing facial expressions (receptive facial communication) while measuring imitative responding (production-related aspects); fits social communication criteria.

Authors report rTPJ activation for the happy condition and interpret this as increased self–other distinction; thus this contrast engages self-related/perception-of-self processes (agency/self-other distinction).
Processing of others' happy facial expressions and their influence on behavior is central to this contrast, engaging perception and understanding of others' emotional states.
This contrast isolates mimicry regulation when angry faces are shown; it is a social-affective manipulation and therefore measures social processing.

Angry expressions index non-affiliative/dominance signals; the contrast probes how affiliation-related mimicry is modulated by anger and thus is relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs addressed by the study.
Contrast involves viewing facial emotional expressions (reception) and their impact on imitative behavior (production aspects), meeting social communication criteria.

The angry-specific contrast produced minimal activation (left inferior occipital) and the authors do not interpret engagement of self-related or agency processes for this condition; it does not directly index self-perception or self-judgment.
Contrast indexes processing of others' angry expressions and their effect on imitative responding, reflecting perception/understanding of others' emotional states and actions.
This contrast targets mimicry regulation specifically for out-group faces (social group membership), directly probing social processing of intergroup cues and behavior.

Authors interpret the out-group effect as increased mimicry reflecting affiliative/appeasement goals toward an implicitly threatening out-group; the contrast therefore measures affiliation-related regulation.
Contrast involves processing face-based group cues (receptive facial communication) and imitative behavior (production), consistent with social communication processes.

The out-group-specific activations (AI, MCC, vPMC/IPL) are interpreted as salience and regulation/appeasement processes focused on others and affective salience rather than explicit self-referential or agency processes; authors do not emphasize self-perception here.
Contrast directly assesses processing of others' group membership and the impact on action (mimicry), engaging representation and understanding of others' social identity and emotional salience.
This contrast isolates mimicry regulation for in-group faces and thus probes social processing tied to group membership and affiliative behavior.
In-group versus out-group contrasts directly relate to affiliation and bonding processes; this analysis measures affiliation/attachment-related neural differences in mimicry regulation.
Contrast involves viewing in-group faces and effects on imitative responding (face reception and action production), consistent with social communication constructs.

The in-group-specific activation was minimal (cerebellar vermis) and the contrast is not interpreted as indexing explicit self-referential or agency processes; it does not meet typical self-perception inclusion criteria.
This contrast concerns processing of others (in-group members) and how their presence modulates mimicry, engaging perception/understanding of others' social cues.

The why>how contrast across all stimulus categories includes social stimuli (emotional expressions and intentional actions) and targets attributional processing about others’ mental states; thus it measures social processing. ROI and whole-brain conjunction results explicitly report social-attribution activations (DMPFC, TPJ, aSTS, LOFC).

The task probes attributional reasoning about emotions and actions and nonsocial causal events, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition, or loved vs stranger contrasts).

The social conditions involve viewing faces and intentional actions and asking about emotional/behavioral states (receptive facial/emotional recognition, action understanding), meeting examples for social communication tasks (faces > non-faces, emotion recognition).
Analyses focus on perceiving and reasoning about others (attribution of mental states) rather than self-related processing or self-judgments; no self vs other contrasts were used.

The why>how contrasts explicitly probe understanding others’ mental states (theory-of-mind/attributional judgments). The study uses emotion and action stimuli and reports DMPFC/TPJ involvement tied to mental-state inference, directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

This contrast tests stronger why>how responses for social versus nonsocial stimuli, directly indexing social-attribution processing and selective recruitment for social domain (DMPFC social-selective effects).
Contrast tests social vs nonsocial attributional processing but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no loved-one, kinship, cooperation/competition comparisons).

The social > nonsocial why>how effect isolates processing of facial emotional expressions and intentional actions and mental-state inferences (receptive social communication), consistent with social communication inclusion criteria.
The contrast targets others’ mental states and social attribution, not self-referential processing or self>other judgments; thus it does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

The analysis specifically identifies regions more engaged when making mental-state attributions about others (emotional expressions and actions) versus nonsocial scenes, directly indexing perception and understanding of others (ToM).

The contrast (simple + sophisticated deception vs. truth) assesses intentional deceptive behavior in a strategic, interpersonal game—clearly a social processing task involving understanding and responding to social information.
The sender-receiver game manipulates aligned vs. conflicting interests (cooperation/competition) between players, which falls under affiliation/attachment-related social scenarios.
The task centers on sending messages and influencing a receiver (exchange of socially relevant information), so it measures social communication processes.

The contrasts target interpersonal intention and theory-of-mind processes rather than explicit self-related judgments or self-referential processing; no self-judgment or self-other contrast is reported.

The contrast is designed to index the sender's anticipation of the receiver's beliefs and intentions (theory-of-mind/understanding others), meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.
Simple deception vs. truth investigates deliberate interpersonal deception in a game context, a social processing task.
Simple deception contrasts arise from conflicting vs. aligned payoffs (competition/cooperation aspects) relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Simple deception involves producing a false message to influence another—directly a form of social communication.
The analysis focuses on deception toward others and conflict monitoring; it does not probe self-referential evaluation or self vs other contrasts.
Simple deception requires inferring/predicting receiver behavior and beliefs (ToM), satisfying perception-of-others inclusion criteria.
Sophisticated deception vs. truth examines strategic interpersonal behavior (telling truth with intent to deceive), a social processing task.
Sophisticated deception usage depends on payoff structure and strategic interaction (cooperative vs. conflicting interests), relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
Sophisticated deception entails communicative acts (sending truthful message with deceptive intent), falling squarely under social communication.
This contrast emphasizes mentalizing about others and strategic messaging rather than explicit self-focused judgments or self-referential tasks.
Sophisticated deception explicitly requires modeling the receiver's beliefs/expectations (theory-of-mind), meeting inclusion criteria for perception of others.
The contrast sophisticated vs. simple deception compares two interpersonal, strategic behaviors—both social processing phenomena.
Differentiating sophisticated and simple deception depends on strategic motives and payoff-based social interactions (competition/cooperation aspects), relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Both conditions involve different communicative strategies (truthful vs. false messaging with different intents), so this contrast probes social communication mechanisms.
The contrast is about comparing types of interpersonal deception and increased ToM demands, not self-referential processing.
This contrast directly targets differences in mentalizing demands (inferring others' beliefs), fulfilling perception-of-others criteria.
Truth vs. deception contrasts genuine belief-to-belief interactions, assessing social decision-making and intention in interpersonal exchanges—central to social processing.
The contrast implicates strategic considerations shaped by payoff alignment/conflict (cooperation vs. competition), relevant to affiliation/attachment processes.
Truthful vs. deceptive messaging directly tests communicative behavior and its social consequences; it measures social communication.
Although some self-reports were collected post-session, the neuroimaging contrasts reported focus on interactions and mentalizing, not explicit self-judgment contrasts.
Contrast captures senders' expectations about receivers' choices and belief states (ToM), matching perception-of-others inclusion criteria.
The parametric analysis models incentive to deceive in an interpersonal game—this is a social processing manipulation of social incentives.
The parametric modulation uses payoff conflict (cooperation/competition) between sender and receiver, which pertains to affiliation/attachment-related social dynamics.
Modeling how incentives modulate deceptive messaging addresses communicative behavior under varying social stakes, fitting social communication.
The parametric contrast indexes conflict and incentive effects on deception-related networks, not self-referential processing or self vs other judgments.
The modulation reflects how inferring and influencing others' decisions varies with payoff conflict, implicating understanding others (ToM) and satisfying perception-of-others criteria.

The contrast (Fear > Happy+Neutral) examines perception of emotional crowds and group dynamics, which is a social task assessing social processing across emotions.

The contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, bonding, cooperation) or compare loved vs stranger; it focuses on emotion perception in crowds rather than attachment constructs.
The task involves receptive social communication (perception of non-facial bodily expressions and group emotional signals), matching the Social Communication construct.
The contrast does not probe self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge; it compares perception of others' emotions rather than self vs other.
This contrast directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (fear vs other emotions) in crowds, fitting Perception of Others.
Fear+Happy > Neutral examines processing of emotionally expressive crowds versus neutral, a social perceptual task assessing social processing.
The contrast contrasts emotional (fearful/happy) vs neutral crowds but does not index affiliation/attachment or bonding/cooperative constructs.
Contrasts emotional group displays (body motion, affect) vs neutral involve reception of socially relevant non-facial communication.
No self-related task or self>other comparison; focuses on perception of others' emotions.
This contrast assesses observers' perception/understanding of others' emotional states in groups, meeting Perception of Others criteria.
Fear+Neutral > Happy contrasts social-emotional responses across conditions and is a social processing analysis of group emotion perception.
This contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation manipulation).
Comparing emotional (fear/neutral) to happy group displays involves reception of social, non-facial communicative cues (body expressions, dynamics).
No measures of self-awareness, agency, or self-judgment are present in this contrast.
This contrast probes perception and differentiation of others' emotional states (fear/neutral vs happy) in groups, consistent with Perception of Others.
Happy > Fear+Neutral examines social perception of positive crowd emotion versus others, a social processing task.
Although positive emotion could relate to affiliation, the study does not assess attachment or bonding measures (no cooperation/kinship contrasts).
Happy crowd displays convey socially communicative non-facial signals (body movement, group affect), matching Social Communication (receptive non-facial).
No self-related judgments or tasks are included in this contrast; it concerns perception of others' emotions.
This contrast assesses observers' perception and discrimination of others' emotional states in crowds (happy vs others), fitting Perception of Others.
Neutral > Fear+Happy contrasts responses to neutral crowds versus emotional ones; still a social task involving group perception.
This contrast does not index affiliation/attachment processes or measure bonding/cooperation between individuals.
Even neutral crowd displays engage perception of social scenes and non-facial communication (context, implied actions), so Social Communication applies.
Contrast does not involve self-related processing or self>other comparisons; it focuses on others' group behavior.
This contrast examines how observers perceive others (neutral vs emotional crowds), consistent with Perception of Others.
Main effect of dynamics (interactive > individual) directly probes sensitivity to social interactions and group dynamics — a core social processing measure.
Although interactive stimuli involve social interaction, the contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment (no bonding/cooperation/relationship assessment).
Interactive vs individual behavior conveys communicative, non-facial social signals (interaction dynamics), fitting Social Communication (receptive non-facial).
The contrast assesses perception of others' interactions rather than self-related processing or agency judgments.
This contrast measures how participants perceive and interpret others' interactive behaviors (action perception/animacy), matching Perception of Others.
Interactive fear > individual fear assesses processing of socially salient panic-like interactions — clearly social processing.
This contrast isolates interaction dynamics under fear but does not evaluate affiliation/attachment or relationship constructs.
The contrast focuses on reception of non-facial communicative cues (interactive fearful body language), satisfying Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Although discussion mentions self-preparation, the contrast itself compares others' interactions and does not directly probe self-awareness or agency.
This contrast evaluates observers' perception and understanding of others' fearful interactive behavior (animacy/action perception), fitting Perception of Others.
The compound contrast (interactive fear>individual fear + interactive happy>individual happy) targets social interaction effects across emotions — a social processing measure.
Although it probes interactive behavior in different emotions, it does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no bonding/cooperation metrics).
Comparing interactive vs individual across emotions assesses reception of social communicative cues (body motion/dynamics) — fits Social Communication.
The contrast examines perception of others' interactions rather than any explicit self-related processing or judgments.
This contrast measures how observers perceive and differentiate others' interactive behaviors across emotional contexts, meeting Perception of Others criteria.
Interactive fear>individual fear + interactive neutral>individual neutral examines social interaction effects specifically for fear and neutral conditions — a social processing analysis.
The contrast targets interaction dynamics but does not assess affiliation, attachment, or bonding measures between individuals.
By contrasting interactive vs individual in fear and neutral, the analysis probes reception of communicative, non-facial cues and action perception — Social Communication applies.
No direct measures of self-related awareness or self>other comparisons are included in this contrast.
This contrast evaluates perception and understanding of others' interactive behavior under fear/neutral contexts, consistent with Perception of Others.
Interactive fear>individual fear + individual neutral>interactive neutral tests interaction-by-emotion effects — a social processing contrast focused on group behavior and emotion.
Although contrasts involve interactions, they do not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures).
This compound contrast examines how communicative interactive signals (body/dynamics) vary with emotion, fitting Social Communication reception criteria.
The analysis contrasts others' interactions and neutral conditions; it does not probe self-related cognition or agency.
The contrast concerns observers' perception/interpretation of others' interactions under different emotional contexts, aligning with Perception of Others.
Interactive neutral > individual neutral compares social interaction effects even in neutral crowds, a social processing measure of group dynamics.
The contrast evaluates interaction dynamics among actors but does not measure affiliation/attachment, bonding, or relationship constructs.
Even neutral interactive behavior conveys social communicative cues (movement/dynamics); this contrast targets receptive non-facial social communication.
No self-related processing or self>other comparison is present; focus remains on perception of others' interactions.
This contrast assesses perception and understanding of others' interactive behaviors in neutral contexts, matching Perception of Others.
