The localizer and ROI table are part of a study on person perception and were used to identify face- and body-selective regions for subsequent social-dyad analyses; this is directly related to social processing.

This analysis reports peak coordinates from a localizer (faces, bodies, cars) and does not test affiliation/attachment or scenarios of social bonding/cooperation as required by the affiliation/attachment construct.
The localizer explicitly used faces and bodies (faces > cars, bodies > cars) to define face/body selective ROIs, matching the Social Communication construct (reception of facial/body communication).
The localizer and reported coordinates do not measure self-related processing or self-judgments; they index perceptual regions for others, not self.
The ROIs were defined using faces and bodies to index regions involved in perceiving others' faces and bodies (animacy/action perception), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast compares congruent (meaningful) social interactions to incongruent dyads; it directly tests social scene processing and how social relations modulate perception.

Congruent interactions index meaningful social relations (agents in related/interactive roles); the contrast tests neural sensitivity to meaningful (affiliation-like) social interactions versus incongruent pairings, relevant to affiliation/attachment processing.

The contrast involves viewing dyads with mutual facing, related body posture and facial cues vs incongruent pairings; this taps reception of facial/body communicative signals and thus Social Communication.
The contrast concerns perception of others and social relations; participants made sex judgments on images, but no self-referential or self-judgment processes were measured.

This contrast probes how representations of others (faces/bodies and their relational context) differ by interaction meaningfulness, a direct test of perception/understanding of others (animacy/action and social relation perception).
This contrast (incongruent > congruent) examines social-scene incongruency effects on person perception, a social processing phenomenon.
The contrast emphasizes incongruency (ambiguity) rather than the presence of affiliative/attachment signals; it does not specifically measure affiliation or bonding processes.

Incongruent vs congruent interactions modulate face/body processing and communicative cues; the contrast assesses reception of facial/body signals in differing social contexts, fitting Social Communication.
No self-referential or self-judgment processes are probed by this contrast; it addresses perception of other agents and their relations.
The contrast probes how perception/representation of other people (their bodies/faces and implied actions/relations) changes under incongruency, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast compares congruent interactions (meaningful social scenes) to non-interactions; this directly tests social scene processing and its effect on person perception.

Congruent interactions represent meaningful social exchanges (affiliation-related cues) and are contrasted with non-interactions; this contrast probes sensitivity to affiliative/relational content in scenes.

Comparing congruent interactions to non-interactions involves differences in mutual facing, body posture, and communicative facial cues, and therefore assesses reception of social communication signals.
The contrast targets perception of other agents and their relations; it does not involve self-related judgments or self-awareness measures.

This contrast tests how perceivers represent others when they engage in meaningful interactions versus when they do not, directly relevant to perception and understanding of others (action/animacy cues).
Non-interactions > congruent interactions still concerns social scenes and how their relational properties modulate neural responses; thus it falls under social processing.

This contrast emphasizes non-interactions producing greater activity than congruent (meaningful) interactions; it does not test affiliative/bonding processes specifically and therefore does not meet criteria for affiliation/attachment.
Non-interactions differ from congruent interactions in communicative cues (lack of mutual gaze, facing), so this contrast probes reception of social communicative signals (or their absence).
No self-referential measures are present; the contrast pertains to perception of other agents and their relational configurations.
The contrast compares different relational contexts of others (non-interacting vs interacting), probing action/animacy and relational understanding of other agents.
Incongruent interactions > non-interactions compares different types of social scenes and how social relations affect perception, fulfilling social processing inclusion.
Both incongruent and non-interaction conditions are low on clear affiliative signals; this contrast focuses on incongruency and ambiguity rather than measuring affiliation/attachment explicitly.

This contrast contrasts two scene types that differ in communicative and relational cues (incongruent pairings vs non-facing non-interactions), thus tapping the reception of facial/body communicative signals.
No measures of self-perception or self-referential processing are involved in this contrast.
The contrast probes how perceivers represent other people under differing relational contexts and ambiguity, aligning with perception/action/mental-state understanding of others.
Non-interactions > incongruent interactions compares social scene types and neural sensitivity to differing relational properties, so it pertains to social processing.
This contrast pits non-interactions against incongruent interactions and does not specifically probe affiliation/bonding processes; it therefore does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion.

Non-interactions vs incongruent interactions differ in communicative cues (mutual facing, related body posture), so the contrast assesses reception of communicative facial/body signals and their contextual integration.
No self-related processing or self-judgment contrasts are present; the analysis concerns perception of other agents and their relations.
This contrast examines how perceivers interpret others' actions/relations across different scene types, directly relevant to perception and understanding of others (action/animacy/relations).

Task explicitly probes social processing: participants judged whether they felt addressed by videos manipulating co-speech gestures and actor orientation. The IC>NG contrast measures neural responses to a social cue (gesture) within that social judgment task.
The study and the IC>NG contrast probe social addressment and communication, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, or relationship closeness).
Contrast compares presence vs absence of co-speech gestures, directly indexing social communicative signals (receptive non-facial communication) used in an explicit communication judgment task.

Participants made explicit self-referential judgments (“Do you feel addressed?”) on every trial; although the contrast is gesture-based, it arises from a self-evaluation task and thus engages perception/understanding of self.
The contrast reflects processing of others' communicative behavior (gestures) and inferring communicative intent, engaging perception/understanding of others (mentalizing/action perception).
The ego>allo contrast probes social self-involvement and addressment (actor orientation) during an explicit social judgment; it measures social processing related to engagement and self-involvement.
Egocentric vs allocentric orientation manipulates addressment and perspective, not affiliation/attachment or bonding between individuals; no measures of attachment are present.
Actor orientation modulates communicative intent and signaling (who is addressed). This is directly relevant to social communication (reception of non-facial communicative cues).
Egocentricity manipulation explicitly targets self-related processing (feeling addressed, self-involvement); thus it indexes perception/understanding of self (agency/self-relevance).
Egocentric vs allocentric presentation requires inferring the actor's communicative intent toward others versus self, engaging perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).

The allo>ego contrast examines processing when the actor is allocentric (less addressing) within an explicit social task, thus indexing social processing related to communicative context and interpretation.
Allocentric vs egocentric orientation does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation metrics).
Allocentric presentation changes communicative signalling and how messages are received, directly relevant to social communication and reception of non-facial cues and speech-gesture integration.
Although allocentric trials reduce feelings of addressment, participants still make self-referential judgments on each trial; the contrast therefore relates to self-perception of being addressed.
Allocentric presentation implicates reasoning about the actor directing communication toward others (understanding others’ perspective/intent), engaging perception of others and mentalizing.
This interaction ((IC-ego>IC-allo)>(NG-ego>NG-allo)) directly targets how gesture and body orientation jointly influence the feeling of being addressed—clearly a social processing measure.
The interaction probes communicative addressment and mentalizing rather than affiliation/attachment or bonding; no measures of attachment are used.

The contrast tests how communicative cues (gesture) interact with orientation to affect perceived addressment—directly indexing social communication processes (reception of non-facial cues and communicative intent).

The interaction isolates conditions that most strongly change subjects' self-referential feeling of being addressed (IC-ego produced highest addressment); thus it measures perception/understanding of self-relevance in communication.
Detecting how gestures and orientation modulate perceived addressment requires inferring the actor's communicative intent and others’ perspective, engaging mentalizing/action perception.
This interaction ((IC-allo>NG-allo)>(IC-ego>NG-ego)) evaluates how gesture effects differ by actor orientation within the social addressment judgment task—clearly social processing.
The contrast addresses modulation of communicative cue processing by orientation, not affiliation/attachment; no bonding or relationship measures are present.
This interaction directly tests the role of co-speech gestures (production/reception of non-facial communicative behavior) across orientations—central to social communication.
The analysis examines how gestures change perceived addressment in ego vs allo contexts; it is tied to participants' self-referential judgments and thus perception of self-relevance.
Understanding how gesture effects depend on orientation requires modeling the actor's communicative intentions toward others versus self—engaging perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).

The RJA vs RJAc contrast isolates social joint attention (responding to another's gaze) using a social interactive task; it directly measures social processing. Matches I1 (social task) and I2 (measures social processing).
The task is cooperative (‘Catch the Burglar’) with an avatar partner; RJA trials require cooperating/responding to partner—fits affiliation/attachment (cooperation) measures.
Contrast involves gaze following, eye contact and communicative exchange (responding to a partner's gaze), core social-communication processes (production/reception of facial/gaze cues).

RJA trials require monitoring one’s own attention and shifts in agency (self-related attentional perspective), and authors discuss self-representation processes; thus the contrast taps perception/understanding of self.
Responding to another's guiding gaze requires representing the partner's attentional state/intentions (theory-of-mind/other perception); contrast measures perception of others.
The IJA vs IJAc contrast isolates initiating joint attention in an interactive social task (guiding another's attention), directly measuring social processing. Matches I1 and I2.
IJA trials occur in a cooperative game requiring guiding the partner to a shared goal, indexing cooperative/affiliative interaction (affiliation/attachment).
IJA entails production of communicative gaze cues (initiating, guiding) and evaluating partner responses—core social communication processes (gaze production/reception).

Initiating joint attention requires representing one’s own attentional state/agency and planning guiding actions; authors highlight self-representation demands, so contrast measures perception/self processes.
IJA requires representing the partner's readiness to be guided and their attentional state (mental state representation), so it measures perception/understanding of others.
The conjunction identifies regions common to both initiating and responding joint attention in an interactive social paradigm—clearly measures social processing. Matches I1 and I2.
The conjunction reflects brain regions recruited during cooperative interaction (both partners’ coordinating attention) and thus indexes affiliative/cooperative processes.
Common activation across IJA and RJA reflects shared mechanisms for gaze-based communication (production/reception of gaze cues), fitting social communication.
Authors interpret the conjunction as supporting parallel self- and other-attention representations; thus the conjunction taps self-perception/agency processes.
The conjunction highlights regions involved in representing another's attention (TPJ, pSTS, etc.), directly indexing perception/understanding of others.

The IJA>RJA contrast (after controlling for non-social controls) isolates social-role-dependent increases in joint attention processing (initiating>responding), so it measures social processing. Matches I1 and I2.
This contrast captures additional recruitment during cooperative initiating behaviour (greater demands in guiding partner within cooperative task), relevant to affiliation/cooperation.
IJA>RJA reflects greater engagement of communicative gaze-production and evaluation systems when initiating versus responding—within social communication domain.
Regions more active for IJA relate to self-monitoring/agency and planning of goal-directed guiding actions (SMA, MFG), indicating self-perception processes are measured.
IJA>RJA also showed greater activity in TPJ and precuneus—regions implicated in representing others’ attention—so the contrast measures perception of others as well.

Contrast friend minus PC directly probes social context and engages the mentalizing network; it measures social processing (dmPFC, TPJ, precuneus activations).
Contrast compares messages believed to come from a real-life friend versus a computer (analogous to loved one vs non-human), and the study further relates effects to measures of friendship intensity.
Task involves receiving and evaluating text messages (socially relevant communicative signals); univariate contrast tests sender-dependent processing of communicative input.
Contrast does not involve judgments about the self, self-knowledge, or agency; it contrasts sender identity (friend vs computer).
Engages perception/understanding of others (mentalizing network) as participants infer/attend to the social sender and process messages about others' affect.
MVPA (happy vs sad) is embedded in a social-communication experiment and examines encoding of socially-relevant affective message content, so it falls under social processing.
This contrast tests sensory/content discrimination of words (happy vs sad) independent of sender and does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no loved-vs-stranger contrast).
Classification of message content (affective words) is a receptive form of social communication (non-facial, text-based); MVPA assesses representation of communicative content.
Analysis does not involve self-related judgments or self-representation.

The MVPA identifies low-level content encoding (visual word/affect discrimination) that is largely sensory and sender-invariant; it does not directly index higher-order perception/understanding of others (e.g., theory-of-mind).
MVCA explicitly tests sender-dependent gating of sensory information into social-cognitive regions (dmPFC) and therefore indexes social processing.
Contrast compares friend versus computer coupling and the effect is further related to measures of friendship/closeness, meeting the affiliation/attachment criterion (friend vs non-human).

MVCA examines how communicative content (text messages) is transmitted from sensory regions to a social-cognitive hub (dmPFC) depending on perceived sender—directly about social communication processing.
Analysis focuses on how sensory information about messages is relayed to regions involved in processing others' mental states, not on self-related processing.

Findings implicate dmPFC and other mentalizing regions and show sender-dependent changes in how information about others' affect is represented—this indexes perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).

Task involves explicit labeling of briefly presented emotional facial expressions — a prototypical social-processing task requiring perception and interpretation of others' emotions. The contrast (happy>neutral) measures social processing of facial emotion.
Task does not assess affiliation, attachment, close relationships, or bonding; it is an emotion-labeling perceptual task rather than affiliation/attachment measurement.
The contrast presents faces and requires affect recognition (receptive facial communication), fitting the Social Communication construct (Reception of Facial Communication).
Task does not involve self-related judgments, viewing of one's own face, or self-referential processing; it targets perception of others' emotions.
The contrast measures representations and judgments about others' emotional states (labeling others' facial emotions), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Angry>neutral contrast is a social task requiring perception and interpretation of another person's emotional expression; it measures social processing.
No measures or contrasts related to affiliation, attachment, or close relationships; this is an emotion recognition task.
Task involves receptive facial communication (recognizing/labeling angry faces) and thus meets Social Communication criteria.
Contrast does not involve self-related processing or judgments about the self.
Angry>neutral examines perception and understanding of others' emotional states (anger), satisfying Perception and Understanding of Others.
Fearful>neutral contrast requires perceiving, interpreting, and labeling another person's emotional expression; it is a social-processing measure.
No affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger) are present; this is an emotion labeling task.
The task assesses reception of facial communication (recognition/labeling of fearful expressions), matching Social Communication inclusion criteria.
No self-referential or self-judgment component; participants label others' faces rather than self-related stimuli.
Fearful>neutral measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states, aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.

This analysis examines correlations between neural responses to happy>neutral and alexithymia during an emotion-labeling task — a social-processing investigation of individual differences in social cognition.
The analysis does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs; it examines emotion recognition and individual differences (alexithymia).
Contrasting emotional faces and relating activation to alexithymia indexes reception and interpretation of facial communication, so it fits Social Communication.
No self-related task or contrast (self>other) is involved; analysis focuses on perceiving others' emotions.
Relates brain responses to perceiving others' emotional states (happy faces) with alexithymia, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis studies neural correlates of perceiving angry>neutral faces as a function of alexithymia — directly addressing social processing mechanisms for others' emotions.
No measures of affiliation/attachment or bonding; the focus is on emotion recognition and trait correlations.
Analysis concerns reception of facial communication (anger recognition) and its relation to alexithymia, fitting the Social Communication construct.
The contrast and regressions do not involve self-referential judgments or self-perception.
Examines representations and neural responses tied to understanding others' negative emotional states (anger) as a function of alexithymia, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis relates fearful>neutral brain responses to alexithymia during an emotion labeling task — a social-processing assessment of perceiving others' emotions.
No affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts are assessed; the focus is on emotion recognition and trait associations.
Fearful face perception and its neural correlates (and relation to alexithymia) target receptive facial communication, meeting Social Communication criteria.
No self-related processing is being measured; participants label others' emotions rather than making self-judgments.
This analysis probes understanding of others' emotional states (fear) and how this is represented neurally in relation to alexithymia, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF correlations with happy>neutral reflect individual differences in social perception and labeling of facial emotion, thus a social-processing measure.
The analysis does not measure affiliation, attachment, or relationship-bonding constructs.
Correlating brain responses to faces with TAS-20-DDF concerns reception of facial communication and its neural basis, fitting Social Communication.
No self-related judgments or contrasts are present; task focuses on perceiving others' emotions.
Examines perception and neural representation of others' emotional expressions (happy) in relation to an alexithymia subscale, consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF correlations with angry>neutral probe how individual differences affect social processing of anger faces — a social-processing analysis.
No affiliation/attachment task elements (e.g., cooperative vs loved one contrasts); this is emotion recognition-focused.
Relates reception of facial communication (angry faces) to an alexithymia measure, meeting Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Does not involve self-perception or self-related judgments; participants label others' facial emotions.
Addresses perception and understanding of others' emotions (anger) in relation to TAS-20-DDF, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
TAS-20-DDF correlations with fearful>neutral examine social-processing differences in perceiving fearful faces linked to alexithymia.
No affiliation/attachment measures or contrasts are present; study focuses on emotion recognition under temporal constraint.
Fearful face perception and its relation to TAS-20-DDF involve reception of facial communication, satisfying Social Communication criteria.
No self-related processing is measured in this analysis; it focuses on others' emotion perception.
Examines neural correlates of perceiving others' fearful expressions and their relation to alexithymia — fits Perception and Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with happy>neutral probe observer-rated alexithymia effects on social perception of facial emotion — a social-processing analysis.
No attachment/affiliation constructs are assessed; analysis pertains to emotion recognition and alexithymia ratings.
Relates reception of facial communication (happy faces) to an observer-rated alexithymia subscale, matching Social Communication.
No self-referential task component; participants label emotions of other people's faces.
Examines understanding of others' emotional expressions and how observer-rated alexithymia relates to neural responses, aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with angry>neutral investigate how observer-rated alexithymia modulates social processing of angry faces — a social-processing measure.
The analysis does not assess affiliation/attachment or relationship contexts; it focuses on emotion recognition and trait relationships.
Concerns reception/recognition of facial communication (anger) and its neural correlates as a function of TSIA-DDF, meeting Social Communication criteria.
No self-related judgments or contrasts are present; task focuses on others' emotional expressions.
Analyzes perception and neural representation of others' angry emotional states in relation to observer-rated alexithymia, fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
TSIA-DDF correlations with fearful>neutral probe how observer-rated alexithymia affects social processing of fearful faces — clearly a social-processing analysis.
No measures of affiliation, bonding, or attachment are involved; focus is on emotion recognition under time constraints.
Examines reception of facial communication (fear) and its neural correlates as a function of TSIA-DDF, fulfilling Social Communication criteria.
Does not involve self-perception or self-referential tasks; participants label others' facial emotions.
Relates neural processing of others' fearful expressions to observer-rated alexithymia, consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The CV>NV contrast contrasts social, empathy-inducing campaign videos with neutral driving videos and explicitly targets socio-cognitive and socio-emotional processing (empathy, mentalising). This meets both criteria: the task is social and the contrast measures social processing related to understanding others’ mental/emotional states.

The study targets empathy and socio-emotional responses to victims rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, bonding, cooperation vs loved-one vs stranger). The task does not explicitly probe attachment or affiliation processes, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.

Participants viewed dynamic social interactions with audio and visual cues; the stimuli require reception of affective/non-verbal cues and processing of communicative social content. The CV>NV contrast therefore captures social communication processes.

Although behavioral measures included some self-referencing indices, the imaging contrast (CV>NV) and reported brain–behavior correlations focused on understanding others’ states (empathy) rather than explicit self-related judgments or a Self>Other contrast. Thus it does not satisfy the Perception/Self inclusion criteria for the neural analysis.

The study is expressly about empathy and understanding others’ mental and emotional states (the composite empathic expression index correlated with STS activation). The CV>NV contrast therefore measures perception and understanding of others (empathy/Theory of Mind), meeting the inclusion criteria.

The task is impression formation of social targets (faces) paired with moral/financial status cues and the contrasts assess neural responses to social status — this is a social processing task measuring social cognition and evaluation.

The paradigm includes social-comparison elements (participants assigned a status; targets are higher/same/lower) and post-scan likeability/similarity ratings tapping affiliation-related judgments, so it measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.

Participants viewed faces and formed impressions; the task involves reception of facial communication (viewing faces) and the contrasts examine responses to face stimuli with social information, meeting Social Communication criteria.

The primary fMRI task and contrasts probe evaluation of others, not explicit self-judgments or self>other contrasts. Although participants had an assigned status and similarity ratings were collected post-scan, the imaging contrasts do not index perception/understanding of the self.

The contrasts directly assess neural responses to other people varying in moral and financial status (impression formation, trait-like evaluations), which matches Perception and Understanding of Others.

The main effect of Status Type compares responses to different social status dimensions (moral vs financial) during impression formation of faces — a social processing contrast measuring social cognition.

Status Type manipulation (moral vs financial) taps social-evaluative and affiliative judgments (likeability/similarity measures reported), reflecting affiliation/attachment processes via social comparison.
Analysis examines neural responses to faces conveying socially relevant information (status cues); therefore it falls under Social Communication (reception of facial communication).
This contrast tests effects of Status Type on responses to others; it does not involve explicit self-referential judgments or self>other comparisons in the imaging data.
Status Type main effect evaluates how perceivers represent and respond to others' moral versus financial status — directly assessing perception/understanding of others.
The main effect of Status Level (Lower/Same/Higher) examines social-evaluative processing during impression formation of faces with status cues — a core social processing measure.

Status Level comparisons relate to likeability and similarity (affiliation-related judgments) and reflect social comparison/affiliation dynamics, meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
This analysis involves viewing faces and measuring neural responses as a function of status level; thus it constitutes Social Communication (reception of facial information) processing.

Although similarity ratings to self were collected post-scan, the imaging main effect of Status Level concerns responses to others and not explicit self-processing contrasts, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Status Level effects index how perceivers evaluate and represent others differing in status (higher/same/lower), directly targeting perception and understanding of others.

Contrast Angry > Neutral uses socially relevant video of an opponent's facial expression during a social interaction (Taylor Aggression Paradigm). This directly measures social processing (perception and response to social cues) across subjects.

The task is a competitive social interaction (TAP) probing social behavior in a cooperation/competition context; Angry > Neutral contrast examines reactions in this affiliative/competitive social domain.
The contrast contrasts viewing angry versus neutral facial expressions (receptive facial communication), fitting Social Communication (reception of facial signals).

The contrast measures responses to another person's facial expressions and behavioral choices, not judgments about the participant themself (no self>other or self-judgment contrast), so Perception/Self is not assessed.
Angry > Neutral directly probes perception and understanding of another agent's emotional state (opponent's angry expression), matching Perception/Understanding of Others.
Angry > Neutral (outcome or decision phase) involves processing socially relevant emotional expressions in an interactive context; thus it measures social processing.
The TAP is a competitive social paradigm (affiliation/attachment domain includes competition/cooperation); this contrast examines behaviorally relevant social signals in that context.
Contrast isolates neural response to angry vs neutral facial communication (reception of facial emotion), matching Social Communication criteria.
No measures or contrasts target self-perception or self-judgment (e.g., Self > Other); the contrast addresses perception of the opponent, not the self.
The contrast assesses perception/processing of the opponent's emotional state (anger vs neutral), directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.
Parametric modulation of Angry > Neutral with punishment selections links trial-by-trial social cue processing to social behavior in an interactive task, satisfying Social Processing.

This parametric analysis examines how competitive/affiliative social context (opponent anger) modulates aggression (social behavior in competition), so it pertains to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition/cooperation).

The modulation examines neural sensitivity to another's facial communication (angry expression) as it relates to communicative/affective behavior (punishment selection), fitting Social Communication reception.
Parametric modulation links perception of others to behavioral response but does not test self-related judgments or self>other contrasts; thus Perception/Self is not measured.
This analysis specifically addresses how perception of the opponent's emotion (angry vs neutral) relates to behavior, directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast FAIR > UNFAIR comes from an ultimatum game, a classic social-norm decision-making task involving evaluation of fairness in social exchanges. It directly measures social processing (perception/interpretation of social offers and norm enforcement).

The UG probes social norms, cooperation/competition and responses to others' offers (affiliation/attachment-related processes such as normative enforcement and social bonding), so this contrast measures affiliation/attachment-relevant constructs.

The task and contrast do not involve communicative signals (faces, gaze, expressive reciprocity, or explicit receptive/expressive communication); it is a decision-making/norm-enforcement contrast rather than a social-communication paradigm.

Although choices affect self-interest, this contrast does not operationalize explicit self-reflection, self-judgment, or tasks that directly probe self-related representations (e.g., self vs other), so it does not meet the Perception/Self criterion.

FAIR > UNFAIR captures responses to others' offers and norm violations, reflecting representations and evaluations of other agents' behavior (understanding others’ fairness/intentions), consistent with perception/understanding of others.
The UNFAIR > FAIR contrast probes neural responses to social norm violations in the ultimatum game, directly indexing social processing of others' offers and norm enforcement.

Responses to unfairness involve social evaluation, punishment, and cooperative/normative enforcement processes tied to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation/competition), so this contrast maps onto affiliation/attachment.
No explicit social-communication signals or tasks (faces, gaze, communicative exchange) are involved; this is a decision/valuation contrast rather than a communication contrast.
Contrast indexes evaluation of offers (others' behavior) and normative responses, not explicit self-reflection or self-judgment processes required for Perception/Self inclusion.
UNFAIR > FAIR reflects processing of others' unfair behavior and likely engages representations of others' intentions and traits (perception/understanding of others), meeting the criterion.
HUMAN > COMPUTER directly contrasts social (human proposer) vs non-social (computer) conditions in the UG, clearly indexing social processing differences attributable to social interaction context.

The HUMAN > COMPUTER contrast isolates brain responses to human partners, tapping processes related to social bonds, trust and normative interpersonal interactions (affiliation/attachment constructs such as cooperation/competition).

Although this contrast concerns social vs non-social agents, it does not probe communicative behaviors or signals (faces, gaze, explicit communication), so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion.
The contrast compares responses to human vs computer proposers and does not assay explicit self-related judgments or self-awareness processes required for Perception/Self inclusion.
By contrasting human and computer proposers, this analysis indexes how participants represent and respond to other agents (human intentions/agency), aligning with perception/understanding of others.
The modulation contrast HIGH(UNFAIR–FAIR) > LOW(UNFAIR–FAIR) examines how monetary incentives alter fairness-related social decision-making in the UG, a social processing measure.
This contrast captures changes in responses to others' offers depending on stake size, reflecting shifts in normative enforcement/cooperation dynamics—processes relevant to affiliation/attachment.
The contrast manipulates incentives and fairness but does not involve communicative signal processing (faces, gaze, vocal/expressive exchanges), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
Although stake size affects self-interest, the contrast is focused on social-norm processing rather than explicit self-reflection or self-judgment tasks required for Perception/Self inclusion.
The contrast probes how perception/evaluation of others' offers (fairness) is modulated by incentives—this reflects representations of others and their behavior, consistent with Perception/Others.
This is the same modulation contrast restricted to human proposers; it directly indexes social processing in interpersonal contexts (how incentives change norm enforcement with human partners).
Within-human modulation of fairness by stake size reflects changes in interpersonal normative and cooperative dynamics (affiliation/attachment-relevant processes), so inclusion applies.
Even though limited to human partners, the task still does not involve explicit communicative exchanges or signals; it is decision-making about offers rather than communication per se.
While decisions implicate self-interest, the contrast does not explicitly probe self-related awareness or self-judgment processes required for Perception/Self inclusion.
Restricting the modulation contrast to human proposers isolates how participants represent and respond to other human agents' offers and intentions, meeting Perception/Others inclusion.

The conjunction analysis tests common activity across triad, self, and other tasks — all are social-related mentalizing tasks (imagining social interactions, self-referential and other-referential processing). This contrast clearly measures general social processing and recruits core mentalizing regions (MPFC, PCC, TPJ).

The study contrasts do not specifically measure affiliation or attachment (no measures or tasks targeting close relationships, bonding, or explicit cooperation/competition). The conjunction simply identifies common mentalizing activations across tasks, not attachment-related processes.

Although the tasks are social/mentalizing in nature, they do not involve explicit social communication paradigms (e.g., face/gaze processing, communicative gestures, emotion recognition). The conjunction reflects general mentalizing overlap rather than communication-specific processing.

One of the included conditions is the self-referential task and the conjunction shows core medial prefrontal activations associated with self-related processing. Thus the analysis includes neural responses from a task that measures perception/understanding of self.

The conjunction includes the other-referential condition and shows TPJ and precuneus activations linked to reasoning about others. Therefore the analysis includes processing related to perception/understanding of others.

The contrast triad > (self & other) isolates neural activity specific to imagining triadic social interactions (self + other + object), a social processing task recruiting mirror and mentalizing systems.

The triadic condition asks participants to imagine an object in a social interaction but does not explicitly measure affiliation/attachment, bonding, or cooperation scales. No direct measures or contrasts of affiliation (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation vs neutral) are present.

The triad contrast emphasizes imagined joint action and action understanding (mirror system) rather than explicit communicative behaviors (faces, gaze, gestures). The task does not operationalize social communication per the examples (e.g., face/gaze processing).
This contrast isolates triadic interaction relative to self and other conditions; it is not a comparison targeting self-referential processing (in fact it controls out self).

Triadic interactions recruit mirror neuron areas (IFG, IPL) associated with action perception/understanding of others' actions. The contrast isolates processes involving representing another agent's action in joint context, fitting perception/understanding of others (action perception subcomponent).
The Self > (Other & Triad) contrast specifically isolates self-referential processing, which is a core component of social processing and mentalizing, engaging MPFC/ACC.
The self contrast targets self-relevance and memory effects, not affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or cooperative/competitive interactions).
Self > (Other & Triad) isolates self-referential cognition (MPFC/ACC) rather than communicative reception/production; task does not involve explicit communication stimuli.

This contrast explicitly isolates self-referential processing (self > other & triad) and yields activation in anterior cingulate/medial prefrontal regions classically linked to self-knowledge and self-related judgments.
The contrast is selective for self > others and triad and does not index perception/understanding of others.

The Other > (Self & Triad) contrast isolates other-referential mentalizing (e.g., judgments about Angela Merkel) and engages core mentalizing regions (right TPJ, PCC), reflecting social processing about others.
The other contrast is about attributing self-relevance to a public figure and does not measure affiliation or attachment to close others or bonding constructs.

Other > (Self & Triad) captures mentalizing about another person's relation to objects (theory of mind) but does not involve explicit communication stimuli (faces, gaze, gestures) or communicative exchanges.
This contrast isolates other-referential processing rather than self-related processing; it does not index perception/understanding of self.

Other > (Self & Triad) directly targets other-referential judgments and engages right TPJ and PCC/precuneus associated with representing others' mental states (theory of mind), matching the perception_others construct.

The contrast tests brain responses to typical vs. atypical (incongruent) dyadic social interactions using point-light displays while participants performed an unrelated task. This directly measures social processing (detection and interpretation of social interactions and violations of social expectations).

The task manipulates congruency of observed interactions but does not assess affiliation, bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship constructs (no loved-one vs stranger or attachment measures).

Participants view non-verbal, point-light biological motion of two agents and the analysis probes perception of their interactive/non-interactive communication (receptive non-facial social communication), fitting the Social Communication construct.
The experiment addresses third-person perception of others' interactions and does not involve self-related judgments, self-recognition, or agency/self-knowledge contrasts.

The study explicitly examines perception and understanding of others via point-light biological motion and contrasts congruent vs incongruent interactions, directly matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (animacy/action perception, understanding others' actions/intentions).
Same contrast as analysis_0 (atypical vs typical dyadic point-light displays); it probes social processing of interactions and expectation violations, satisfying both inclusion criteria.
This analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).
The contrast evaluates perception of non-verbal interactive cues in point-light displays (receptive non-facial communication), which fits Social Communication inclusion criteria.
No self-related processing or self vs other contrasts are present; task assesses third-person perception only.

The analysis examines perception and interpretation of others' actions/intentions using point-light biological motion, directly matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (examples explicitly list point-light biological motion).

The analysis contrasts affective (reactive–aggressive and social-positive) vs neutral interactions using first-person videos and explicit empathic instructions. This is a social-related task probing perception, interpretation, and response to social cues, so it measures broad Social Processing.

The analysis includes the social-positive condition (social/positive interactions) contrasted with neutral, which directly probes affiliation/positive social bonding and approach tendencies (behavioral tendency ratings).

Stimuli contain communicative body and facial actions (dynamic social interactions) and the contrasts examine responses to these communicative signals (receptive processing of non‑verbal/gestural social communication).

Participants were instructed to put themselves in the first-person perspective and provided self-reports of feelings/behavioral tendencies; contrasts therefore tap processes related to self‑perception/awareness and self-referential appraisal.

Analyses probe perception and understanding of others' actions, intentions and emotional states (empathy for aggressive or positive interactions, judging others' behavior), meeting the Perception/Understanding of Others construct.
This analysis (A) derives from the same first-person social interaction paradigm and contrasts affective vs neutral conditions; it therefore measures broad social processing.
Condition A includes social-positive interactions (approach/friendly scenarios) compared to neutral, indexing affiliation-related processing and bonding-related cues (behavioral approach ratings).
Analysis A interrogates neural responses to dynamic, communicative social signals (gestures, body language, facial cues) and thus meets Social Communication criteria.
Participants adopt a first‑person perspective and report internal states; contrasts in A therefore engage self-perception and self-referential processes.
The analysis examines perception/interpretation of others' actions and intentions (aggressive or friendly agents), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Analysis B uses contrasts from the first‑person social video task; it taps core social processing (perception, interpretation and responses to social interactions).
Social-positive vs neutral contrasts in B index affiliation/attachment processes (positive interaction and approach behavior).
Dynamic communicative signals (body movement, gestures, facial cues) are central to these contrasts, meeting Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Because participants adopted a first‑person perspective and provided self-ratings, contrasts in B engage self‑related perceptions and judgments.
Analyses in B examine participants' representation of others' actions, intentions, and emotions (empathy/understanding), consistent with Perception of Others.
Analysis C corresponds to contrasts from the same social-interaction fMRI paradigm and thus measures broad Social Processing networks engaged by the stimuli.
This analysis includes social-positive conditions (or conjunctions involving them) that probe affiliation-related processing (approach/friendly responses).
The contrasts assess neural responses to communicative, non‑verbal social signals in the videos (body language, facial expressions), meeting Social Communication criteria.
First-person perspective instructions and self-report measures mean contrasts in C engage self-awareness and self-related appraisal processes.
Analysis C probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states and actions (empathic appraisal of aggressive vs positive agents), matching Perception of Others criteria.
Analysis D (final-phase contrasts) derives from the same first-person interactive video task and targets social processing (evaluation and response to interactions), so Social Processing applies.
Final-phase contrasts include social-positive vs neutral and thus probe affiliation/attachment processing (friendly interactions, approach behavior ratings).
Final-phase clips contain communicative gestures and emotional expressions; contrasts measure receptive social communication processing.
Participants' adoption of the first‑person perspective and subsequent self-reports indicate engagement of self‑perception mechanisms in final-phase contrasts.
Final-phase contrasts assess understanding of others' actions and emotional consequences (empathy/attribution), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast isolates processing of communicated social feedback (exchange of socially relevant information); therefore measures social communication.
The contrast is self > other at feedback onset, directly indexing self-related perception/processing (self-referential feedback).

Contrast examines neural responses to social feedback about the other person versus self—clearly a social processing contrast.
Receiving and processing feedback about another person involves social comparison and relationship-relevant information, fitting affiliation/attachment constructs.
Contrast isolates processing of communicated social information about another person (receptive social communication).
This contrast targets Other > Self, so it does not primarily index self-perception processes.
Other > Self contrast directly indexes perception/understanding of others (processing feedback about another person).
Interaction tests cultural modulation of social feedback processing (self vs other) — clearly within social processing domain.
Interaction probes cultural differences in conformity/social evaluation following peer feedback (social comparison/affiliation relevance).

Interaction involves self > other and its modulation by culture, directly indexing self-related processing differences.

This analysis correlates whole-brain activity (self > other) with behavioral updating (conformity) — directly addresses social feedback processing.

Feedback discrepancy reflects social comparison and updating (conformity/social learning), aligning with affiliation/attachment constructs.
Analysis measures how communicated feedback (discrepancies) is received and processed, a social-communication function (receptive processing).
Includes self-related feedback discrepancies and their neural correlates, indexing self-perception/processing.
Also includes other-related feedback discrepancies and neural responses (mentalizing about others), directly indexing perception/understanding of others.
Negative trial-by-trial correlations with feedback discrepancies (self and other) remain squarely within social feedback and comparison processing.
This analysis examines the social-comparison component (discrepancies) which relates to social learning and affiliation processes.
Focuses on neural responses to communicated feedback discrepancies (receptive social communication); thus included under social communication.
Captures self-related discrepancy processing (self vs other included) and associated neural responses, indexing self-perception.

The task involves trait judgments (self vs other) using words, not social communication (faces, gaze, or communicative signals).

Although the task includes an other-judgment condition, this specific contrast (Self > Other) is focused on self-referential processing and does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others.
Localizer contrasts include other-judgment vs self, a social cognitive task involving reasoning about another person (President Obama).
The localizer does not assess affiliation or attachment (no measures of relationship bonds or cooperation/competition).
Task is trait judgment about self/other (text-based), not social communication processing such as facial or communicative signal reception/production.

Contrast compares Communication > Moral items from the main experiment, which involves social content and social task context (group/alone), so it falls under broad social processing.

This contrast targets self-referential versus other-referential processing of statements rather than social communication per se (faces, gaze, or communicative signals).
Self > Other in the main experiment directly indexes perception/understanding of the self (self-referential neural responses to first-person vs third-person statements).

The contrast examines neural responses to witnessing an emergency modulated by number of bystanders. This is a social task assessing how social context (group size) influences processing of social scenes and action preparation. Meets I1 (social-related task).

The study addresses helping behavior and social influence (bystander effect) but does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation task). Does not meet the inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.

The task is not about sending or receiving communicative signals (e.g., face/voice processing, gaze, explicit emotion recognition). Stimuli were blurred and the focus is on action preparation rather than social communication per se, so it does not meet social communication criteria.
Analyses do not involve self-related judgment, self-concept, agency, or viewing the self. The contrasts concern observing others and social context, not self-processing.

The contrasts probe perception and understanding of others (observing a person fainting, bystander presence, action preparation, empathy-related processes). This fits Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception/empathy). Meets I1 and I2.
This analysis examines increases in activity with group size during observation of social scenes (bystander presence), a social processing manipulation. Meets I1.

Although related to social context, the contrast indexes visual/attention responses to group size and not affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation). Does not meet inclusion for affiliation/attachment.

The contrast reflects visual/perceptual changes with group size rather than communicative signal processing (faces blurred, not measuring receptive/expressive communication). Does not meet social communication criteria.
No self-related processing or judgments are assessed in this contrast; it focuses on visual/attentional responses to others, not self-perception.

Even though activations are in visual/attention regions, the manipulation concerns perception of others (number of bystanders) and how observers process others in an emergency. This assesses Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/action perception). Meets I1 and I2.
Control > bystander contrast tests responses to social scenes (presence vs absence of bystanders) and visual complexity; it still involves social stimuli and context, satisfying I1.
The contrast isolates visual complexity effects of social scenes and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures). Does not meet inclusion criteria.
This contrast focuses on visual-processing differences and not communicative signal reception/production (faces blurred, no communication-specific task). Does not meet social communication inclusion.
No self-referential processing is involved; task contrasts social scenes, not self-related judgments or agency.

The contrast contrasts scenes with vs without bystanders, directly manipulating others' presence and thus perception of others. This fits Perception and Understanding of Others (animacy/other perception). Meets I1 and I2.
Falling > standing contrasts responses to another's emergency vs neutral action; this is a social task probing processing of others in distress and therefore meets I1 for social processing.

The contrast examines perception of an emergency versus a neutral event and is not a measure of affiliation/attachment (no bonding or relationship comparisons). Not meeting inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.

Although emotional content is present, the task is not assessing communicative exchanges, facial/expressive reception or production; it targets empathic/action preparation responses, so it does not meet social communication inclusion.
This contrast is about observing another person's action (falling vs standing), not self-related processing, so it does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

Directly compares perception of another's emergency (falling) versus neutral (standing), indexing perception/understanding of others' states and eliciting empathic/action-perception processes. Meets I1 and I2.
Standing > falling contrasts responses to the person standing versus falling, manipulating social content and perception of others; qualifies as social processing under I1.
This contrast contrasts neutral vs emergency actions and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation). Does not meet inclusion criteria.
The contrast does not target communicative signaling or face/voice processing; it focuses on perceptual differences and is not a social communication task per the inclusion criteria.
No self-related judgments or agency assessments are involved; contrast concerns perception of another person, not the self.
Contrasts perception of another's state (standing vs falling), relevant to understanding others' actions and states (animacy/action perception), meeting I1 and I2.

The analysis examines face perception (faces > houses) and links fusiform gyrus activation to quantitative social-cognition measures (EQ, SRS, SAT). This is clearly a social-related task and measures social processing broadly (face processing, empathy, social responsiveness).

The task/contrast (faces vs houses) and reported analyses probe face perception and general social cognition (empathy, social responsiveness) but do not assess affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved-one vs stranger, cooperation, bonding). No measures or contrasts targeting affiliation/attachment are reported.

The contrast is faces > houses (viewing pictures of faces), and the study links neural responses to measures of affective/social competence. This fits Social Communication (reception of facial communication) per the inclusion examples.

No self-referential or self-judgment task is included (no self > other contrasts, no viewing of the participant's own face, and no explicit self-awareness measures). The analysis does not measure perception/understanding of self.

Face perception (faces > houses) and the use of social attribution and empathy measures relate to perception/understanding of others (animacy and social meaning of faces). The SAT-MC and face stimuli probe interpretation of others' social signals, consistent with this construct.

Imitating is an online social interaction task requiring perception, interpretation and response to another person’s actions (role switching between model and imitator). This directly measures social processing (social interaction, action understanding, anticipation).
Task involves reciprocal imitation but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition contrasts).
Task is hand-gesture imitation (production of non-facial communicative gestures), matching the example domain (hand mimicking) and directly measures social communication exchanges.

Although imitating requires self-monitoring and action production, the contrasts do not explicitly probe self-awareness, agency judgments or self-referential evaluation (no self>other or explicit agency contrasts), so it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion examples.

Imitating requires perceiving and understanding another’s actions and intentions (action perception and anticipating role switching), fitting Perception/Understanding of Others and ToM-related processes.
Being imitated is an interactive social condition requiring interpretation of another’s behavior and role dynamics, thus measuring social processing.
The condition does not explicitly assess affiliation or attachment (no bonding or relationship measures), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Being imitated involves non-facial communicative hand gestures and reciprocal exchange (receptive/interpretive aspect), matching social communication criteria (hand mimicking).

Although self-other representation and agency may be engaged, the analysis does not explicitly test self-related judgments or self>other contrasts; thus it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion examples.
Being imitated requires perceiving others’ actions and inferring intentions (anticipation of role switching and mentalizing), directly addressing Perception/Understanding of Others.
Observation of hand gestures is a social perception task (perceiving another’s actions) and forms the baseline social processing condition in this study.
Passive observation does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or bonding-related measures; therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
Observation of hand gestures probes reception of non-facial social communication (action perception, gesture processing), consistent with the social communication inclusion examples.
The observation contrast focuses on perceiving others rather than explicit self-referential processing or self-evaluation, so it does not satisfy the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.
Observation directly measures action perception and understanding of others’ movements (fits animacy/action perception and mentalizing examples), meeting Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.

PPI for Imitating-IFG examines changes in functional connectivity of mirror system during an online social interaction; this directly assesses social processing integration between action and mentalizing systems.
The PPI connectivity analysis targets neural coupling during imitation but does not test affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship contrasts).

Seed in IFG (mirror system) during imitation probes neural substrates of producing/processing communicative hand actions and their social exchange dynamics (fits social communication, e.g., hand mimicking).

Although PPI shows coupling between IFG and medial prefrontal regions (which can be self-referential), the analysis tests connectivity modulation during a social interaction rather than an explicit self-evaluation or self>other contrast; it therefore does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The PPI reveals increased coupling with mentalizing regions (MPFC, ACC) when imitating, indicating processes of understanding/anticipating others’ intentions and action perception — clear Perception/Understanding of Others.
PPI for Being imitated-IFG examines functional coupling during an interactive social condition (being imitated), thus measuring social processing integration between mirror and mentalizing systems.

Although being imitated can have affiliative aspects behaviorally, this analysis does not explicitly measure attachment or affiliation (no bonding metrics), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Being imitated engages reception and interpretation of non-facial communicative gestures; IFG-seed connectivity during this condition addresses social communication processing (reception of non-facial gestures).

The PPI is focused on connectivity changes during social interaction rather than explicit self-referential evaluation or agency contrasts, so it does not satisfy the Perception/Self inclusion examples.

Connectivity increases with mentalizing regions during being imitated reflect inference about the other’s actions and intentions (action perception/ToM), satisfying Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.
PPI for Imitating-IPL tests connectivity of a mirror-system node during imitation in an interactive social task, directly assessing social processing.
The IPL connectivity analysis addresses action/mentalizing coupling during imitation but does not directly measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship contrasts).

IPL is a posterior mirror-system region implicated in action perception/means; its increased coupling during imitation reflects processing of non-facial communicative gestures (hand mimicking), meeting social communication criteria.

Although IPL coupling with medial structures may relate to self/other mapping, the analysis does not explicitly probe self-referential judgments or agency contrasts required by Perception/Self inclusion examples.

Imitating-IPL connectivity with medial frontal and precuneus regions reflects action perception and inference about others’ intentions (action perception/ToM), meeting Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.
PPI for Being imitated-IPL examines functional coupling during an interactive social condition (being imitated), directly assessing social processing between mirror and mentalizing systems.
Being imitated-IPL connectivity pertains to action and mentalizing processes but does not explicitly test affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures), so excluded.
Being imitated engages reception of non-facial communicative gestures; IPL connectivity during this condition indexes perception/processing of those gestures consistent with social communication.
The analysis examines connectivity changes during social interaction rather than explicit self-evaluation or agency contrasts; therefore it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

Being imitated-IPL coupling with precuneus and medial frontal areas indicates processes of action perception and inference about others’ intentions (animacy/action perception and ToM), meeting Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.

The analysis examines neural differences between prosocial and proself participants during one-shot prisoner’s dilemma decisions, focusing on social cognition (medial PFC, TPJ, precuneus) and how dispositional trust and SVO shape cooperative behavior. This is a social-related task and the contrast measures social processing (mentalizing, trust, cooperation).

The task is a cooperation/competition paradigm (prisoner’s dilemma). The contrast (main effect of SVO on decision-making) directly pertains to affiliation-related behavior (cooperation levels differ by SVO), satisfying the affiliation/attachment criteria.

The study does not probe social communication (receptive or productive communication such as face/emotion processing, gaze, or explicit communicative exchanges). Although partner photographs were shown to reinforce anonymity, the main contrast indexes decision-making/mentalizing rather than social communication per se.

Results and interpretation emphasize self-referencing and agency (precuneus activation) and differences in self-related processing between groups, indicating that the analysis measures processes related to perception/understanding of the self.

The analysis highlights mentalizing and inference of others' intentions (TPJ, medial PFC), consistent with perception and understanding of others (theory-of-mind processes). The contrast measures these processes across SVO groups.

This analysis tests the interaction between dispositional trust and SVO on neural activation in social cognition regions (TPJ, medial frontal cortex, precuneus). It directly measures social processing related to trust and cooperation.

The interaction concerns how dispositional trust modulates cooperative decision-making (affiliation) across SVO groups in the prisoner’s dilemma, fitting the affiliation/attachment construct (cooperation task).
The interaction analysis focuses on trust-modulated social cognition (mentalizing) and does not assess social communication components (e.g., face/emotion perception or communicative behaviors).

The interaction produced effects in the precuneus and relates to self-referencing/expectation-matching processes; thus the contrast probes perception/understanding of the self in social decision contexts.
The interaction identifies modulation of regions (TPJ, medial frontal gyrus) implicated in inferring others' intentions and mental states, directly indexing perception and understanding of others.

This contrast tests the main effect of emotional (sad vs neutral) context across all three social conditions (empathy, ToM, self-reference). The task explicitly involves social cognition (inferring internal states of pictured people), satisfying social processing.

The study manipulates empathy, ToM, and self-reference using IAPS pictures and does not measure affiliation, bonding, or relationship-related variables (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.
Participants view pictures of people and infer emotional/internal states from visual cues; this involves reception of facial/nonverbal emotion cues consistent with social communication measures.

The contrast pools across conditions including the self-reference condition (imagining how one would feel), so the analysis contains measurements related to perception/understanding of the self in social contexts.

Empathy and ToM conditions explicitly require representing others’ emotions and mental states, and this contrast includes those conditions, meeting the criteria for perception/understanding of others.
This contrast (Empathy: sad vs neutral) isolates social cognitive processing of others’ emotions (imagining what the main character feels), directly measuring social processing.

The empathy task asks participants to imagine another’s feelings but does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criteria.
Empathy trials use visual emotional cues from pictured individuals to infer feelings, which fits reception of facial/nonverbal communication (receptive social communication).

The empathy contrast focuses on inferring another person’s feelings (other-focused), not explicit self-related judgments (not Self > Other), so it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Empathy condition explicitly requires representing others’ emotional states (imagining what the main character is feeling), directly meeting the Perception/Others criteria.
This contrast (ToM: sad vs neutral) involves social cognitive processes (inferring what would make another feel better), so it measures social processing.
The ToM task requires inferring actions to help another but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship measures), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
The ToM condition uses pictures and social cues to infer others’ mental states; this involves receptive social communication processes (interpreting facial/situational cues).
ToM trials are other-focused (what would make the main character feel better) and do not directly measure self-judgments (not Self > Other), so Perception/Self is not met.
ToM explicitly requires reasoning about others’ internal states and intentions, matching the Perception/Others inclusion criteria (Understanding Mental States).
Self-reference sad vs neutral isolates social-cognitive processes in a first-person perspective within a social task (imagining oneself in another’s situation), so it is social processing relevant.

The self-reference condition asks participants to imagine their own feelings in a scenario but does not assess affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding, so affiliation/attachment does not apply.

Although self-focused, the condition involves interpreting social/affective cues from pictured people to construct an emotional response; this engages receptive social communication processes (viewing faces/emotional context).
Self-reference explicitly asks participants to imagine how they would feel (self-focused perspective), directly meeting the Perception/Self inclusion criterion (thinking about the self).
This contrast isolates self-referential processing (how I would feel) rather than representing others’ mental states, so it does not meet the Perception/Others criterion.

This contrast compares Empathy vs ToM across emotions and directly probes different kinds of social cognition (inferring feelings vs reasoning about how to help), so it clearly measures social processing.

Although both conditions involve other-focused processing, the contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
Both Empathy and ToM conditions require interpreting social/emotional cues from pictured persons (receptive social communication), so the contrast involves social communication processes.
The contrast pits two other-focused conditions (Empathy vs ToM) and does not isolate self-related judgments (not Self > Other), so Perception/Self is not met.
Both conditions require understanding others’ emotional/mental states (Empathy and ToM), and the contrast examines differential processing of others, meeting the Perception/Others criterion.
ToM > Empathy directly probes social cognitive processes (higher-order reasoning about another’s state vs empathic feeling), so it measures social processing.
The ToM vs Empathy contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment (no tasks about bonding, cooperation, or close relationships), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
ToM and Empathy use visual social cues to infer mental states and emotions, engaging receptive social communication processes; thus the contrast involves social communication.
This contrast is other-focused (ToM vs Empathy) and does not measure self-related judgments (not Self > Other), so Perception/Self is not included.
ToM explicitly targets understanding others’ mental states (what would make someone feel better), so Perception/Others inclusion criterion is met.
Empathy > Self-reference contrasts other-focused social inference (imagining another’s feelings) against self-focused perspective, so it probes social processing and self–other differentiation.
The contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding or relationship quality), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
Both conditions use visual social/affective cues from pictured people to infer feelings (empathy) or imagine oneself (self-reference); these engage receptive social communication mechanisms.

This contrast emphasizes Empathy > Self-reference (other > self); it does not isolate self-related processing in the direction required by the Perception/Self examples (Self > Other), so Perception/Self is not included here.

Empathy trials require inferring others’ emotional states, and this contrast specifically examines greater activation for other-focused processing versus self-focused processing, meeting Perception/Others criteria.

Self-reference > Empathy isolates self-focused social-cognitive processing (imagining oneself in another’s situation compared to inferring another’s feelings), so it is clearly social processing relevant.
The contrast compares self- vs other-focused perspective taking and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/relationship measures), so affiliation/attachment is not applicable.
Both self-reference and empathy conditions are performed on social stimuli (people in pictures) and involve interpreting social/affective cues, engaging receptive social communication processes.

This contrast (Self-reference > Empathy) explicitly isolates self-related processing (imagining how I would feel) compared to other-focused empathy, directly satisfying the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
This contrast highlights self-focused processing over representing others’ states (Self > Other), so it does not meet the Perception/Others inclusion criterion in this direction.

This contrast isolates neural correlates of explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness and attractiveness) versus control conditions, directly measuring social processing across participants.

Trustworthiness and attractiveness judgments index social-evaluative processes that guide affiliation and relationship choices; the contrast targets these affiliation-relevant social traits (even though not a direct cooperation task).
Tasks involve reception and evaluation of auditory (vocal) social signals (affect and trait information), matching the Social Communication construct (reception of non‑facial communication).

The task asks participants to judge others’ traits and emotions from voices, not to make judgments about the self; although dmPFC involvement is discussed, the contrast does not measure self-perception directly.
This contrast directly assesses perception and understanding of others’ traits (trustworthiness, attractiveness) and differentiates them from emotion/age judgments, meeting the construct criteria.
This conjunction includes social trait judgments (TR, AT) together with emotional judgments (HA) contrasted to AG, thus clearly engaging social processing of vocal cues.
TR and AT are present in this conjunction and relate to signals that inform affiliation/attachment decisions; the analysis therefore indexes affiliation-relevant evaluations.
The analysis assesses reception and evaluation of auditory social signals (voices conveying emotion and trait information), fitting Social Communication (reception of non‑facial communication).
Participants judge others (trustworthiness/attractiveness/happiness) from voices; the contrast does not involve self-judgment or direct measures of self‑knowledge or agency.
This conjunction explicitly assesses perception/understanding of others’ emotional states and social traits from voice, meeting the construct requirements.
This conjunction includes social trait judgments (TR, AT) and age judgments (AG) contrasted to happiness (HA), indexing social and trait-processing of vocal stimuli and thus social processing.
TR and AT judgments are core to social evaluation relevant to affiliation/attachment; although AG is also included, the conjunction still probes affiliation-relevant trait evaluations.
Contrast involves evaluation of vocal stimuli for trait and age information (auditory social communication), matching Social Communication (reception of non‑facial cues).
The tasks require judgments about other speakers (traits/age), not self-related judgments; the contrast does not fulfill Perception/Self criteria.
This conjunction assesses representation and reasoning about others’ traits/age from voices, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.
