Contrast compares meaningful dyadic social interaction videos vs scrambled controls; task required participants to evaluate naturalness of social scenes, so the analysis measures social processing broadly.

The task and contrast probe general perception of dyadic nonverbal interactions and naturalness, not measures of affiliation, attachment, kinship, cooperation/competition, or close-relationship comparisons.

Stimuli are communicative nonverbal interactions and the contrast isolates processing of socially relevant communicative motion versus scrambled; thus it measures social communication (receptive non-facial communication).
The contrast does not involve self-referential judgments or self vs other comparisons; it assesses perception of external social scenes rather than self-related processing.
Contrast assesses observers' perception and interpretation of others' actions and interactions (animacy and action perception), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast (Contingent > Mirrored) isolates processing of dyadic social contingency — a social task measuring perception and interpretation of social interactions, thus indexing social processing.

Although contingent interactions can imply social bonds, the experiment does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation/competition metrics or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).

Contingency manipulation directly pertains to the exchange of socially relevant information between agents (interactive dynamics), fitting Social Communication (reception of non-facial communicative cues).
This contrast probes perception of other agents' interactions rather than self-related judgments or agency/self-knowledge tasks.

Contingency vs mirrored contrasts assess how observers perceive others' coordinated actions and infer intentions (action perception/animacy and mental state understanding), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast (Mirrored > Contingent) still addresses processing of dyadic social stimuli (here symmetry/noncontingency) and participants' social judgments of naturalness, so it falls under social processing.
The mirrored (noncontingent) condition manipulates visual symmetry and contingency, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or relationship quality.
Mirrored vs contingent comparisons probe communicative relevance (loss of interactive dynamics) and the reception of nonverbal communicative cues, thus mapping to Social Communication.
No self-referential or agency/self-knowledge measures are present in this contrast; it focuses on perception of others.
This contrast examines observers' representation of others (symmetry, animacy perception, difficulty in distinguishing agents), aligning with Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast (Rigid > Smooth) addresses processing of kinematic properties of dyadic social stimuli and participants' social-evaluative judgments (naturalness), so it measures social processing broadly.
Kinematics manipulation (rigid vs smooth) probes biological motion and inferential processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship measures.
Movement fluency affects perception of communicative intent and animacy; the contrast examines reception of nonverbal communicative cues (non-facial), fitting Social Communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast manipulates observed agents' kinematics and does not require self-judgment or self/other comparisons; it therefore does not index perception of self.
Rigid vs smooth motion directly pertains to animacy and action perception and to inferences about others' intentions, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
Interaction contrast [(Contingent>Mirrored) for Smooth>Rigid] examines combined effects of contingency and fluency on perception of dyadic social interactions — a social processing measure.
The interaction probes perceptual/inferential processing of communicative kinematics and contingency, not affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific constructs.
The interaction tests how communicative dynamics (contingency) and motion fluency jointly affect reception of nonverbal communication, thus indexing Social Communication.
Although the interaction may engage self-referential processing speculatively, the task did not explicitly probe self-related judgments; therefore it does not meet Perception of Self criteria.

This interaction examines how observers perceive others' coordinated actions under different kinematic conditions, involving animacy/action perception and intention inference — fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.

The intention effect examines interns' intentions to recommend ideas — a social task involving planning social communication and influence. This maps onto broad social processing (perceiving, interpreting, and responding to social information).

The task assesses intentions to recommend media ideas and personal preferences, not measures of affiliation, attachment, close relationships, kinship, or cooperation vs. stranger contrasts. It does not target affiliation/attachment constructs.

Interns evaluated whether they would recommend ideas (a communicative intent) and later produced videotaped recommendations; the analysis links neural responses during encoding to communicative intentions, which fits social communication (production/reception of social information).

The intention effect was associated with MPFC and PC/PCC and the authors explicitly interpret this as self-relevance / interns' own preferences driving intentions (self-judgment), matching perception/understanding of self.

The intention effect primarily reflects self-relevant valuation (MPFC/PC/PCC) rather than mentalizing or reasoning about others; the analysis did not show TPJ/DMPFC mentalizing activations for this contrast.
The salesperson effect indexes interns' success at persuading producers — a social-influence task involving social cognition and interaction, fitting broad social processing.
This analysis measures persuasive ability and mentalizing, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, or close-relationship measures).

The salesperson effect reflects interns' communicative effectiveness (how well their communicated recommendations influenced producers), directly mapping onto social communication (production of non-facial communication, persuasive messaging).
The salesperson effect was associated exclusively with bilateral TPJ (mentalizing about others) rather than self-referential regions; it indexes ability to influence others, not self-judgment.

The salesperson effect was linked to bilateral TPJ, a core mentalizing region involved in understanding others' perspectives and predicting recipients' responses — this matches perception/understanding of others (Theory of Mind).
The buzz effect identifies neural responses predicting which ideas spread across people — inherently social processing (valuation and mentalizing in a social propagation context).
The buzz effect concerns message propagation, reward, and mentalizing, not affiliation/attachment measures such as bonding or kinship; it does not assess attachment constructs.

Buzz indexes which ideas the communicators encode that later spread via their communications (videotaped recommendations), tying directly to social communication processes (production and impact of communicative acts).

Although reward regions (ventral striatum) were implicated, the buzz effect primarily reflects social valuation and mentalizing about others (TPJ, DMPFC) across recipients; it is not primarily about self-judgment or self-referential processing.

The buzz effect engaged TPJ and DMPFC (mentalizing network), indicating processing related to understanding others' minds and predicting what will spread — matching perception/understanding of others (Theory of Mind).

The contrast isolates imitation vs control across observation and execution of gestures (IMI>CT in both phases). This is a social-related task involving perception and processing of communicative and non-communicative gestures and examines networks (MNS, pSTS, medial frontal areas) implicated in social cognition. Thus it measures broad Social Processing.

The contrast probes imitation of gestures generally and does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition, loved one vs stranger). No measures or contrasts related to bonding or affiliation are present.

The task requires viewing and imitating hand/arm gestures (including communicative gestures) and contrasts imitation versus a motor control. This directly indexes production/reception of non‑facial social communication (hand mimicking/gesture imitation), matching the Social Communication inclusion examples.

Perception/understanding of self typically requires explicit self-judgment or Self>Other contrasts. This contrast primarily targets imitation-related sensorimotor and mirror networks rather than explicit self‑referential judgement; self-related processing is not the primary measured construct here.

Imitation involves perceiving and understanding others' actions and intentions; the contrast engages regions (IPL, pSTS) linked to action perception and understanding others’ intentions, matching the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria (action perception/understanding mental states).

This interaction specifically contrasts social versus non-social gestures during imitation versus control in the observation phase, directly addressing recognition and processing of communicative (social) gestures and associated social-cognitive mechanisms.

The analysis contrasts social versus non-social communicative gestures but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., relationships, bonding, cooperation/competition). The task does not measure attachment-related processes.

The comparison isolates processing of communicative (social) gestures versus non-communicative gestures during an imitation-related observation task, directly indexing reception and interpretation of non-facial social communicative signals (hand gestures).

Although the authors interpret some activations (e.g., middle cingulate) as related to self-awareness, this contrast is not an explicit self‑judgment or Self>Other contrast. It primarily targets perception of others' communicative intent rather than direct measures of self‑knowledge or agency.

The interaction tests sensitivity to others' communicative intention (social vs non-social gestures) during observation with imitation intent, which is directly relevant to action perception and understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind/action perception).

Contrast CSL>TIC compares complex social (joy/taunt) versus tickling laughter and explicitly probes processing of social information in vocal signals; tasks involve social categorization and implicit/explicit social evaluation, so this contrast measures social processing.

Although tickling laughter is discussed as a bonding signal, the contrast does not operationalize or measure affiliation/attachment (no attachment scales or kinship/cooperation manipulations); thus it does not meet the specific affiliation/attachment task criteria.

Contrast examines perception of affective, nonverbal auditory communication (laughter types) and uses an explicit categorization task of vocal social signals, directly indexing social communication (receptive non-facial communication).
Contrast probes perception of others' laughter and social information, not self-related judgments or self-referential processing; it does not meet criteria for perception/understanding of self.

Complex social laughter (CSL) elicited activations and connectivity in arMFC, precuneus and other mentalizing/ToM-associated regions and the authors interpret CSL as automatically triggering mentalizing/inferences about others’ intentions. The contrast therefore indexes perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).

Contrast TIC>CSL contrasts tickling (reflex-like) versus complex social laughter and probes differences in processing socially relevant vocalizations; tasks involve social stimuli and categorization/counting, so the analysis measures social processing.

Although tickling laughter is discussed as related to social bonding, the experimental tasks and contrasts do not operationalize affiliation or attachment (no attachment-related measures), so the affiliation/attachment construct is not directly measured.

Tickling laughter is an affective nonverbal auditory signal; the contrast evaluates receptive non-facial social communication (auditory) and how different laughter types are communicated and processed, meeting the social communication criteria.
Contrast focuses on perception of others’ laughter and acoustic complexity, not self-related processing or judgments about the self.

Tickling laughter primarily modulated auditory and attentional/working-memory networks; the authors associate mentalizing processes with complex social laughter (CSL) rather than with TIC, so this contrast does not index perception/understanding of others (mentalizing) in the same way.
Contrast CAT>COU contrasts explicit laughter-type categorization versus an implicit bout-counting task, manipulating attention to social information and thus indexing social processing.

The CAT>COU contrast manipulates explicit evaluation of social signals but does not measure affiliation/attachment (no attachment-focused paradigm or measures), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This contrast explicitly manipulates processing of socially communicative vocal signals (categorization of laughter types) versus an implicit auditory task, directly targeting social communication (receptive auditory social signals).
Contrast reflects explicit evaluation of others' laughter, not self-related judgments or self-awareness processes; it does not meet criteria for perception/understanding of self.

Explicit categorization of laughter types (CAT) is interpreted by the authors as engaging processes related to inference about others (evaluation of social intentions) and elicits regions implicated in social evaluation; therefore CAT>COU can be considered to probe perception/understanding of others (mentalizing/evaluation).

This conjunction identifies regions commonly activated across all laughter types and tasks (auditory cortex, IFG, SMA) and thus reflects core processing of socially relevant vocal signals — i.e., social processing broadly construed.

The conjunction captures commonly engaged auditory and motor/IFG regions for laughter perception but does not operationalize or measure affiliation/attachment processes or attachment-related behaviors; thus it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

The conjunction highlights bilateral primary and association auditory cortex and IFG regions commonly engaged by laughter perception — directly indexing receptive social communication (auditory non-facial signals).
Conjunction regions reflect perception of external auditory social signals rather than self-referential processing; no self-related tasks or contrasts are present.

The conjunction lists commonly activated sensory and frontal regions but does not include core mentalizing areas (arMFC/precuneus) in this conjunction result; therefore it does not specifically index perception/understanding of others (ToM).

Contrast compares neural responses to receiving ‘yes’ (interest) vs ‘no’ (rejection/disinterest) in a real-world social interaction paradigm (speed-dating). This directly measures social processing (perception, interpretation, and response to social signals).
The contrast indexes affiliative outcomes (being liked) versus not being liked; it measures social bonding/affiliation value (romantic interest vs rejection).

Participants are presented with partners' faces and their decisions (social signals). The contrast measures reception of socially communicative signals (interest/rejection), matching the Social Communication construct.

Receiving yes/no from partners provides explicit feedback about the participant (their desirability); this contrast measures processing of self-relevant social feedback (self-perception/self-evaluation).
The contrast requires perceiving and interpreting others' decisions and intentions (whether partner likes the participant), thus engaging perception and understanding of others' mental states.
This contrast (No > Yes) captures neural responses to social rejection/disinterest versus interest, a core social processing measure.
No (rejection/disinterest) directly pertains to affiliation/attachment processes (loss or absence of desired social bond), so it measures affiliation-related processing.
Contrast probes reception of communicative signals (partners' ‘no’ responses) conveyed via faces/labels—fits social communication inclusion criteria.
A partner saying ‘no’ is self-relevant feedback (affects self-image/desirability); this contrast measures processing of that self-referential information.
Interpreting a partner's rejection involves reasoning about the other's decision and intentions, invoking perception/understanding of others.
Match (mutual yes) versus Unrequited (partner yes but participant no) contrasts social reward and interpersonal outcomes—clearly social processing.
Match outcomes index successful affiliative bonding (mutual interest) compared to unreciprocated interest; directly measures affiliation/attachment processes.
Contrast involves reception of partners' affirmative decisions (social communicative signals) in face-presentations—matches Social Communication criteria (faces, social signals).
Matches provide positive self-relevant feedback (reinforces self-desirability); contrast evaluates neural processing of self-related reward and evaluation.
Determining mutual vs unrequited interest requires inferring partners' attitudes/intentions (understanding others), so this contrast measures perception of others.
Rejection > Disinterest isolates neural correlates of being rejected by a desired partner versus mutual disinterest—central social processing.
This contrast contrasts negative vs neutral affiliative outcomes (rejection from a desired partner vs mutual disinterest), indexing attachment-related negative feedback.
Both conditions involve reception of partners' communicative signals (no responses) but differ in social context (desired vs undesired); the contrast probes social communication processing.
Rejection from a desired partner is highly self-relevant (affects self-evaluation); this contrast measures processing of self-related negative feedback.
Interpreting why a desired partner says no involves inferring that partner's mental state/intentions, engaging perception of others.
Mismatched (participant and partner decisions differ) vs matched trials capture expectation violation in interpersonal interaction—core social processing.
Mismatches often alter affiliative outcomes (unexpected rejection or unrequited interest) and thus relate to affiliation/attachment processes and social learning about relationships.
This contrast reflects processing of discrepant communicative signals (partner decision mismatches participant expectation) conveyed via faces/labels, fitting Social Communication.
Mismatched outcomes inform participants about themselves (unexpected feedback about desirability) and provoke self-relevant processing (surprise, self-evaluation).
Resolving mismatches requires updating beliefs about the partner (their intentions/feelings), engaging perception and understanding of others' mental states.
Unsigned prediction errors from an RL model index trial-by-trial surprise about partners' decisions (learning from social feedback)—a social processing measure.
Prediction errors quantify learning about one’s desirability (how others respond), which is central to forming and updating affiliative expectations and attachment-related beliefs.
The prediction-error signal is derived from partners' communicative decisions about the participant (yes/no), reflecting reception and interpretation of social signals.
The RL-derived prediction errors specifically model learning about the participant’s own desirability (self-relevant expectation violations), directly indexing perception/understanding of self.
Prediction errors arise from others' actions/decisions and support updating beliefs about others' tendencies—this engages perception and reasoning about others' behavior/mental states.
Comparing partners the participant said yes to vs those said no to at face-presentation examines anticipation and social valuation—core social processing.
Participants’ ‘yes’ designations index affiliative interest; neural differences when viewing ‘yes’ vs ‘no’ partners tap affiliation/attachment and anticipated bonding.
This contrast uses faces and associated social decisions (participant's own prior decision) to probe anticipatory processing of communicative outcomes—fits Social Communication criteria.
Viewing partners to whom one indicated interest involves self-referential anticipation (how the partner might respond to the self), engaging self-related representations.
Anticipating a partner’s decision requires inference about the other's likely response/attitude—engages perception and understanding of others.
Contrast of partners given a no > yes captures neural responses to viewing partners previously judged as undesirable—social processing about interpersonal evaluation.
Partners judged ‘no’ relate to absence of affiliative interest; neural differences reflect affiliation/attachment dimensions (reduced anticipated bonding).
This contrast concerns perception of faces labeled with the participant’s prior ‘no’ decision—processing communicative social cues (reception of social information).
Viewing partners one rejected still involves self-referential processing (choices reflect self-preferences and anticipated outcomes), so this contrast involves perception of self-related decisions.
Interpreting partners one rejected involves reasoning about others' potential intentions and attributes (perception of others), so inclusion is warranted.

Contrast examines famous faces vs baseline — a social/person-related face memory task assessing social processing (person identification, memory).
Famous faces invoke semantic/person knowledge but do not index close affiliative bonds (not a loved-one vs stranger task).
Viewing and recognizing faces (famous) fits Social Communication (reception of facial communication); contrast measures faces vs baseline.
No self-related task (not viewing or judging the self).
Contrast concerns perception and knowledge about other people (famous individuals), aligning with perception/understanding of others.
Contrast examines personally familiar faces vs baseline; clearly a social-related task involving person knowledge and social processing.
Personally familiar faces (friends, acquaintances) and the friend-face task (social closeness judgments) directly measure affiliation/attachment.
Task involves viewing faces and social judgments (reception of facial communication); meets social communication criteria.
Task involves others (friends) rather than self-related judgments or self-viewing.
Contrast measures perception and knowledge about other people (friends), consistent with understanding others (social closeness judgments).
Conjunction of famous and familiar faces identifies overlapping person-memory related activations — a social processing result.

The conjunction shows overlap between famous and familiar face activations but does not by itself constitute an affiliation/attachment-specific contrast (not exclusively a loved‑one vs stranger measure).
Conjunction derives from face-related contrasts (reception of facial information) and thus is relevant to social communication.
No self-related processing is measured by this conjunction map.
Conjunction reflects regions responsive to other people’s faces/identity and thus pertains to perception and understanding of others.
Faces vs landmarks contrast engages face-processing and person-related networks — a social processing task.
Contrast is general face perception (faces > landmarks) and does not target affiliation/attachment or close relationships.
Faces > landmarks is a canonical social communication/reception contrast (viewing faces).
No self-related judgments or self-viewing involved.
Contrast measures perception of others’ faces (animacy/identity), aligning with perception and understanding of others.
Landmarks > faces emphasizes non-social, scene-related processing; not a social-related task.
Contrast does not involve affiliation/attachment constructs (it contrasts places/landmarks, not people).
This contrast is not measuring reception or production of facial/social communication — it emphasizes landmarks over faces.
No self-related processing in a landmarks>faces contrast.
Contrast does not index perception/understanding of other people (focus is on landmarks/scenes).
Famous > Novel faces contrast taps person memory and social knowledge — a social processing task.
Famous faces carry semantic knowledge but do not target close affiliation/attachment (not loved‑one vs stranger).
Contrast compares face categories (familiarity) and involves reception of facial information — fits social communication criteria.
No self-related judgments are involved.
Contrast concerns recognition and knowledge about other people (famous individuals), consistent with perception of others.
Novel > Famous faces examines face perception and novelty detection within a social/person domain — a social processing-relevant contrast.
Novel faces do not probe affiliation/attachment (no loved‑one vs stranger comparison).
Contrast isolates face-related perceptual processing (reception of facial information), meeting social communication criteria.
No self-related processes are targeted.
Novel faces are stimuli of other people and this contrast indexes perception/encoding of others’ faces (fits perception_others).
Novel faces vs novel landmarks is a face-specific contrast probing social/person perception — a social processing task.
Contrast uses unfamiliar faces and landmarks and does not assess affiliative bonds or attachment.
Faces vs landmarks (novel) is a prototypical social communication/reception contrast (viewing faces).
No self-related judgments are present.
Contrast involves perception of other people’s faces (novel individuals), aligning with perception_others.
Novel landmarks > novel faces emphasizes non-social scene/place processing rather than social tasks.
No affiliation/attachment constructs are measured in a landmarks>faces contrast.
Contrast does not measure reception/production of facial/social communication (focus is landmarks).
No self-related processing in this contrast.
Contrast does not index perception/understanding of other people (focus on landmarks/scenes).
Famous faces > novel landmarks contrasts person-related stimuli with non-social scenes and probes social/person processing.
Although famous people are socially known, this contrast does not specifically assess attachment or close relationships.
Contrast involves viewing and recognizing famous faces (reception of facial information), meeting social communication criteria.
No self-referential processing is demanded by this contrast.
Contrast assesses perception/knowledge about other people (famous individuals), consistent with perception_others.
Novel landmarks > famous faces emphasizes scene/place processing and is not a social/person-specific task.
Contrast does not probe attachment/affiliation constructs.
Contrast does not measure facial/social communication; it emphasizes landmarks over faces.
No self-processing present.
Contrast focuses on landmarks and does not index perception/understanding of other people.
Famous landmarks > novel landmarks is a non-social, place/scene contrast; not a social processing task.
Contrast concerns landmarks and does not tap affiliation/attachment constructs.
Not a face/communication task; landmarks contrasts are non-social perceptual comparisons.
No self-related processing in landmark contrasts.
Contrast does not index perception/understanding of others (focus on landmarks).
Novel landmarks > famous landmarks is a place/scene contrast unrelated to social/person processing.
No affiliation/attachment constructs are present in landmark comparisons.
Contrast does not involve faces or social communication processes.
No self-related processing assessed.
Contrast does not assess perception/understanding of other people.
Familiar (friends) > novel faces directly probes social/person knowledge and social processing (friend recognition, social closeness judgments).
Contrast involves personally familiar individuals and a social closeness task (loved/close friends vs strangers), satisfying affiliation/attachment criteria.
Contrast measures reception of facial information for social judgments about friends (reception of facial communication).
Task concerns recognition/judgment about other people (friends), not self-related judgments.
Directly measures perception and understanding of others (friends) via social closeness judgments and identity recognition.
Conjunction of famous and familiar faces highlights shared person-memory activations — a social processing outcome.
As with the earlier conjunction, overlap does not specifically index affiliation/attachment (not exclusively a loved‑one vs stranger contrast).
Conjunction reflects face-related activations (reception of facial information) relevant to social communication.
No self-related processing in the conjunction map.
Overlap pertains to perceiving and identifying other people (famous and familiar), matching perception_others.

The task explicitly manipulates sociality (trustworthiness judgments of faces) and measures social working memory; this directly assesses social processing.
The task involves trait judgments (trustworthiness) and working memory but does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, bonding, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).
Participants view faces and make trait judgments (receptive facial processing), matching the inclusion examples (Viewing pictures of faces; reception of facial communication).
The task does not involve self-related judgments or self-awareness processing; it concerns judgments about others (trustworthiness).
Trustworthiness judgments are evaluations of others' traits and map onto Perception and Understanding of Others (trait inference).
Same experiment/contrast manipulates social vs. nonsocial information (trustworthiness vs. spatial location) and assesses social processing in the social condition.
No measures or contrasts targeting affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, cooperation, loved one vs stranger) are present in this analysis.
Analysis involves viewing and evaluating faces (receptive facial communication), consistent with inclusion examples such as Faces > non-faces or affect/face perception tasks.
The contrast does not involve self-referential judgments or self-processing; it targets others' trait perception.
Trustworthiness judgments are evaluations of others' traits/attributes and thus fit Perception and Understanding of Others.
This analysis is part of the same study manipulating social information (trustworthiness) and thus measures social processing broadly.
No affiliation/attachment-specific task or contrast is present; trustworthiness judgments do not equate to measures of affiliation or bonding per the inclusion examples.
Faces are presented and participants make trait-based judgments (receptive facial communication), meeting the social communication inclusion criteria.
The analysis does not involve self-related processing or self-judgments; it concerns perceptions of other individuals.
Trustworthiness judgments are evaluations of others' traits and therefore align with Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task is action observation with goal manipulations (what/how/why) and a load manipulation to probe automaticity of social-cognitive systems (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems). This directly measures social processing broadly (perception and interpretation of others’ actions and mental states).
The study does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).

Although participants view hand actions, the task probes action understanding and mentalizing rather than communicative exchange (no face/gaze/emotion communication or explicit communicative gestures), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
The analyses do not involve self-related judgments, self vs other contrasts, or agency/self-knowledge measures; thus they do not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

The contrasts probe action perception (what/how) and mental-state inference (why), engaging action perception and understanding mental states subconstructs of Perception and Understanding of Others; matches both inclusion criteria.

This contrast compares goal-directed action understanding (how) against passive observation across loads, directly targeting social-cognitive processing involved in action understanding and thus qualifies as broad social processing.
Contrast contrasts action comprehension goals; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/attachment measures).

The contrast focuses on understanding implementation of actions (how) vs observation, not on communicative reception or production (faces, gaze, emotion), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.
No self-related judgments or self vs other contrasts are involved in this analysis, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The how > observe conjunction assesses action perception and understanding of others’ actions, fitting the Action Perception subconstruct and mental-state-related processing insofar as it concerns understanding others’ behavior; meets both inclusion criteria.

This analysis tests modulation by cognitive load across goals for systems implicated in social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems), addressing automaticity of social processing and thus falls under broad social processing.
The load modulation analysis does not examine affiliation or attachment constructs or related contrasts, so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
This is a cognitive-load modulation analysis of action/mentalizing systems, not an assessment of communicative reception/production (faces/gaze/emotion), so Social Communication criteria are not met.
The analysis is about load effects on action-understanding systems; it does not involve self-related processing or self vs other comparisons, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

By assessing whether load modulates activity in systems engaged during observation of others’ actions and mental-state inference, this analysis directly probes Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception and mentalizing).

The low-load/why-goal > other-conditions contrast isolates mentalizing (inferring others’ motives) under sufficient cognitive resources — a prototypical social-cognitive process and thus broad social processing.
This contrast isolates mental-state inference about motives but does not assess affiliation/attachment or relationship-related constructs, so Affiliation/Attachment criteria are not met.

Although mentalizing concerns understanding others, this contrast targets causal attribution/mental-state inference rather than communicative reception/production (faces, gaze, emotion), so Social Communication criteria are not met.
The contrast focuses on inferring others’ motives (why), not on self-referential judgments or self vs other comparisons; Perception/Self criteria are not met.

This contrast directly targets understanding others’ mental states (mentalizing) and action motives, matching both Action Perception (context) and Understanding Mental States subconstructs; meets both inclusion criteria.
The load-by-goal interaction evaluates how cognitive resources and task goals shape activity in mirror and mentalizing systems during social perception — a central social-processing question.

The interaction analysis does not involve affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, or cooperative/competitive contexts), so it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
The analysis examines goal × load effects on action understanding and mentalizing rather than communicative behaviors or face/gaze/emotion processing; thus Social Communication criteria are not met.
There are no self-related judgments or self vs other contrasts in the interaction analysis, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The interaction isolates regions where goal (what/how/why) and load affect processing of others’ actions and mental-state inference, directly addressing Perception and Understanding of Others subconstructs; meets both inclusion criteria.

The contrast Self > Other examines perspective-taking (self vs other) in an empathy task using painful vs neutral stimuli; this is a social-related task measuring social processing of self/other perspectives.
The task and contrast probe perspective taking and empathy for pain, not affiliation/attachment processes (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or loved vs stranger comparisons).
Stimuli are hands/feet in painful situations rather than facial or communicative signal processing; the contrast does not target social communication subconstructs.
This contrast directly tests self-perspective relative to other (Self > Other), matching the Perception/Self construct (agency/self-related representation).
Self > Other emphasizes self-related processing; it does not isolate perception/understanding of others.
The Other > Self contrast probes adopting a third-person perspective (mentalizing/empathy) and therefore measures social processing.
Contrast involves perspective-taking/empathy but not affiliation/attachment (no cooperation, kinship, or relationship measures).
Stimuli and contrast do not probe facial or communicative signal reception/production; instead they probe mentalizing and regulatory processes.
Other > Self targets representation/processing of others rather than self-related judgments or agency.
The contrast specifically isolates processing related to adopting another's perspective (third-person/other), matching Perception/Understanding of Others (empathy/theory of mind).
OtherGood > OtherBad compares successful vs unsuccessful third-person perspective taking in an empathy task; this is a social processing measure.
Contrast assesses success of perspective taking/empathy, not affiliation or attachment-related processes.
Task contrasts do not target facial/non-facial communicative reception or production; they index empathic perspective-taking success.
This contrast concerns the Other perspective (successful vs unsuccessful), not self-related perception or agency.
Directly assesses successful vs unsuccessful adoption of another's perspective (empathy/theory-of-mind), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.
OtherBad > OtherGood contrasts unsuccessful > successful third-person perspective taking in an empathy paradigm—this is social processing relevant.
Contrast focuses on perspective-taking success, not affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or cooperation measures).
Stimuli and contrast do not target social communication (faces/gaze/exchange) but rather mentalizing/empathy processes.
Contrast examines processing related to others (unsuccessful perspective taking), not self-perception/agency.
This contrast isolates differences in representing/understanding others (unsuccessful vs successful), fitting the Perception/Understanding of Others construct.
SelfGood > SelfBad contrasts successful vs unsuccessful self-perspective taking within an empathy paradigm, which is social processing (self/other distinction component).
This contrast targets internal self-perspective success and not affiliation/attachment processes.
The contrast does not involve communicative signals (faces/gaze/expressive behaviors); it measures self-perspective success in empathy for pain.
Directly assesses successful vs unsuccessful adoption of the first-person perspective (Self), matching Perception and Understanding of Self (agency/self-related processes).
Contrast concerns self-perspective success, not representations of others' mental states.
SelfBad > SelfGood examines unsuccessful vs successful first-person perspective taking — a social processing contrast concerning self/other distinction and empathy.
Contrast assesses self-perspective success and not affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.
Task does not probe communicative reception/production; it targets self-perspective/empathic processes.
This contrast isolates self-perspective processing (unsuccessful > successful), fitting the Perception/Understanding of Self construct.
Focus is on self-perspective differences rather than understanding others.
Analysis 6 is unspecified but belongs to the same study investigating perspective taking and empathy; as such it likely probes social processes — include by default given study context.
No information indicates affiliation/attachment tasks (cooperation, kinship, loved vs stranger); therefore exclude.
No evidence that this analysis targets communicative signal processing (faces/gaze/expression); exclude.
Analysis name/details are not provided; cannot determine it isolates self-related processing specifically, so conservatively exclude.
Without details, cannot confirm it measures perception/understanding of others specifically; exclude conservatively.

The power-motive analysis uses social movie clips (power-related interactions) and regressions of BOLD responses on social-motive individual differences, so it targets social processing broadly.

The power-motive analysis focuses on power-related stimuli (dominance, speeches) and BOLD responses predicted by power motive scores; it does not measure affiliation/attachment content, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Stimuli are movie clips with conversational/speech and emotionally expressive social interactions (reception of auditory/affective social cues). The contrast (power > control) assesses responses to social-communicative content, meeting the social communication criteria.

The analysis does not include tasks or contrasts that explicitly probe self-referential processing (no Self>Other or explicit self-judgment); it instead assesses trait-modulated responses to external social stimuli.

Viewing power-related interpersonal interactions requires perception/understanding of others (dominant/subordinate roles, intentions); the contrast and regression on motive scores index processing of others’ social states and actions, meeting the perception-of-others criteria.
The affiliation-motive analysis uses love/affiliation movie clips and regresses BOLD responses on affiliation motive scores, directly addressing social processing related to bonding/attachment.

Stimuli are romantic/affiliation movie clips and the contrast (affiliation > control) regressed on affiliation scores specifically measures affiliation/attachment-related neural responses (e.g., right putamen/pallidum).

Affiliation clips contain emotionally expressive social interactions, conversations and bonding cues (auditory/visual communicative content); the analysis measures responses to such social-communicative stimuli.

The contrast and analysis do not explicitly probe self-referential judgments or Self>Other processing; they measure responses to others’ affiliative interactions modulated by trait affiliation, not direct self-perception tasks.

Affiliation clips involve understanding others’ emotional/relational states (romantic interactions); the affiliation > control contrast and its modulation by affiliation motive index perception and understanding of others, consistent with this construct.

This analysis indexes learning and prediction about another person's decision-making (simulated-other's reward prediction error); it directly involves social cognition/simulation. Matches inclusion I1 (social-related task).

The task involves predicting another's choices and learning their values but does not probe affiliation, attachment, or bonding (no cooperation/competition or relationship contrasts). Does not meet I1 for this construct.
The analysis does not measure communicative signals (faces, gaze, affect recognition or production/reception of social communicative behavior). Does not meet I1 for this construct.

This analysis reflects a simulated-other reward prediction error (sRPE), i.e., representation of another's internal variable rather than self-related judgments or self-awareness. It does not meet I1 for self-perception.

The sRPE is explicitly about representing and learning another person's reward expectations (Theory-of-Mind / perception of others). This directly matches I1 for Perception and Understanding of Others.

This analysis indexes the simulated-other's action prediction error (sAPE) based on observing another's choices, a core social-cognitive process (learning about others' behavior). Matches I1 (social-related task).

The sAPE reflects tracking and learning about another's choices, not affiliation/attachment or relationship bonding; no measures of cooperation/attachment are present. Does not meet I1 for this construct.

The analysis does not probe communicative channels (faces, gaze, affect recognition, or expressive behavior); it addresses action prediction/error rather than communication per se. Does not meet I1 for this construct.
The sAPE indexes prediction errors about another's actions; it is not an analysis of self-awareness, agency, or self-judgment. Does not meet I1 for self-perception.

sAPE reflects representation and learning about another's choices/behavior (understanding others' actions), directly matching I1 for Perception and Understanding of Others (e.g., Theory of Mind / action perception).

This analysis concerns the subject's reward probability in the Other task (decision based on simulation of another), which occurs within a social simulation context (predicting another's choices). Thus it is a social-related analysis (I1).
Although social, the measure is about predicting choices and value, not about affiliation, bonding, cooperation or relationship contrasts. Does not meet I1 for this construct.

The decision-variable analysis does not measure communicative reception/production (faces, gaze, emotion recognition). It reflects value-based prediction rather than social communication. Does not meet I1 for this construct.

Although the regressor is the subject's decision variable, in this Other task it primarily reflects choices made to predict another rather than introspective self-judgment or self-awareness; the primary construct targeted is understanding the other. Therefore I do not mark this as Perception/Self.

The reward probability in the Other task is computed via simulation of the other's value and is used to predict the other's choices—it indexes understanding and representation of another's internal variables/behavior (I1).

This analysis indexes the subject's own reward prediction error in the Control task, which is a nonsocial reinforcement-learning condition used as a reference; it does not involve social or other-directed processing, so it does not satisfy the social-related inclusion I1.
The Control task measures individual value learning for oneself and does not probe affiliation/attachment or relationship-based constructs. Does not meet I1 for this construct.
No measures of communicative behavior (faces, gaze, affect recognition or production) are involved in the Control task reward-prediction analysis. Does not meet I1 for this construct.

The Control task directly measures the subject's own reward prediction error and learning about their own outcomes, which maps onto Perception/Understanding of Self (self-related value signals, agency/learning about self). Matches I1 for this construct.
This analysis concerns the subject's own reward prediction error in a nonsocial Control task, not representations about others; therefore it does not meet I1 for Perception/Understanding of Others.
This analysis indexes the subject's reward probability in the Control (nonsocial) task, which does not involve social processing of others and thus fails the social-related I1 for this construct.
The Control reward-probability analysis does not probe affiliation/attachment or social bonds/cooperation; it measures individual reinforcement learning. Does not meet I1 for this construct.
No communicative reception/production measures are present in the Control task reward-probability analysis (faces, gaze, emotion recognition). Does not meet I1 for this construct.
Reward probability in the Control task reflects the subject's own decision variable and learning about their own outcomes—this maps onto self-related perception/understanding (I1).
The Control reward-probability measure pertains to self-directed decision-making and not to representation/understanding of others; it does not meet I1 for Perception/Others.

The contrast of emotional (all emotions) vs neutral trials measures emotional prosody comprehension, a social-related task requiring perception and interpretation of others' vocal emotional cues. This meets the criteria for Social Processing as it assesses social cue perception and understanding.
The task involves recognizing emotion from prosody, not assessing affiliation, attachment, kinship, cooperation, or relationship-related processes (no loved one vs stranger or similar contrasts).
Emotional prosody comprehension is an auditory social-communication task (reception of non-facial communication). The emotional vs neutral contrast directly measures receptive social communication.
The contrast targets perception of others' emotions from voice rather than self-related judgments, self-evaluation, or self-other comparisons, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Emotional > neutral trials index representation and interpretation of others' emotional states (perception/understanding of others), satisfying the Perception_of_Others construct.

The complex>simple emotion contrast probes additional socio-cognitive processing (mPFC, premotor, insula, somatosensory regions) required to interpret complex/social emotions, clearly indexing social processing.
Although complex emotions can be social, the task contrasts complex vs simple emotion recognition and does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation comparisons).

The contrast isolates processes involved in decoding vocal emotional signals (reception of non-facial communication) with greater recruitment for complex emotions, meeting Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The subtraction identifies increased processing for complex emotions in regions linked to ToM and simulation of others, but does not involve judgments about the participant's own traits or self-related processing.
Complex>simple evokes mPFC and other regions associated with inferring mental states and understanding others, directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others (including Theory of Mind).

Controlling for pitch, the complex>simple (pitch-controlled) contrast still reveals mPFC, premotor and insula activations linked to socio-cognitive processing of complex emotions, consistent with Social Processing.
The contrast controls for acoustic confounds but remains an emotion-recognition contrast; it does not assess affiliation/attachment processes or relationship-specific comparisons.

Even after controlling for pitch, the contrast indexes enhanced decoding of vocal emotional content for complex emotions (reception of non-facial communication), satisfying Social Communication criteria.
The analysis isolates neural correlates of perceiving others' complex emotional states independent of pitch; it does not probe self-related judgments or self-awareness processes.
Pitch-controlled complex>simple continues to engage mPFC and related regions implicated in inferring others' mental states, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

No self-related judgments or self-perception measures are present; stimuli depict others’ motion.
Point-light biological motion is an explicit example of Perception and Understanding of Others (action/animacy perception); the contrast directly measures this construct.

The functional connectivity analysis examines regions engaged during biological motion perception (left Crus I seed), which is a social-related process (perception of others), so it reflects social processing.

Analysis investigates connectivity during biological motion perception rather than communication-specific signals (faces, gaze, emotional expression).

Contrast I(H+M) > C(H+M) isolates Stroop (incongruent vs congruent) executive/inhibition effects across both opponent types. Although performed in a social-competition context, this contrast does not specifically measure social processing or distinguish human vs. machine interaction (does not isolate ToM or other social processes).
The contrast measures conflict resolution (Stroop) independent of opponent type and does not specifically index affiliation/attachment, cooperation or competition differences.
This contrast does not target social communication constructs (faces, gaze, emotion recognition or communicative exchanges); it isolates executive Stroop processes.
The contrast reflects general inhibitory control (Stroop) rather than explicit self-related processing (self-judgment, self > other contrasts or agency judgments).

Although the task was carried out in a social competition context, this main Stroop contrast does not isolate perception/understanding of others (Theory of Mind) because it collapses across Human and Machine conditions.
Contrast C(H+M) > I(H+M) isolates Congruent > Incongruent Stroop (control > Stroop) and does not measure social processing specifically; it collapses across opponent types.
This contrast reflects Stroop control-related activity and does not target affiliation/attachment or competition-related differences.
No measures of social communication (face/gaze/emotion processing or communicative exchange) are isolated by this contrast.
Contrast reflects task control processes, not self-specific judgments or agency contrasts.
This contrast does not distinguish processing about others (ToM) because it collapses across Human and Machine conditions.

Contrast H(I+C) > M(I+C) directly compares human vs. machine competition and therefore isolates social processing related to human–human interaction (ToM/social context). The task explicitly manipulates social competitor type and instructions encourage mentalizing in the Human condition.

This contrast operationalizes competition between a human and a machine; competition is explicitly an affiliation/attachment-relevant social interaction (inclusion criterion I1: competition tasks), so the contrast measures aspects of social comparison/competition.

Although the contrast probes social interaction type, it does not specifically measure social communication constructs such as face/gaze processing, communicative exchanges, or affect recognition; the paradigm focuses on mentalizing/competition rather than communicative signal processing.

The contrast targets social interaction (human vs machine) and ToM-related processing rather than explicit self-judgments or self > other contrasts; self-specific processes are not the main measured construct.

This contrast is a direct test of human–human vs. human–machine interaction (designed to index Theory of Mind/understanding others' intentions). It therefore meets criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others (ToM).

Contrast M(I+C) > H(I+C) is a direct social manipulation contrast (machine vs human opponent). Even though the paper reports no suprathreshold activation for this direction, the contrast is designed to measure social-processing differences between opponent types.
The contrast compares competition with a machine versus a human; it probes competition/affiliation-related processing (competition is specified in inclusion criterion I1).
The task contrast does not target social communication per se (faces/gaze/emotion or communicative exchange) and instead probes differences in social context/ToM related processing.
This contrast focuses on the social competitor type rather than explicit self-related judgments or agency contrasts; it does not operationalize self-perception measures.

The contrast directly addresses perception/understanding of others by contrasting human vs machine opponents (designed to elicit ToM-related processes), satisfying the Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.

Interaction [H(I>C)] > [M(I>C)] isolates executive (Stroop) activity that is specifically modulated by human (vs machine) competition — directly indexing social-processing modulation (ToM in a competitive context).

This interaction specifically probes how competition with a human (vs machine) modulates executive processes; because it operationalizes competition between agents it meets the affiliation/attachment (competition/social comparison) inclusion criterion.
Although the interaction targets social modulation, it focuses on mentalizing/executive interactions rather than explicit social-communication constructs (faces, gaze, communicative signals).
The interaction addresses modulation of executive control by social (human) context and ToM, not explicit self-judgments or agency contrasts (no self > other manipulation).

This interaction was explicitly designed to find executive regions recruited when mentalizing about a human opponent (i.e., perception/understanding of others, ToM), so it meets criteria for perception/understanding of others.

Interaction [M(I>C)] > [H(I>C)] is a social-context contrast (machine vs human modulation of Stroop). Even though no suprathreshold voxels were reported, the contrast is designed to detect social-processing differences and thus counts as a social-processing analysis.
The contrast compares competitive contexts (machine vs human) and therefore pertains to competition/social-comparison processes relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast probes modulation by opponent type rather than communicative signal processing (faces/gaze/emotion); it does not operationalize social communication measures.
This contrast addresses social-context modulation of executive control and does not index explicit self-perception or self-judgment processes.

Even though the direction is machine > human, the interaction contrasts are intended to isolate processing related to opponent type and thus probe perception/understanding of others (ToM-related contrasts).

Contrast examines prosocial (costly donation to family) versus self-reward decisions, a social task probing social motives, mentalizing and self-control during interpersonal decisions. This directly measures social processing involved in understanding and responding to others (family).
Task targets helping one’s family (kinship/close-relationship context) and decisions to provide support to family members, which directly index affiliation and attachment-related processes.

The task does not involve exchange of communicative signals (facial, gaze, or vocal communication) or measures of receptive/expressive social communication; it is an economic/prosocial decision task rather than a communication task.

Although the contrast contrasts self-reward vs family reward, it does not probe self-judgment, self-reflection, or explicit self-knowledge processes (e.g., self>other evaluations) as required by the Perception/Self construct; primary focus is prosocial choice and self-control rather than self-evaluation.

The analysis specifically reports activation in mentalizing regions (DMPFC, TPJ, pSTS) during Costly-Donation decisions, implicating processes of understanding others’ needs/mental states consistent with Perception/Understanding of Others.

This analysis links individual differences in family-obligation preferences to neural recruitment during prosocial family decisions — a social construct assessing how people perceive/act toward others (family), thus measuring social processing.

The regressor is a measure of family obligation (support, respect, time with family). The analysis tests how affiliation/attachment values modulate neural responses during family-helping decisions, matching the Affiliation/Attachment construct.

The analysis concerns value-driven modulation of prosocial decision neural activity, not reception or production of communicative signals (faces, gaze, etc.), so it does not meet Social Communication criteria.

Although individual differences (family obligation) are used as a regressor, the contrast does not index self-reflection or explicit self-judgments (self-knowledge/agency) as defined for Perception/Self; it focuses on other-directed values and their neural correlates.

Results show that higher family-obligation scores relate to greater recruitment of mentalizing regions (TPJ, pSTS, DMPFC) during prosocial decisions, indicating enhanced perception/understanding of others’ perspectives/needs — matching Perception/Others.

PPI examines functional coupling between reward (ventral striatum) and self-control/mentalizing regions during prosocial family decisions and how this varies with family-obligation — a social-processing question about interpersonal decision mechanisms.

Connectivity that is modulated by family-obligation values during giving to family directly pertains to affiliation/attachment processes (kinship/close-relationship motivations), satisfying the construct.

PPI and connectivity here concern decision-related coupling (reward × mentalizing/self-control) rather than communicative signal processing (faces, gaze, vocalizations), so it does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The analysis addresses neural coupling underlying prosocial choices and how values modulate that coupling; it does not probe self-perception, self-judgment, or agency explicitly, so Perception/Self is not supported.

Significant PPI results (ventral striatum coupled with MPFC/DMPFC and VLPFC linked to mentalizing) in relation to family-obligation indicate enhanced interactions supporting understanding/valuing others’ needs — consistent with Perception/Understanding of Others.

Contrast directly isolates retrieval of social context ((rSS+rSO) - (rNS+rNO)); task involved collaborative social interaction and recognition of words learned in social vs solitary contexts, so this measures broad social processing.

The social context manipulation involved collaboration and forming a coherent story with a partner and discussion of social scripts and social reward in the paper; this targets affiliation/attachment-related processes (positive interaction, social bonding) during encoding/retrieval of socially learned items.

The social condition required interactive story generation and reciprocal communicative behavior (alternating generation and reading aloud), so the contrast probes social communication processes associated with collaboration and exchange of information.

This contrast isolates social context (social vs non-social) rather than self-related processing (self > other); although self may play a role in SS trials, the main contrast targets context and not self-perception/agency, so it does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

Retrieval of socially encoded items (including rSO trials where items were generated by another) involves representing others’ contributions/roles and inferring others’ actions in the social context, consistent with perception/understanding of others.

Contrast isolates self-generation retrieval ((rSS+rNS) - (rSO+rNO)); self-generation in a social experimental context still falls under social processing broadly (self vs other generation within social interaction), so it is included as social processing.

The self-generation contrast targets self-referential mnemonic processing and generation effects (left mPFC/MCC) rather than measures of affiliation, bonding, or cooperative/competitive relationship differences; it does not meet Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criteria.

Although encoding included communicative interaction, the self-generation contrast isolates self vs other source effects in memory (self-referential generation) rather than communication/perception of communicative signals (faces, gaze, expressive behavior); it therefore does not meet Social Communication inclusion criteria.

Contrast explicitly isolates self-generated vs other-generated retrieval and produced left mPFC and MCC activations consistent with self-referential/agency processes; this directly matches Perception/Understanding of Self inclusion criteria (self > other).

The contrast tests self-generation effects (self > other) rather than representing or inferring others’ mental states or actions per se (Theory of Mind/empathy); thus it does not meet the Perception/Others inclusion criteria.

Task involves processing humorous cartoons, social cognition, emotion perception, and mentalizing; authors explicitly discuss social aspects of humor and report TPJ/ToM and ACC involvement, so this is a social-processing task.
The study does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, cooperation/competition, or relationship/bonding tasks); cartoons and funniness ratings do not operationalize attachment.

Although cartoons convey social content, the task is not an explicit social-communication paradigm (e.g., face processing, gaze, or explicit communicative exchange); authors focus on emotion, appraisal, and ToM rather than message exchange or facial communication.
The paradigm does not probe self-related judgments or self-referential processing (no self>other contrasts, no viewing of self, no agency/self-knowledge measures).

Cartoon comprehension and humor appreciation engage theory-of-mind and understanding of others' mental states; authors explicitly link TPJ and ToM and discuss mentalizing contributions to humor processing, meeting perception-of-others criteria.

Parametric modulation relates subjective funniness to brain activation during processing of humorous cartoons—a social-cognitive, affective task involving appraisal and mentalizing; authors frame humor as social and report joint activations in social-cognition regions.
The parametric analysis links funniness ratings to activation but does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding, kinship, cooperation contrasts).

Although affect recognition and social cue processing are involved, the parametric modulation is focused on amusement ratings, not explicit social-communication tasks (no face/gaze/expressive production or reception paradigms).
Parametric modulation relates to subjective experience, but it does not measure self-judgment or self-related trait/agency contrasts as defined by the Perception_Self construct.

Authors report recruitment of ToM-related regions (TPJ, precuneus, ACC) and discuss mentalizing/understanding others' intentions as part of humor processing; CPM captures affective responses linked to perceiving others’ states, satisfying the perception_others inclusion criteria.

The task involves perceiving communicative, gesture-based interactions (point-light displays conveying social intentions and communicative acts). This fits Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication) and matches the inclusion criteria.

The task assesses perception/understanding of others' actions and intentions, not self-related processing (no self-judgment, self-viewing, or agency/self-knowledge contrasts), so it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion criteria.

The experiment uses point-light biological motion to assess perception and understanding of others' intentions and actions (explicit example in inclusion criteria). The Preference task explicitly asks subjects to judge whether they like a presented face (social preference). This is a social-related task probing social information processing and thus meets I1.

The Preference task measures interpersonal liking ("Do I like this person?"), an affiliation-related judgment about social bonds/positive social evaluation. Although not a formal attachment paradigm, it assesses affiliation/liking and therefore meets the inclusion criterion.

The task involves viewing faces and responding to socially meaningful facial stimuli (receptive facial communication). This fits the Social Communication inclusion examples (viewing faces, affect recognition).
Preference judgments are self-referential (subjects report their own liking) and constitute self-judgment processes; thus the analysis measures Perception/Understanding of Self (I1).
Although the task is self-referential, it requires perceiving and evaluating another person’s face and traits; it therefore involves Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).
The Gender (control) task involves face perception and social information (identifying another person's gender), therefore it is a social-related task and meets I1.

The Gender task requires perceptual identification (male/female) but does not measure affiliation, attachment, or interpersonal liking/bonding. It does not meet the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion examples.
Gender identification uses facial stimuli and face-processing mechanisms (receptive facial communication), matching the Social Communication inclusion examples (viewing faces).

The Gender task does not require self-referential judgments or accessing knowledge about the self; it is an other-focused perceptual decision and therefore does not meet the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Gender identification involves perceiving attributes of other individuals (faces) and thus fits Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).
The Preference>Gender contrast isolates neural processes of social preference (liking others) and therefore measures social processing (I1).

This contrast specifically highlights brain activity related to interpersonal liking (Preference relative to Gender), directly indexing affiliation-related evaluation and meeting the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion.
Preference>Gender isolates processing of socially meaningful facial information and evaluative reception of faces, consistent with Social Communication inclusion examples.
The contrast emphasizes self-referential evaluative processing ("Do I like this person?") relative to a non-self referential task, satisfying the Perception/Self inclusion criterion.
Preference>Gender reflects evaluation of others' faces and attributes (assessing likeability), thus engaging Perception/Understanding of Others and meeting I1.
The Gender>Preference contrast still concerns social stimuli (faces) and differences in processing of social information (greater activity for Gender), so it remains within social processing.

Gender>Preference highlights regions more active for gender identification versus preference and does not index affiliation/attachment or interpersonal bonding/liking; it does not meet the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion.
The contrast emphasizes face-processing and related social perceptual processing (e.g., TPJ, STG), consistent with Social Communication (receptive face processing).
Gender>Preference reflects externally focused perceptual processing (gender identification) rather than self-referential judgment, so it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion.
Gender>Preference concerns perceiving attributes of other people (gender) and activates regions implicated in processing others, thus meeting Perception/Understanding of Others.
The aMFC PPI analysis examines task-dependent functional coupling during the social preference task (Preference vs Gender), addressing network mechanisms of social processing and meeting I1.

The aMFC PPI probes connectivity changes specifically associated with social preference (liking), which indexes affiliation-related evaluative processes; thus it meets the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion.

This connectivity analysis examines interactions among regions engaged while processing faces and social evaluative information (receptive facial communication), aligning with Social Communication inclusion criteria.
aMFC seed PPI assesses connectivity changes during a self-referential preference judgment, implicating self-related processing and satisfying Perception/Self inclusion.
The aMFC connectivity patterns reflect interactions while evaluating others' faces (assessing likeability), and thus involve Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).
The vMFC PPI analysis tests task-dependent coupling during social preference, directly concerning social processing and meeting I1.

vMFC PPI probes mechanisms underlying evaluative processing of liking (affiliation-related appraisal); although vMFC is rapid appraisal rather than attachment per se, the analysis indexes affiliation/liking processes and meets I1.
vMFC connectivity during face evaluation involves processing socially relevant facial information (receptive facial communication), consistent with Social Communication inclusion.
vMFC is implicated in stimulus valuation and the PPI examines changes during self-referential liking judgments, thereby engaging Perception/Self processes.
vMFC PPI captures how the brain evaluates other persons' faces (valuative processing of others), thus involving Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).
The PCC PPI analysis examines network interactions during the social preference task, addressing mechanisms of social processing and meeting I1.

PCC connectivity changes were examined in relation to social preference (liking), which indexes affiliation-related evaluative processes; thus the analysis meets the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion.
PCC PPI assesses interactions among regions engaged in evaluating faces and social information, consistent with Social Communication (receptive facial processing).
PCC is implicated in autobiographical/temporal integration and the PPI assesses its role during self-referential preference judgments, satisfying Perception/Self inclusion.
PCC connectivity during Preference reflects processes involved in evaluating others and integrating information about them, thus meeting Perception/Understanding of Others (I1).

The analysis reports the main effect of painful vs. neutral stimuli within an empathy-for-pain paradigm that manipulates perspective (Self, Loved-one, Stranger). The task is explicitly social (empathy, perspective-taking, relationships) and the contrast indexes social processing related to perceiving others in pain and associated affective responses. Thus it meets I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures social processing).

Although the overall study manipulates affiliation (Loved-one vs. Stranger), this specific analysis is the main effect of pain across all perspectives (Pain > Neutral) and does not directly test affiliation/attachment contrasts (e.g., Loved-one vs Stranger). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring the analysis/contrast to measure affiliation/attachment.

The stimuli are animated images of hands/feet in painful vs. neutral situations and the contrast indexes pain-related neural responses. The task does not involve facial or communicative signals or explicit reception/production of social communicative behavior as defined by the social_communication construct, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Perception_self requires analyses that measure self-related processing (e.g., Self > Other or explicit self-judgment). This contrast is the main effect of pain irrespective of perspective and is not a Self > Other comparison or an explicit self-judgment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for self-specific processing.

The paradigm assesses empathy for pain and the Pain > Neutral contrast captures neural responses to perceived pain in others (participants were instructed to imagine targets in pain), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (empathy-related processing). Although the contrast is across perspectives (including Self), the task is centered on perceiving others' pain and thus meets I1 and I2 for this construct.
