Experiment 1 Live>Recorded contrasts a live, contingent social interaction with recorded playback, directly measuring neural correlates of social interaction and social processing (social cognition, reward, attention).
The Live vs Recorded task involves cooperative games and elicits reward-related regions (ventral striatum, amygdala, ACC), consistent with affiliation/attachment and social bonding processes.
The task requires reciprocal, face-to-face communication (gaze, instructions, showing/matching events), matching the social communication construct (receptive and productive aspects).
Contrasts probe responses to another person (live vs recorded) and social contingency, not explicit self-related judgments, self-reference, or agency tasks (no Self>Other contrasts).
Live>Recorded engages regions (rpSTS, rTPJ) implicated in perceiving and reasoning about others’ actions and intentions, directly targeting perception/understanding of others.
Recorded>Live arises from the same social interaction paradigm (recorded vs live) and thus reflects contrasts within a social-processing task, even if the peak activations are motor regions.

Although this contrast shows greater motor activity for recorded playback, it is derived from a cooperative social interaction paradigm; the task probes affiliation-related contexts (cooperative games), satisfying the criterion.

The underlying paradigm involves face-to-face communicative episodes (showing, matching); the Recorded>Live contrast still indexes differences in social-communication contexts (albeit showing stronger non-social motor responses).
This contrast does not involve explicit self-related judgments or self-monitoring measures; it contrasts modes of social presentation rather than self vs other processing.

The contrast is embedded in a task that manipulates the social relevance of another person's actions; thus it pertains to perception/understanding of others even if the observed effect favors motor regions for the recorded condition.
Experiment 2 Joint Attention>Solo Attention directly manipulates a core social interaction component (joint attention), measuring social cognitive processing during live interaction.
The joint attention game is cooperative (Catch the Mouse) requiring coordination with another person; this cooperative/affiliative context maps onto affiliation/attachment processes.
Joint attention and gaze-following are prototypical social communication behaviors (production and reception of gaze cues); contrast explicitly isolates gaze-based communication.
The JA>SA contrast isolates responses to others’ gaze and joint action, not self-referential judgments or self-monitoring; no Self tasks are present.
Joint attention requires representing and using another's gaze/intentions; observed rpSTS and rTPJ activations reflect perception and understanding of others' actions and mental states.
Solo>Joint Attention is part of the same social interaction task and reflects contrasts in social processing (differences when the partner is present but not coordinating attention).
Although Solo Attention is the non-cooperative control, the paradigm as a whole involves cooperative games and social contexts; this contrast is derived from that affiliation-relevant task.

Solo Attention still engages social-communicative elements (visible partner, eye movements) and is contrasted with Joint Attention to index communication-related processes; thus it meets the criterion.
The Solo>Joint contrast does not probe self-specific judgments or agency; it manipulates whether attention is coordinated with another, not self-reflection.

Even the Solo Attention condition involves perceiving another person (experimenter present but not sharing attention); contrasts probe how perception of the other and their gaze relates to task performance, fitting the construct.

The study investigates joint attention and content attribution (theory of mind) rather than affiliation/attachment, cooperation, kinship, or relationship-related processes. The contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment constructs.

The paradigm explicitly uses gaze following and joint attention (seeing where the avatar looks), which are core aspects of social communication (production/reception of gaze). The Places > Bodies contrast arises from this gaze-based communicative scenario.
The task does not probe self-related judgments, self-referential processing, or agency/self-knowledge. Contrasts compare contents attributed to another person, not self vs other.

The experiment specifically tests representation of another's mental content (what the avatar is seeing) and engages theory-of-mind/social cognition regions; thus the Places > Bodies contrast measures perception and understanding of others' mental states.
The Bodies > Places contrast is derived from the same joint-attention/theory-of-mind task and indexes social processing related to attributing content to another's mind (seeing a body vs a place).

The contrast reflects differences in content attribution (body vs place) and joint attention, not affiliation or attachment processes such as kinship, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger comparisons.
Bodies > Places arises from gaze-following and joint-attention behavior (avatar looking at occluded stimuli), which are key social communication processes (gaze perception and following).
The task contrasts concern representation of another agent's view and do not involve self-referential judgments or self-related processing.

The Bodies > Places contrast directly assesses neural responses when attributing specific content to another person's visual experience (theory of mind/understanding mental states), meeting the perception-of-others construct.

Contrast probes perception/understanding of others' emotions and social context rather than self-related processing or self-judgment. Does not meet I1 for perception_self.
Emotional > Neutral directly taps perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy, mentalizing), matching I1 for perception_others.
Neutral > Emotional uses the same social stimuli set (people in scenes) and therefore still indexes social processing (differences in response to social content). Meets I1.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship, close-relationship, cooperation comparisons), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.

Even though the contrast emphasizes neutral over emotional scenes, the stimuli require decoding social cues from body/posture/context (reception of non-facial communication). This satisfies I1 for social_communication.
No task element requiring self-reflection, self-judgment, or viewing of the self; contrast assesses responses to others, so does not meet perception_self criteria.
The contrast contrasts social stimuli (neutral vs emotional), continuing to probe perception/understanding of others (emotional attribution, mentalizing). This meets I1 for perception_others.
Contrast Social relation (two persons) > Single person explicitly probes social interaction/relations and engages social cognitive processes (mentalizing, STS/mPFC activations). Meets I1.

Although two-person stimuli show social relations, the contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.
Viewing interactions between two people requires processing communicative and social cues (reception of non-facial/bodily social signals), matching I1 for social_communication.
Contrast targets perception of others and social relations rather than self-related judgments or self-referential processing. Does not meet perception_self I1.
Social relation > single person directly assesses understanding others and their relations/intentions (mentalizing, action/animacy perception). This fits I1 for perception_others.

The contrast (movie scenes ToM > PI) uses MASC naturalistic social videos to probe theory-of-mind/mentalizing during dynamic social scenes, which directly measures broad social processing.

The MASC stimuli depict interpersonal situations (friendship/dating dinner party) and the movie-scene contrast isolates social inference in those relationship contexts, consistent with affiliation/attachment-related social content.

The movie scenes involve audiovisual social cues (faces, expressions, speech) and the contrast targets implicit social message decoding (face/gaze/STS/FFA engagement reported), matching social-communication (receptive) processes.

The movie-scene GLM contrast probes implicit perception of others' mental states rather than self-related judgments; although precuneus appears at an uncorrected threshold, there is no clear dmPFC/self-judgment signature in this specific contrast, so it does not meet criteria for Perception/Self.
This contrast directly targets understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind) during movie viewing, matching the Perception/Understanding of Others construct.
Silent-answer ToM > PI probes explicit mental-state reasoning in the social MASC task, clearly measuring broad social processing.
The explicit silent-answer condition asks about characters' thoughts/feelings in interpersonal scenarios (friendship/dating), which taps affiliation/attachment-related social inferences.

Silent-answer mode requires comprehension and internal processing of social communicative content (verbal/visual cues); observed recruitment of STS/IFG supports classification under social communication reception.

The GLM silent-answer contrast shows dorsomedial PFC and precuneus engagement (reported), regions commonly linked to self-referential processing and simulation-based mentalizing, satisfying Perception/Self inclusion.
Silent-answer ToM > PI explicitly requires reasoning about others' mental states (ToM) and activates canonical regions for understanding others, meeting Perception/Others criteria.
MC-answer ToM > PI assesses explicit mental-state reasoning with overt responses in social contexts, directly indexing broad social processing.
The MC-answer items probe characters' mental states within interpersonal (friendship/dating) scenarios; these are relationship-relevant inferences consistent with affiliation/attachment processing.
MC-answer mode engages language and face/STS systems (reported IFG, STS activations) and requires comprehension/selection of socially relevant communicative content, matching Social Communication.

MC-answer ToM > PI robustly recruited dmPFC and precuneus (authors report), regions linked to self-referential / simulation processes used in attributing mental states, meeting Perception/Self criteria.
This contrast explicitly contrasts mental-state reasoning about others versus physical inference, directly indexing Perception/Understanding of Others (Theory of Mind).

IC1 (T-PICA) is a task-related network during ToM that includes STS, TPJ, temporal poles, PCC/precuneus and occipito-temporal/FFA — a canonical social-cognitive network, indexing broad social processing.

IC1 reflects person/face-processing and retrieval of person knowledge during socially rich movie scenes (MASC), which supports inference about interpersonal relationships and affiliation-relevant cues present in the stimuli.
IC1 includes core face-processing and STS regions (FFA, occipito-temporal, STS) linked to reception of facial communication and dynamic social cues, meeting Social Communication inclusion.

IC1 is best characterized as a face/person-recognition and perceptual-social network (core + extended face system); it does not specifically index self-referential processing (dmPFC) and so does not meet Perception/Self criteria for this component.

IC1 is time-locked to ToM movie events and comprises regions (STS, TPJ, temporal poles, FFA) central to representing others' faces, actions and mental states, thus satisfying Perception/Others criteria.
IC2 (T-PICA) comprises STS, temporal poles, IFG and precuneus and is task-related during ToM, reflecting a distributed social-cognitive network and broad social processing.

IC2 reflects language/semantic systems engaged when reasoning about characters in interpersonal contexts; these processes support interpretation of relationship-relevant content in the MASC scenes and thus relate to affiliation/attachment content.

IC2 includes classical language and comprehension regions (STS, IFG) and was differentially engaged during explicit ToM MC answers, matching Social Communication (receptive language/semantic processing of social content).

IC2 is dominated by language/STS/temporal-lobe circuitry and does not show a primary dmPFC/precuneus self-referential signature; therefore it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion for this component.

IC2 activity is tied to explicit ToM processing (comprehension of characters' mental states) and involves regions implicated in representing others' mental/semantic content, satisfying Perception/Others criteria.
IC3 (T-PICA) is a ToM-related component including dmPFC and precuneus and is implicated in mental-state attribution, indexing broad social processing.

IC3 reflects higher-level social-cognitive processes (dmPFC/precuneus) engaged when reasoning about characters and their relationships in the MASC stimuli; these processes are relevant to understanding interpersonal/affiliative dynamics in the task.

IC3 is primarily a self-referential / higher-level mentalizing network (dmPFC, precuneus) rather than a network for reception/production of social communicative signals (faces/voice/IFG language); it therefore does not meet Social Communication inclusion for this component.
IC3 includes dorsomedial PFC and precuneus and was interpreted by the authors as reflecting self-referential mental activity used in simulative mentalizing, meeting Perception/Self inclusion.
IC3 is engaged during ToM modes and supports attribution/simulation processes used to infer others' mental states (dmPFC-mediated), thus matching Perception/Understanding of Others.

The contrast Pain > No Pain was derived from an event-related fMRI task that manipulated perception of others in painful vs non-painful situations within a social-context experiment. This is a social-related task probing neural responses to others' pain and thus measures social processing.

The contrast measures neural responses to observed pain (empathy) rather than processes of affiliation, bonding, cooperation or attachment. The task does not assess attachment-related constructs (e.g., loved one vs stranger).

Although stimuli are social scenes, this contrast isolates pain-related processing (pain vs no pain) rather than explicit social-communication exchanges (e.g., facial/expressive communication, gaze, or communicative signals).
This contrast targets perceiving pain (affective and sensory components) rather than processes of self-perception or agency (no Self>Other manipulation here).

Pain > No Pain directly indexes perception and understanding of others' pain (empathy). The contrast identifies canonical ‘pain matrix’ responses while observing another in pain, meeting the construct’s criteria.
No Pain > Pain is derived from the same task with social stimuli (presence/absence of others). Even inverse contrasts come from a social perception task and thus belong under broad social processing.
This contrast does not tap affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation or close-relationship comparisons).

The contrast identifies regions more active for non-painful scenes than painful ones; it does not explicitly probe communicative reception/production (e.g., facial or gaze processing) as defined by the social_communication construct.
No Pain > Pain does not measure self-related perception or agency (no Self>Other manipulation).

This inverse contrast does not meaningfully index perception/understanding of others’ emotional states; it isolates greater response to non-painful scenes and thus does not meet the construct’s intent.
Self+Other > Self directly tests the effect of the presence of another individual (social context) on neural responses. This is a social-related manipulation and thus meets social processing.
The contrast probes presence of another person / agency, not affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, cooperation or loved-one comparisons).

This contrast isolates brain responses to the presence of another agent (TPJ, STS, temporal pole, mPFC) which index processing of social cues and interpretation of actions/intentionality—functions consistent with social communication (reception of non-facial communication/biological motion).
The contrast emphasizes trials with another person present (Self+Other > Self), so it does not index self-perception or agency per se.
Self+Other > Self specifically measures perception and understanding of others (detection of another agent, intentionality, mentalizing) and therefore meets the perception_others criteria.
The Self > Self+Other contrast is part of the same social-context design and hence falls under broad social processing (manipulation of social presence/agency).
This contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation comparisons).
Self > Self+Other contrasts emphasize self-related processing rather than reception/production of social communicative signals; it is not primarily a social-communication contrast.
Self > Self+Other directly contrasts self-only trials vs trials with another present and thus indexes self-related perception/agency (matches the example Self > Other).
This contrast favors self-only trials and therefore does not index perception/understanding of others’ mental states or actions.

The PPI contrast PCO > PCS tests task-dependent connectivity modulated by whether pain was caused by another person versus by accident (agency/social context). This probes social-contextual modulation of neural circuits and thus is social processing.
The PPI assesses connectivity differences related to perceived agency/intentional harm, not affiliation/attachment processes.

PCO > PCS isolates connectivity when pain is intentionally inflicted by another—this involves processing of social interaction cues and intentionality (biological motion/agentive signals), which map onto social-communication reception (non-facial cues).
PCO > PCS emphasizes others-caused pain (Other > Self). It does not index self-related perception or an explicit Self > Other contrast, so it does not meet the perception_self inclusion example.

This PPI examines how left amygdala coupling is modulated when observing another person intentionally harming someone (perception/understanding of others’ actions and intent). It directly addresses perception_others (mentalizing/empathy for others).
PCS > PCO PPI tests connectivity when pain was caused by accident (self) versus intentionally by another; this contrast arises from a social-context task and therefore falls under social processing.
This contrast compares agency contexts and connectivity, not affiliation/attachment constructs such as bonding or cooperation.

Although PCS > PCO emphasizes self-caused pain, it still probes social-contextual modulation of communication-related networks (connectivity of amygdala with ACC/SMA/insula) and reflects processing of social/affective signals tied to observed actions; thus it is reasonably classified under social_communication (reception of non-facial social cues/biological motion).

PCS > PCO contrasts emphasize the self-caused condition (agentive difference favoring self), indexing processes related to self/agency and matching the perception_self construct (examples include Self > Other contrasts).
This contrast highlights stronger coupling during self-caused pain and therefore does not primarily index perception/understanding of others’ mental states (it is the reverse-agentive condition).

This correlation links individual differences in emotional contagion (a social trait) to brain responses during the task (here labelled as during PCS trials). The analysis evaluates social susceptibility within a social-context experiment, satisfying social processing.
Emotional contagion scores index susceptibility to others' emotions, not attachment/affiliation per se; the analysis does not measure bonding or close-relationship constructs.

Emotional contagion relates to reception of affective signals from others (a receptive social-communication process). Correlating EC with neural responses implies modulation of social-communicative perception (e.g., affect recognition, vicarious emotional processing).
This correlation addresses trait susceptibility to others' emotions and its relationship to observed stimuli; it does not directly probe self-judgment or agency.

Emotional contagion is a dispositional measure of empathy for others; correlating it with brain responses to observed pain directly indexes perception/understanding of others and meets the construct criteria.

This analysis correlates participants' pain ratings with brain responses (during PCS trials per label) in a social-context empathy task, linking subjective perception of others’ pain to neural activity and therefore fits social processing.
Pain rating correlations target perceived pain intensity/empathy rather than measures of affiliation or bonding.
While ratings index affective evaluation, this analysis does not directly probe communicative exchange (facial/gaze/expressive communication) as defined by the social_communication construct.
This correlation links subjective ratings of observed pain to neural responses; it does not target self-related agency or self-knowledge processes.

Correlating pain ratings (subjective evaluation of others' pain) with brain activity directly indexes perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy), satisfying the perception_others inclusion.

This correlation links emotional contagion scores with brain responses during PCO trials (others-caused pain). It evaluates trait-level social susceptibility within an intentional-harm social context, and thus is a social-processing analysis.
Although emotional contagion is social, this analysis does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.

Emotional contagion represents receptive affective processing (recognition/ resonance with others' emotions). Correlating EC with neural responses during PCO trials implicates social-communication reception mechanisms.
This analysis examines trait sensitivity to others' emotions in response to others-caused pain and does not probe self-judgment or agency processes.
EC correlations with brain activity during PCO trials directly address sensitivity to others' affective states and thus index perception and understanding of others (empathy/theory-of-mind related).

This analysis correlates subjective pain ratings during PCO trials (others-inflicted pain) with brain responses, linking subjective perception of others' suffering to neural activity — a social processing measure.
Pain-rating correlations concern perceived pain/empathy and not affiliation or attachment measures.

While ratings reflect affective evaluation, this analysis does not directly probe communicative signal reception/production (faces, gaze, explicit communicative acts) as defined by social_communication.
The analysis links ratings of others' pain (PCO) to neural responses and does not probe self-related perception/agency (no Self>Other contrast).

Correlating subjective pain ratings for others-inflicted pain with hemodynamic responses directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (empathy), meeting the construct criteria.

Task presents facial emotional expressions (social stimuli) and measures neural responses; thus this analysis assesses social processing broadly.
This contrast reports main effect of masked sad vs neutral faces but does not test or quantify attachment/affiliation (no attachment-variable correlation in this specific contrast).
Analysis involves viewing facial expressions (receptive facial communication), which meets the Social Communication inclusion criteria.
Task does not involve self-judgment, self-related processing, or viewing the self; thus it does not measure Perception/Self.
Contrast measures perception of others' emotional expressions (representations of others' states), meeting Perception/Others criteria.
Masked happy vs neutral faces contrast uses social stimuli (faces) and measures social information processing.
This main effect contrast does not directly test attachment/affiliation constructs or relate activation to attachment measures.
Viewing facial expressions (happy faces) is a prototypical social communication receptive task, so this contrast meets the criterion.
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are involved, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
Contrast reflects perception of others' emotional states (others' facial expressions), satisfying Perception/Others inclusion.
This analysis correlates attachment avoidance with neural responses to masked sad faces, directly addressing social information processing differences.
This analysis explicitly tests relationships between brain activation and attachment-related avoidance (RSQ), meeting the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criteria.
The contrast involves perception of facial emotional expressions (receptive facial communication) and how it varies with attachment, meeting Social Communication criteria.
The analysis examines responses to others' faces and correlations with attachment trait; it does not measure self-referential processing.
Analysis investigates neural representation of others' emotional states (responses to others' sad faces) and individual differences in perceiving others, satisfying Perception/Others.
This analysis correlates attachment avoidance with brain responses to masked happy faces, thus probing social processing mechanisms.
This analysis directly examines associations between RSQ attachment avoidance and neural responses to social (happy) faces, meeting Affiliation/Attachment criteria.
Task involves receptive processing of facial expressions (happy faces) and how it varies with attachment, fitting Social Communication inclusion criteria.
No measures of self-perception or self-referential judgment are included in this analysis.
This analysis assesses perception of others' emotions (happy faces) and individual differences in these perceptions, matching Perception/Others criteria.
Negative correlations of attachment avoidance with brain responses to masked happy faces still probe social processing and individual differences in social-emotional response.
This analysis reports correlations between attachment avoidance and neural responses (negative correlations), directly addressing affiliation/attachment constructs.
Examines reception of facial emotional cues (happy faces) and their modulation by attachment, meeting Social Communication criteria.
No self-related processing or judgments are assessed in this analysis.
Addresses perception/understanding of others' emotional states (responses to happy faces) and individual differences, fitting Perception/Others inclusion.

Task involved viewing eye stimuli and dynamic pupillary interaction between observer and observed, directly probing social information processing and social salience. Analysis measures social processing of cues (eyes, pupillary coherence).
Study manipulated pupillary coherence and social salience but did not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts or attachment measures).
Participants viewed eye-region stimuli and dynamic pupil changes (receptive facial communication, eye signals); analysis directly probes reception of facial communication.

Although participants' own pupil dynamics were measured and used for biofeedback, the task did not explicitly measure self-awareness, self-judgment, or other self-referential processing as defined by the criterion (no explicit self vs other contrasts).
Analyses focused on perceiving and interpreting another's autonomic signal (pupil size) and how it signals others' dispositional state, directly addressing perception/understanding of others.
ROI/main-effect analysis examines neural responses to dynamic pupillary signals in a social context (eyes), thus measuring social processing.
ROI analysis does not target affiliation/attachment constructs or related contrasts (no cooperation, kinship, loved-one vs stranger).
ROI analysis targets regions (FFA, STS, amygdala, insula) engaged by facial/eye-based communication and responses to observed pupil changes, meeting reception of facial communication criteria.
ROI analysis includes observer pupil variance as a regressor but does not operationalize explicit self-perception or self-referential judgment per inclusion examples.
ROI analysis examines brain correlates of perceiving another's pupil dynamics and incoherence (inferring dispositional state), satisfying perception-of-others criteria.
Interaction and contrasts in the reported analyses concern dynamic social signals (eyes/pupils) and their neural processing, fitting broad social processing.
This analysis does not operationalize affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts; it focuses on salience and coherence rather than bonding or attachment.
Analysis examines reception of facial/eye communication (dynamic pupil changes, coherence/incoherence), matching social communication inclusion criteria.
Although observer pupil changes are modeled, the contrasts do not probe self-related judgment or explicit self-awareness, so do not meet perception_self criteria.
Contrasts (e.g., negative>positive feedback) probe inference about another's dispositional state from their pupil behavior, directly addressing perception and understanding of others.
Interaction analysis directly examines neural responses to coherent vs. incoherent social autonomic signals (eyes/pupils), reflecting social processing.
Interaction specifically probes salience and prediction errors in pupillary signals rather than measures of affiliation or attachment.
Interaction (positive vs negative feedback) concerns receptive aspects of facial communication (eye region dynamics) and their neural encoding, matching social communication criteria.
Although the interaction uses observer pupil data, it does not test explicit self-related perception or self-knowledge processes required for this annotation.
The interaction contrast (incoherent > coherent) identifies regions responding to unexpected changes in another's autonomic signal, addressing perception/understanding of others' internal state.

Contrast STEP1+STEP2 vs REST presents footstep sounds conveying social information (one vs two walkers) and measures brain responses to socially relevant auditory scenes; thus it assesses general social processing.
The task contrasts presence of footsteps vs rest and does not probe affiliation, bonding, kinship, cooperation or attachment-related constructs.
Auditory stimuli (footstep sounds) convey socially relevant information (number of walkers, identity cues); this matches Social Communication (receptive non-facial auditory social cues).
No self-related task or contrasts (no self-judgment, self vs other, or viewing self) are present.

Listening to footsteps of one or two people engages perception/action representation of others (biological motion/STSp) and inferring others' identity/intentions, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast NOISE1+NOISE2 vs REST is part of the experimental manipulation controlling auditory stimuli; although noise is non-social, it is used within a social-processing experiment and the contrast characterizes auditory processing in the social task context.
This contrast uses matched noise controls and does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs.
NOISE1+NOISE2 are non-social control sounds; the contrast vs REST does not measure reception of social communication (it is a non-social auditory baseline).
No self-related processing is measured by noise vs rest.
Noise bursts do not convey information about other agents (animacy, action perception, or mental states), so this contrast does not index perception/understanding of others.

The contrast (STEP2 - NOISE2) - (STEP1 - NOISE1) is explicitly designed to isolate social differences between two-person vs one-person walking after noise subtraction, targeting social-processing differences between conditions.
Although this contrast targets social complexity, it does not operationalize affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, cooperation, or kinship).
This enhanced contrast isolates differences in processing socially informative auditory cues (two vs one walker) and thus indexes reception of non-facial social communication in the auditory domain.
The contrast compares different external social auditory scenes and does not involve self-related judgments or self vs other comparisons.

The contrast aims to reveal neural responses to multiple agents vs a single agent, implicating animacy/action perception and mentalizing about others, consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
STEP1 - NOISE1 isolates brain responses to single-person footstep sounds versus matched noise, directly measuring social auditory processing of an individual agent.
This contrast examines single-walker perception versus noise and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.
The contrast evaluates receptive auditory social cues (footsteps conveying identity/gender/motion), matching Social Communication (reception of non-facial auditory social information).
No self-referential processing is assessed in this contrast.
STEP1 - NOISE1 probes perception of another agent's action (biological motion/STSp, amygdala responses), consistent with Perception and Understanding of Others.
STEP2 - NOISE2 isolates neural responses to two-person footstep sounds versus matched noise, directly assessing processing of a social scene involving multiple agents.
Although STEP2 involves multiple agents, the contrast does not operationalize affiliation, bonding, cooperation, or attachment-related behavior.
Two-person walking sounds provide richer socially communicative auditory cues (interpersonal dynamics, identity cues); this contrast measures reception of non-facial social communication.
No tasks or contrasts relate to self-perception or self-knowledge.

STEP2 - NOISE2 taps perception and representation of multiple other agents (temporal pole, subcallosal, amygdala activations linked to mentalizing and socio-emotional processing), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
Contrast STEP2 - STEP1 compares two-person vs one-person footstep sounds, directly addressing social complexity and processing differences between group vs single-agent auditory scenes.
Although it compares one vs two people, the contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding, cooperation, or kinship.

Comparing two vs one walker examines differences in processing socially informative auditory cues (group dynamics, identity cues), consistent with Social Communication (reception of non-facial auditory social information).
No measures of self-related cognition or self vs other comparisons are present in this contrast.

STEP2 - STEP1 targets neural differences in perceiving multiple agents vs a single agent (mentalizing about intentions, animacy/action perception), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast directly compares observation of social interactions versus individual actions, which is a canonical social-processing task engaging interpretation of others' behavior and social cues (dMPFC, IFG, pSTS). This matches Social Processing inclusion criteria.

The 'social' stimuli depict cooperative/interactive behaviors (e.g., passing objects, shared actions) that index affiliation/attachment-related processes (formation/recognition of social bonds and cooperative interactions). The contrast (Social > Individual) assesses these social-bonding/affiliative interactions.

Observing interactions between agents involves exchange of socially relevant information (gaze, action-directedness, inferred intentions). The task engages receptive social communication processes (interpreting actors' actions and communicative intent).

The task requires observing others and inferring relations between agents; it does not involve self-referential judgments, self-monitoring, or viewing the self. Thus Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The contrast targets representations of others' actions and social relations (triadic interactions), recruiting brain regions implicated in understanding others (dMPFC, pSTS, precuneus). This fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The main effect of gaze isolates a core social cue (gaze present vs masked). Gaze is central to social information processing and modulates interpretation of others' actions, meeting Social Processing criteria.

The gaze main effect contrasts presence vs absence of gaze across both social and individual actions; it indexes sensitivity to a social cue rather than measurement of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation vs stranger). The task does not specifically assess affiliation or bond-related judgments.

Gaze direction/availability is a prototypical social-communication signal (eye contact, gaze following). The contrast directly measures responses to gaze cues (GAZE vs NO-GAZE), matching Social Communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast manipulates perception of others' gaze and does not involve self-referential processing or self-judgments, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

Gaze processing reflects perception and interpretation of others' attentional states and intentions (pSTS, amygdala findings). The contrast measures perception/understanding of others' cues and intentions, satisfying Perception of Others criteria.

The interaction tests how gaze availability modulates neural responses to social versus individual actions (i.e., how social inference is computed), directly indexing social processing (dMPFC modulation argues for inferential social processing).

The interaction shows greater dMPFC activity for social interactions specifically when gaze is unavailable, reflecting inferential processing about shared goals/relations between agents (triadic relations). Although not a classic attachment paradigm, it probes recognition of affiliative/cooperative relations, meeting the broad inclusion criterion for affiliation-related tasks.

The interaction explicitly involves gaze (a communicative signal) and social vs individual action context; it measures how communicative gaze cues modulate processing of others' actions and intentions (fits Social Communication criteria).
The interaction concerns observers' perception of others and the effect of gaze on social inference, not self-related judgments or self-referential processing. Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The interaction reflects higher-order perception and understanding of others (inferring social meaning when gaze cues are absent), engaging theory-of-mind/inferential systems (dMPFC). This matches Perception and Understanding of Others (action perception and mental-state inference).

The task requires participants to view approaching characters making emotional facial expressions (happy vs angry) and to interpret social intentions (affiliation vs threat). This directly engages broad social processing (perception, interpretation, and response to social cues).

The contrast explicitly manipulates signals of affiliation (happy) versus lack of affiliation/threat (angry) and assesses neural responses to these affiliative cues, matching the affiliation/attachment construct.

The paradigm centers on reception of facial communication and direct eye gaze (dynamic facial expressions and gaze shifts). The contrast measures neural responses to facial/communicative signals, satisfying social communication criteria.

The task involves passive observation of other actors and inference about their intentions; it does not involve self-referential judgments, self-evaluation, or agency assessments, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
Participants assess others' emotional states, intentions (dominance vs affiliation), and biological motion; the contrast probes perception and understanding of others, matching this construct.

The Happy>Angry contrast still involves social stimuli (approach, facial expression) and measures social processing of affiliative versus threatening cues; it therefore indexes broad social processing.
This contrast highlights greater responses to happy (affiliative) approaches compared with angry approaches, directly measuring affiliation-related neural processing.
Happy>Angry evaluates neural responses to facial communication and gaze (reception of facial expressions), fitting the social communication inclusion criteria.
No self-referential or self-judgment processes are involved in this contrast; participants passively view others rather than evaluating themselves.
Happy>Angry examines perception and interpretation of others' emotional states and social intentions (affiliation), consistent with Perception/Understanding of Others.

Stories present and interpret social rules (social-exchange, precautionary, descriptive); this contrast (Stories > Rest) examines brain activity during interpretation of social-rule stories, so it measures social processing.
Stories>Rest is a broad, collapsed contrast across all content types and does not specifically target affiliation/attachment (cooperation) processes.
Story presentation involves interpreting rules and speakers’ communicative intent (comprehension module); this contrast measures the interpretive/communicative processing of social rule stories.
Task does not involve explicit self-judgment, self-other comparison, or agency assessments; stories focus on others’ rules and behaviours, not self-related processing.
Stories require inferring others’ goals/intentions (ToM) especially for social-exchange stories; Stories>Rest captures interpretive processes involving understanding others.

This contrast is the inverse of the story-based condition from the same social-rule task; although it reflects deactivations, it is derived from a social cognitive paradigm and thus pertains to social processing.
Rest > Stories is not assessing affiliation/attachment processes; it reflects relative deactivation compared to story interpretation rather than measuring cooperation-related processing.
The contrast reflects greater activation at rest relative to stories and does not directly measure social-communication processes (which are engaged during story interpretation).
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are targeted by this contrast.
This contrast does not specifically measure understanding of others’ mental states; it reflects deactivations relative to the story condition rather than direct ToM measurement.

Card responses require subjects to evaluate potential violations of social rules (including social-exchange and precautionary rules), so this contrast measures social processing during decision-making.
Cards>Rest collapses across all card types and does not selectively measure affiliation/attachment (cooperative exchange) processes.
The card phase is a decision/violation-detection stage rather than a communicative-comprehension stage; it does not directly index social-communication (receptive/expressive) processing.
No self-referential or agency judgments are required during the card-choice phase.

Authors report that ToM areas were principally engaged during story interpretation rather than card choice; Cards>Rest therefore does not primarily index perception/understanding of others’ mental states.
Rest > Cards is part of the same social-rule decision-making paradigm; although it reflects relative deactivations, the underlying task is social, so the contrast is linked to social processing.
This contrast does not specifically probe affiliation/attachment processes (cooperation/relationship measures).
Rest > Cards indicates deactivation relative to the decision phase and does not directly index social communication.
No self-related processing is targeted by this contrast.
This contrast does not directly measure ToM or understanding of others’ mental states; it captures relative deactivation patterns versus the card decision condition.
This contrast specifically compares social-exchange (social contract) story interpretation to precaution stories; it directly probes social processing related to social-exchange reasoning.

Social-contract stories instantiate cooperative/social-exchange scenarios (benefit-requirement template and cheater detection), which directly tap affiliation/attachment/ cooperation-related processing.

Interpreting social-contract stories requires inferring communicative intent and the social meaning of conditional offers (comprehension of social exchanges), thus indexing social-communication processes.
Contrast concerns understanding social exchange between agents, not self-referential judgments or self-knowledge.

Social-contract interpretation required inferring others’ desires/intentions (ToM); authors reported anterior/posterior temporal and posterior cingulate activation consistent with perception/understanding of others.
Stories contrasting social contracts versus descriptive rules probe social-exchange-specific interpretive processing and therefore social processing.
Social-contract stories involve cooperative exchange and cheater-detection—core affiliation/attachment-related constructs—so this contrast measures affiliation/attachment processes.
Interpreting social contract stories involves reconstructing speakers’ social intent and the communicative meaning of offers; thus this contrast indexes social-communication processes.
No self-referential or agency judgments are elicited by this contrast; it focuses on others’ social-exchange representations.

Authors report ToM-related activations (anterior/posterior temporal cortex) for social-contract stories relative to descriptives; this contrast therefore measures perception and understanding of others’ mental states.
Card-phase contrast for social contracts versus precautions targets decision-making about social-rule violations (cheater detection), reflecting social processing during choices.

The card-phase for social contracts involves cheater detection in cooperative exchanges (social-exchange-specific), so it taps affiliation/attachment-related processing even if ToM activation is minimal at this stage.
The card phase is about violation detection (categorization/information search) rather than communicative reception/production; it does not directly measure social-communication processes.
No self-focused judgments are required during the card choice phase for this contrast.

Authors report that ToM areas were not differentially activated during card-based cheater detection for social contracts; thus this contrast does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others’ mental states.
Card-phase social-contract vs descriptive contrast examines decision processes about potential violations of social rules and is part of the social-processing task.
Card decisions for social contracts index cheater-detection in cooperative contexts, tapping affiliation/attachment constructs even if interpretive ToM is not re-engaged at this stage.
This contrast focuses on violation-detection responses (decision-making) rather than communicative signal reception/production.
No self-evaluation or agency judgments are probed in this card-based contrast.
Authors report no differential ToM activation for social-contract card choices relative to descriptives; thus this contrast does not primarily index ToM/perception of others’ mental states.

This contrast probes interpretation of precautionary versus social-exchange stories; precautionary stories are social in that they concern people’s actions and safety, so it is linked to social processing.
Precautionary rules are about hazard management and do not instantiate cooperative/affiliation scenarios, so this contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Interpreting precautionary stories requires comprehending rule content and the communicative context (instruction/warning), so the story-interpretation contrast taps social-communication-related comprehension processes.
These stories do not require self-referential judgments or self-knowledge assessment.

Authors report that precautionary story interpretation did not differentially activate ToM-associated regions; precautionary stories do not require inferring others’ mental states in the same way social contracts do.
Precautionary stories concern people’s behavior in hazardous contexts and thus fall under social processing; this contrast examines those interpretive processes relative to descriptive stories.
Precautionary rules regulate safety and risk, not cooperative affiliation/attachment; this contrast therefore does not index affiliation.

Interpreting precautionary rules involves processing communicated safety constraints and intentions behind warnings/instructions; thus the contrast engages social-communication/comprehension processes.
No explicit self-related judgments are required by the precautionary vs descriptive story contrast.
Precautions do not require inferring others’ desires/intentions (ToM) in the same way social-exchange stories do; authors report no ToM-area activation for precaution interpretation.
Card-based precaution vs social contract contrast involves evaluating others’ actions with respect to rules (danger vs cheating) and thus pertains to social processing during decision-making.
This contrast centers on hazard detection rather than cooperative exchange; it does not index affiliation/attachment processes.
The card phase is a decision/search stage, not a measure of communicative reception/production or the comprehension of communicative intent per se.
No self-referential or agency-related processing is required in this card-contrast.

Although some posterior temporal activation was observed for precautions during card choice, the decision-phase contrast is not primarily a ToM/perception-of-others measure according to the authors (precautions do not require inferring mental states as social contracts do).
Cards contrast (Precautions > Descriptives) examines decision processes about rule violations concerning people’s safety—part of social processing in the task context.
Precautionary decision-making concerns hazard detection rather than affiliation/cooperative exchange.
Card-phase contrasts index violation detection rather than communicative reception/production.
No self-focused processing is required by this contrast.
This card-based contrast is not primarily a ToM measure; authors do not report ToM-area engagement as central to precaution vs descriptive card decisions.
Descriptive stories concern people’s habits/preferences and are part of the social-rule story set; this contrast (Descriptives > Social Contracts) involves social content and thus social processing.
Descriptive stories are not focused on cooperative exchange or affiliation-based interactions, so this contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment.

Interpreting descriptive stories involves comprehension of communicative content about individuals’ preferences/traits; as a story-interpretation contrast it indexes social-communication processes to some degree.
No self-referential judgments or agency attributions are required by this contrast.

Although descriptives involve others’ traits, this contrast did not strongly invoke ToM/mental-state inference regions (authors found limited ToM-related activation), so it is not primarily a perception-of-others (ToM) contrast.
Descriptive vs precautionary story contrast engages processing of social-content stories about people’s traits/hazards and thus relates to social processing.
Descriptives vs precautions contrast does not target cooperative/affiliative interactions; it contrasts descriptive social content with hazard-focused rules.

Both descriptive and precautionary stories require comprehension of communicated information about people’s behavior; this contrast indexes interpretation/comprehension (social-communication) processes during stories.
No self-related judgments are required by this contrast.

Authors report that descriptive stories (vs precautions) engaged right parahippocampal/amygdala area but did not robustly activate canonical ToM regions; thus this contrast is not primarily a ToM index.

Card-based Descriptives > Social Contracts contrast examines decision processes about others’ behaviors and rule violations; this is embedded in the social-rule task and pertains to social processing.
This contrast contrasts descriptive-rule violation detection with social-contract violation detection and is not specifically a measure of affiliation/cooperative bonding.
Card-choice contrasts reflect violation-detection decision processes rather than receptive/expressive social-communication measures.
No self-referential or agency-related judgments are required in this contrast.

The Descriptives > Social Contracts card contrast activated dorso-medial prefrontal and cingulate regions (areas often implicated in mentalizing/ToM); this contrast thus indexes perception/understanding of others in the decision phase.

Cards contrast (Descriptives > Precautions) evaluates others’ behaviors against descriptive vs precautionary rules and is part of the social-rule decision-making paradigm, so it is relevant to social processing.
This contrast contrasts descriptive and precautionary violation detection and does not specifically target affiliation/cooperation.
Card-choice phase is about violation detection and does not measure communicative reception/production directly.
No self-related processes are explicitly measured by this contrast.

This card-contrast principally activated dorso-lateral prefrontal and parietal regions (deliberative reasoning) rather than canonical ToM regions; thus it is not primarily a perception-of-others contrast.

The contrast (pieces cued as composed vs computer-generated) manipulates subjects' social attitude toward the stimulus and measures mentalizing/theory-of-mind processing. fMRI results show activation in aMFC, STS and temporal poles—canonical social cognition/mentalizing regions—so this contrast clearly measures social processing.

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger, etc.). It targets attribution of intentions to an artifact rather than formation or maintenance of social bonds.

Although the stimuli are auditory, the study tests attribution of intentions (mentalizing) rather than reception/production of communicative signals (faces, explicit emotional/communicative content, gaze, speech). The task does not operationalize social communication per the annotation definition.
The contrast does not involve self-related judgments, agency/self-knowledge, or comparisons of self vs other. It concerns inference about others' (creator's) intentions, not self-perception.

The core question and measured effects concern attributing intentions to a presumed human creator (theory of mind/understanding mental states). Activations and questionnaire correlations support that this contrast indexes perception/understanding of others (mental state attribution).

Same experimental manipulation: belief that music is composed vs computer-generated drives mentalizing. The contrast assesses social processing and recruits canonical ToM regions (aMFC, STS, temporal poles).
This analysis does not test affiliation/attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts). It indexes attribution of intentions, not attachment.

The contrast measures mental state attribution to a creator rather than communicative exchange per se; it does not operationalize reception/production of communicative signals (faces, explicit social communicative acts).
No self-related judgments or self/other comparisons are made in this contrast; the focus is on inferring others' intentions (composer), not on self-perception.

The analysis targets understanding others' mental states (did participants think the music expressed the composer's intentions). Neural and behavioral measures (aMFC activation correlated with intention ratings) support interpretation as perception/understanding of others (ToM).

This analysis (Pavlovian water reward task) is a non-social Pavlovian conditioning task using thirsty subjects and water delivery; it does not involve social stimuli or interactions. Does not meet inclusion criteria for social processing.
Pavlovian water delivery does not measure affiliation or attachment-related processes (no social inclusion/exclusion or relationship measures).
Task does not involve exchange of social information, faces, gaze, or communicative gestures; it is non-social reward learning.
Does not probe self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge (water reward learning only).
Does not involve perceiving or reasoning about others' states or actions; no social agents are involved.

The Social task is explicitly a social motor response learning paradigm involving animated other agents, social inclusion/exclusion, and learning about social inclusion as reinforcement—this directly measures social processing.

The Social task manipulates and measures social inclusion versus exclusion (affiliation-related processes) and subjects rated feelings of belonging/value; thus it assesses affiliation/attachment-related learning.

The paradigm involves exchange between agents (ball passing) and reception/production of social actions; it is an interaction paradigm measuring socially relevant information exchange, fitting social communication criteria.

Although subjects are represented in the game, the task does not measure self-judgment, self-knowledge, or agency explicitly (no self>other contrasts); it probes inclusion rather than core self-perception.

The task requires perceiving other agents' actions (throwing/catching) and learning about their likelihood of including the subject—this engages action perception/understanding of others and animacy inference.
This analysis compares Pavlovian and Social tasks and identifies regions with stronger TD signals in the Social task (e.g., frontal operculum, dAC), thereby measuring social processing differences.

The contrast highlights neural responses linked to social inclusion/exclusion (affiliation) differences between tasks (Social > Pavlovian), and thus measures affiliation/attachment-related processing.
By contrasting Social and Pavlovian tasks, this analysis isolates regions engaged by social interaction/communication (ball-passing exchanges), meeting social communication criteria.
The group-level contrast compares task types and does not target self-specific judgments or agency (no explicit self > other contrasts), so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.

The Pavlovian vs Social comparison reveals regions involved in perceiving and understanding others' actions and intentions (e.g., frontal operculum implicated in action understanding), thus measuring perception/understanding of others.

The SELF vs high-level baseline contrast is an empathy-related social task probing emotional perspective taking (self-focused), which clearly measures social processing across interpersonal contexts.
The task probes emotional perspective taking and empathy but does not measure affiliation or attachment (no kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).
Participants view emotional faces and select emotional descriptors (receptive facial communication and emotion recognition), meeting criteria for social communication (face/emotion processing).
This contrast explicitly requires subjects to focus on their own emotional response (SELF task > baseline), directly measuring perception/understanding of the self (self-related emotional judgments).
The SELF vs baseline contrast targets self-related processing rather than perception/understanding of others; it does not match the I1 examples (ToM/other-focused contrasts).
The OTHER vs high-level baseline contrast is an empathy-related social task (attribution of emotion to others) and thus measures social processing.
The OTHER task evaluates emotion attribution to faces but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation/loved-one contrasts).
OTHER vs baseline involves viewing faces and judging others' emotional states (receptive facial communication), satisfying social communication criteria.
The OTHER contrast targets perception/understanding of others rather than self-related judgments, so it does not meet the Perception-Self inclusion criteria.

This contrast explicitly measures attribution of emotional states to others (OTHER task > baseline), matching the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (ToM/empathy-related other-focused processing).
The correlations examine neural activation related to empathy (mirror neuron regions) and dispositional empathic scores across tasks—this addresses social processing broadly.
The analysis correlates mirror-system activation with empathy scores; it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/attachment measures).
The correlated activations are in response to viewing and evaluating emotional faces (facial communication) and thus pertain to social communication processes (reception of facial communication).

Correlations include neural responses from SELF-related regressors/regions (mirror neuron activation during self-attribution was analyzed), so the analysis partially measures perception/understanding of self-related emotional responses.

Correlations also include neural responses from OTHER-related regressors/regions (mirror neuron activation during attribution to others), so the analysis measures perception/understanding of others as well.
This interaction tests gender differences in SELF-related activation (SELF_f – B_f) – (SELF_m – B_m), probing social-empathic processing and gender modulation—therefore social processing is measured.
The contrast concerns gender differences in self-related empathy but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no attachment/relationship measures).
The underlying SELF task involves viewing emotional faces and making judgments; the interaction reflects differences in processing facial/emotional communication (social communication).
The interaction is built on the SELF > baseline contrast and specifically tests gender differences in self-related emotional attribution, directly measuring perception/understanding of the self.
This interaction isolates SELF-related processing differences between sexes and does not target perception/understanding of others, so it does not meet the Perception-Others inclusion criterion.
This interaction reverses the gender comparison for SELF-related activation (SELF_m – B_m) – (SELF_f – B_f) and still probes social-empathic processing; social processing is measured.
Although it interrogates gender differences in SELF-related empathy, it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/attachment measures).
As with the other SELF-based contrasts, this interaction concerns processing of emotional facial stimuli and their social communicative content; thus it meets social communication criteria.
The contrast focuses on SELF-related activation differences between males and females (SELF regressors), directly indexing perception/understanding of one's own emotional responses.
This analysis isolates SELF-related gender differences and does not measure perception/understanding of others, so it does not satisfy the Perception-Others inclusion criterion.
This interaction tests gender differences for the OTHER task (OTHER_f – B_f) – (OTHER_m – B_m), which probes social-empathic processing of others' emotions and thus measures social processing.
The OTHER-based gender interaction evaluates emotion attribution to faces but does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one contrasts).
The contrast concerns processing of emotional facial expressions and gender modulation of that processing (reception of facial communication), meeting social communication inclusion criteria.
This interaction concerns OTHER-related processing (attribution to others) rather than self-related perception, so it does not meet Perception-Self inclusion criteria.
The OTHER-based gender interaction directly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states (OTHER > baseline), fitting the Perception-Others construct (ToM/empathy-related).

Contrast compares self vs friend across face and name recognition — a social-related task addressing self/other social processing across modalities.
Contrast is self > friend (self-specific), not a comparison of loved one vs stranger or direct affiliation/attachment measure.
Task involves perception of social stimuli (faces and written names) relevant to social communication; contrast assesses differential processing of social cues for self vs friend.
Contrast is explicitly Self > Friend, directly measuring perception/understanding of self (self-recognition).
Contrast focuses on self > friend rather than measuring perception or reasoning about others.
Face-specific self > friend contrast examines social processing during face recognition, a social task.
Contrast is Self > Friend for faces; not a loved-one vs stranger (affiliation) contrast.
Viewing faces and discriminating self vs friend taps receptive facial social-communication processes (face perception).
Direct Self > Friend face contrast meets criterion for self-perception/self-recognition.
Contrast targets self-specific face processing rather than perception/understanding of others.
Name-based self > friend contrast probes social processing for person-identifying stimuli (written names).
Self > Friend for names is not a direct affiliation/attachment (loved-one vs stranger) contrast.
Recognition of written names is a non-facial form of social communication/receptive processing; contrast addresses differential social-information processing.
Contrast is Self > Friend for names, directly assessing self-related perception/recognition.
Contrast does not target perception/understanding of others; it contrasts self vs friend.
Interaction isolating face-specific self effects examines social processing specific to faces (a social domain).
This interaction isolates self-face specificity rather than an affiliation/attachment contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
Face-specific effects implicate receptive facial communication processes; contrast is relevant to social-communication subconstructs.
Contrast specifically tests self-face processing (Self > Friend for faces), directly measuring self-perception.
Contrast emphasizes self-face specificity rather than processing of others.
Interaction isolating name-specific self effects probes social processing for name stimuli (social identity cues).
Name-specific self contrast is not a loved-one vs stranger (affiliation) comparison.
Written-name recognition is a form of non-facial social communication; name-specific self effects relate to receptive non-facial communication.
Contrast isolates self-related processing for names (self-perception/self-recognition).
Contrast contrasts self vs friend for names and is not focused on perception of others.
Friend > Self (across face and name) contrast examines social processing related to familiar others, a social task.
Contrast is Friend > Self rather than a loved-one vs stranger or familiar vs unfamiliar comparison; it does not directly index attachment.
Contrast involves face/name stimuli and differential processing for a familiar person, engaging social-communication systems.
Contrast focuses on greater activation for friend than self, so it does not index self-perception (Self > Other).
Friend > Self contrast addresses processing of a familiar other and thus measures perception/understanding of others.
Face-based Friend > Self contrast taps social processing during face recognition of a familiar person.
This contrast compares friend vs self for faces but does not directly compare familiar vs unfamiliar (attachment) pairs like loved vs stranger.
Face perception of a friend engages receptive facial communication processes (gaze, identity cues).
Contrast is Friend > Self, not Self > Other, so it does not index self-perception.
Contrast evaluates processing of a familiar other (friend) indicating perception/understanding of others.
Name-based Friend > Self contrast involves social processing of person identity via names.
Contrast is Friend > Self for names, not a familiar vs unfamiliar (attachment) contrast.
Processing written names of a friend implicates non-facial social communication/reception mechanisms.
Contrast examines greater activation for friend than self (not Self > Other).
Contrast probes processing of a familiar other (friend) via name stimuli, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Interaction isolating face-specific friend effects examines social processing related to familiar others in face modality.
Face-specific friend interaction isolates modality-specific friend effects but is not a direct affiliation (loved vs stranger) contrast.
Face-specific friend effects engage receptive facial communication processes for familiar others.
Contrast focuses on friend > self interaction and so does not index self-perception.
This interaction isolates face-specific processing of a familiar other (friend), meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Name-specific friend interaction probes social processing for familiar others in the name modality.
Name-specific friend interaction is not a direct affiliation/attachment contrast (loved vs stranger).
Processing names of friends involves non-facial social communication (reception of identity cues).
Contrast emphasizes friend-related effects (not Self > Other), so it does not index self-perception.
Contrast targets processing of a familiar other (friend) via names, satisfying perception-of-others criteria.
Familiarity contrast (self+friend vs unfamiliar) directly probes social processing related to person familiarity across modalities.
Contrast compares familiar (self and friend) vs unfamiliar persons, directly reflecting affiliation/familiarity effects (analogous to loved one vs stranger comparisons).
Familiar vs unfamiliar person stimuli (faces/names) engage social-communication networks involved in person recognition.
Contrast pools self with friend and compares to unfamiliar; it does not isolate Self > Other specifically.
Contrast targets familiarity rather than perception/understanding of others' mental states or traits specifically.
Face-based familiarity (self+friend > control) examines social processing of familiar faces versus unfamiliar faces.
This contrast compares familiar (self+friend) faces to unfamiliar faces, reflecting affiliation/familiarity effects analogous to loved vs stranger contrasts.
Face familiarity modulation is a core receptive facial communication process (identity and social cue processing).
Contrast combines self and friend, so it does not isolate self-specific perception.
Contrast indexes familiarity effects for faces generally and does not specifically target perception/understanding of others' mental states.
Name-based familiarity contrast probes social processing of familiar vs unfamiliar names across modalities.
Contrast compares familiar names (self+friend) to unfamiliar names, reflecting affiliation/familiarity effects relevant to attachment/close relationships.
Processing familiar vs unfamiliar names is a non-facial form of social communication related to person identity recognition.
As a pooled familiar > unfamiliar contrast, this does not isolate self-specific perception.
Contrast captures familiarity rather than targeted perception/understanding of others' mental states or traits.
Face-specific familiarity interaction examines modality-specific social processing for familiar faces vs names.
This interaction contrasts face-based familiarity effects (familiar vs unfamiliar), indexing affiliation/familiarity in the face modality.
Face-specific familiarity effects involve receptive facial communication and social-cue processing.
Interaction contrasts modality-specific familiarity (faces vs names) and pools self+friend, not isolating Self > Other.
Contrast emphasizes familiarity and modality differences rather than perception/understanding of others' mental states.
Name-specific familiarity interaction probes social processing for names (non-facial modality) and familiar vs unfamiliar persons.
Interaction isolates name-based familiarity effects (familiar vs unfamiliar), reflecting affiliation/familiarity in the name modality.
Name-specific familiarity effects relate to non-facial receptive social-communication processing (person identity by name).
Contrast pools self+friend familiarity and does not isolate self-specific perception.
This interaction addresses familiarity in names rather than explicit perception/understanding of others' mental states or traits.

Analysis derives from the PD vs. Gamble contrast and identifies a network active during social interaction (Prisoner’s Dilemma), directly measuring social processing.
The PD task measures cooperation/competition and social bonding dynamics (affiliation), so the analysis assesses affiliation/attachment-related processes.
The iterated PD is an interactive exchange of socially relevant information between agents (reciprocity, signaling), fitting social communication constructs.
Results implicate default-mode regions and simulation/self-referential processing (DMPFC) suggesting engagement of self-related processes during the social task.
The contrast and subsequent analyses focus on theory-of-mind/mentalizing (understanding others’ intentions), directly indexing perception and understanding of others.
This table/analysis pertains to the social interactive task (PD) and its neural correlates, so it measures social processing.
Analysis concerns cooperative behavior and in-group/out-group interactions which index affiliation and attachment dynamics.
The PD involves exchange of socially relevant choices and outcomes (communication/reciprocity), fitting social communication.
Analyses implicate self-related/default-mode processing (simulation and self-referential thought) during the task, consistent with perception/understanding of self.
The task requires inferring partners’ intentions and mental states (theory-of-mind), so it measures perception and understanding of others.
This analysis correlates behavioral discrimination (cooperation difference) with BOLD differences for in-group vs out-group—direct measure of social processing.
The cooperation difference score indexes affiliative behavior toward in-group vs out-group, so its neural correlates reflect affiliation/attachment processes.
The analysis links behavior in an interactive exchange (cooperation/defection signaling) with neural responses, reflecting social communication processes.
Individual differences in behavioral discrimination likely involve self-related processes (e.g., self-other simulation) that the analysis captures via BOLD correlations with behavior.

The cooperation difference reflects differential treatment of others (in-group vs out-group) and the analysis isolates brain regions responding to others’ social status, indexing perception/understanding of others.
This analysis compares DMPFC functional connectivity between in-group and out-group interactions—directly addressing social neural processing.
Differential DMPFC connectivity with reward/limbic regions for in-group vs out-group is directly related to affiliation/attachment (positive valuation of in-group).
Changes in functional connectivity during interactive sessions reflect exchange-related neural dynamics and communication-related processing between agents.
DMPFC is implicated in self-referential/simulation processes; connectivity differences reflect self-related processing during social interaction.
The connectivity contrast is motivated by differences in mentalizing and responses to others (in-group vs out-group), indexing perception and understanding of others.

The task is a social interaction simulation using personalized peer (friend) and celebrity face stimuli and approach/avoid decisions; the reported contrasts (peers vs celebrities, friends vs others) directly assess social processing (empathy, reward, person knowledge). This meets both criteria: it is a social task and the analysis measures social processing.

Positive peer stimuli were defined as friends and the key contrasts isolate friend-specific responses (positive peers vs other conditions). This directly measures affiliation/attachment (friend vs non-friend), satisfying the criteria.

Participants viewed faces (personalized peers and celebrities) and made social approach/avoid decisions; the analysis involves receptive facial/social cues and interpersonal communication-related processing, so it qualifies as social communication.

The experimental contrasts focus on peers/friends versus celebrities and on emotional valence; there is no self-referential contrast (e.g., Self > Other or viewing one’s own face) or explicit self-judgment measure, so Perception/Self processes are not specifically measured here.

The study probes representations of others’ social/emotional value (friends vs celebrities) and discusses empathy, theory-of-mind and retrieval of person knowledge; the contrasts and reported activations (e.g., vmPFC, amygdala, hippocampus) index perception/understanding of others, meeting the criteria.
