The Communication vs Control contrast measures communicative speech directed at another person (video actor) and involves social interaction processes; meets inclusion criterion for social-related tasks.
This contrast pools familiar and unfamiliar actors (communication overall) and does not directly contrast loved one vs stranger or specifically measure affiliation/attachment.
The contrast isolates production of communicative speech (socially directed verbal exchange) relative to a control naming task, matching the Social Communication construct.
No self-related judgments or self>other contrasts are present; tasks focus on speech production toward others, not self-perception.

Communication vs Control involves understanding and responding to another person (the actor), engaging theory-of-mind/other-perception processes; meets criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.
The Description vs Control contrast requires observing and verbally describing another person's actions and situation, engaging social perceptual and interpretive processes.
The Description vs Control contrast does not manipulate or contrast personal affiliation or attachment (no loved-one vs stranger comparison).

Although verbal, the description task is non-interactive (describing the situation rather than producing social/communicative exchange); the contrast versus control indexes descriptive speech and action perception rather than social communicative production.
The tasks do not probe self-related judgments or self-awareness processes; focus is on others' actions and situations.

Description vs Control engages processing of others' actions, intentions, and situational context and was intended to control for theory-of-mind related processes; fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The Communication vs Description contrast isolates behavioral/social aspects of communicative speech production and explicitly targets social interaction processes, satisfying the social processing criterion.
This contrast compares communicative vs descriptive speech but does not manipulate affiliation or attachment (no familiar vs unfamiliar contrast here).
This contrast isolates production of social communicative speech (communication) relative to non-communicative description, directly indexing Social Communication production processes.
No self-reflection or self-judgment contrasts are present; the focus is on communication directed toward others.
The contrast targets processes involved in understanding and responding to others in a social interaction (theory-of-mind and biographical inference), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The Familiar Communication vs Unfamiliar Communication contrast directly manipulates the social variable of familiarity and examines how social processing differs with a known vs unknown target, clearly a social task.
This contrast compares familiar (close friend) versus unfamiliar actors during communication (loved one/stranger-type comparison), directly matching the Affiliation and Attachment inclusion example.

The contrast examines production of communicative speech as modulated by familiarity (production of social communication toward familiar vs unfamiliar recipients), fitting Social Communication production.
No measures of self-perception, self-judgment, or self>other contrasts; effect pertains to perceptions of others' familiarity and biographical information.
The contrast probes processing of others' biographical information and how it affects communicative behavior, engaging understanding of others (theory-of-mind/biographical inference).

The condition involves a social interactive task (competitive reaction-time paradigm) where subjects observe an opponent adjusting aversive stimulus intensity and anticipate punishment. This clearly measures social processing (perceiving, interpreting, and responding to social information).

The task is a competitive social interaction (cooperation/competition context—Taylor aggression paradigm) which probes social bonding/interaction dynamics (competition and social learning), meeting the affiliation/attachment inclusion examples (cooperation and competition).

Subjects view social cues (opponent’s actions/scale and later pain-related videos) and emotional signals; this involves reception of socially relevant information (facial/behavioral cues), consistent with social communication measures.

This specific analysis isolates anticipation of receiving an aversive stimulus based on the opponent’s adjustment; it primarily concerns perception of the opponent’s action and anticipation rather than explicit measures of self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge. It does not match the example tasks for perception_self.

The condition measures perception and understanding of another’s actions (opponent adjusting stimulus intensity) and anticipatory responses to that other’s behavior, fitting empathy/other-perception constructs and example tasks (empathy-related, observing others).

Retaliation involves explicit social interaction (deciding punishment to an opponent) and engages processing of social information and decisions in an interpersonal context, meeting broad social processing criteria.

The retaliation condition is embedded in a competitive interpersonal context (cooperation/competition dynamics); selection of punishment intensity reflects social decision-making relevant to affiliation/attachment constructs (competition example).

Although primarily decision-oriented, the retaliation condition constitutes a communicative social act (sending a socially meaningful signal to the opponent) and involves processing of socially relevant cues; it therefore fits the social communication inclusion (exchange/reception of social information).
Selecting the intensity of the retaliation stimulus involves agency and self-related decision processes (acting on the opponent), matching the perception_self subconstruct (agency/self-monitoring).

Retaliation requires consideration of the opponent’s prior actions and likely mental states (integration of other’s behavior into decision), fitting perception/understanding of others (mentalizing/empathy-related processes).

The conjunction combines retaliation and watching the opponent—both are social-interactive conditions requiring perception, interpretation, and response to social information, meeting broad social processing criteria.

The conjunction reflects core elements of competitive social interaction (tit-for-tat dynamics, adjustments in punishment), which falls under affiliation/attachment tasks (competition/cooperation examples).

Both components involve exchange and perception of socially relevant signals (observing opponent’s suffering, adjusting punishment)—this involves receptive and productive aspects of social communication (facial/behavioral cues and communicative retaliation).

Because the conjunction includes the retaliation condition (active selection of stimulus intensity), it involves agency and self-related decision-making processes, satisfying perception_self inclusion (agency).
The conjunction also includes watching the opponent suffer, directly measuring perception and understanding of another’s affective state (empathy/mentalizing), matching perception_others criteria.

Contrast compares faces associated with learned social behaviors vs novel faces, directly assessing spontaneous retrieval of person knowledge and engagement of social-cognitive systems (APC, STS). Measures social processing.
Task/contrast does not target affiliation or attachment processes (no measures of kinship, close relationships, cooperation or bonding).
Contrast involves viewing faces and assessing socially relevant information bound to faces (reception of facial communication), fitting Social Communication criteria.
Contrast does not involve self-related judgments or self-referential processing tasks (no Self>Other or self-judgment contrasts).
Contrast assesses retrieval and representation of others’ traits/behaviors (person knowledge, theory-of-mind related regions), meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.
Contrast differentiates faces based on learned social/emotional behaviors (disgusting vs aggressive), probing social-cognitive and affective processing systems; thus measures social processing.
The disgust vs aggression contrast targets affective trait differentiation rather than affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship or cooperation).
Contrast is based on face stimuli and decoded social-affective information (reception of facially bound social information), so meets Social Communication criteria.
No self-referential or self-judgment manipulation is present in this contrast; it concerns others’ traits.

This contrast probes representation of others’ affective traits (disgust vs aggression) and recruits regions involved in understanding others’ emotional states—meets Perception/Understanding of Others criteria.
Contrast (aggressive > disgusting) examines socially relevant trait information bound to faces, engaging social-cognitive processing; therefore included.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no cooperation, kinship, or bonding measures).
Contrast uses face stimuli and contrasts socially meaningful information (traits inferred from behaviors), aligning with Social Communication inclusion criteria.
No self-related processing is probed by this contrast; it concerns perception of others’ traits only.

Contrast assesses differentiation of others’ trait knowledge (aggressive vs disgusting) and recruits regions for understanding others’ emotional/trait states, meeting Perception and Understanding of Others criteria.

The task required subjects to judge whether visual cursor movement was feedback from their own movement (self) or not (other). This directly involves perception/understanding of self vs other, which falls under broad Social Processing constructs per I1.

The experiment does not probe affiliation, attachment, bonding, cooperation/competition, or kinship-related processes. It assesses agency/self-other detection rather than attachment-related behaviors.
The task does not involve communicative exchanges, facial/eye-gaze processing, or other receptive/expressive social communication measures. It instead tests agency and visuo-proprioceptive synchrony.
The contrast measures detection of feedback from one’s own movement (agency/self-recognition). This directly matches the Perception and Understanding of Self construct (I1).

Subjects judged when visual movement was not their own (i.e., non-self/other). This involves action perception of others (distinguishing self vs other action), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (I1).

As in the active condition, subjects judged ownership of visual feedback (self vs non-self) during passive movement; this involves perception/understanding of self and other and therefore falls under Social Processing per I1.
The passive-condition analysis does not measure affiliation, attachment, or relationship-related processes; it focuses on agency/ownership detection rather than bonding or social relationships.
The task does not assess communicative behaviors (e.g., facial expressions, gaze, speech) or social exchange; it examines visuo-proprioceptive synchrony and agency.
The passive contrast examines subjects’ ability to recognize whether visual movement is feedback from their own body — a direct measure of agency/self-perception (I1).

The passive condition requires detecting non-self visual feedback (i.e., other), engaging action/other perception processes and meeting the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criterion (I1).

Contrast SOC>ARB directly tests perception of socially relevant facial expressions versus arbitrary movements, a canonical social-processing manipulation. It therefore measures social processing broadly (perception and interpretation of social cues).

The task contrasts socially relevant expressions with arbitrary movements but does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation, or attachment-specific comparisons).

SOC>ARB isolates reception of socially communicative facial gestures (greetings/approach) versus non-communicative movements, matching the Social Communication construct (reception of facial communication).
SOC>ARB pools across addressees and does not specifically test self-related processing (no Self>Other contrast here).

SOC>ARB concerns perceiving others' socially meaningful facial expressions (animacy/action and social intent), which fits Perception and Understanding of Others (action/animacy perception and mental-state-relevant cues).

Contrast ARB>SOC examines neural responses to facial movements lacking social meaning versus socially relevant expressions; this still probes social processing by contrasting social/non-social face cues.
The contrast concerns low-level/visual face motion versus social expressions, but does not assess affiliation or attachment (no bonding/cooperation metrics).

ARB>SOC involves perception of facial movements and distinguishes communicative (SOC) from non-communicative (ARB) signals, directly relevant to Social Communication (reception of facial communication and related distinctions).
ARB>SOC pools across ME and OTHER and does not test self-related processing (not a Self>Other contrast).
ARB>SOC reflects processing of others' facial movements (action/animacy/perceptual features of faces), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (action/animacy perception).
Contrast ME>OTHER manipulates self-involvement (being gazed at) versus observing others, clearly a social manipulation assessing how social context affects neural responses.

Although ME>OTHER involves interpersonal gaze (which can be affiliative), the study does not operationalize affiliation/attachment or measure bonding or relationship variables; thus it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
ME>OTHER involves directed gaze (an ostensive communicative signal) and thus indexes a form of social communication (production/reception of gaze-based communicative cues).

ME>OTHER is a textbook Self>Other contrast: it specifically probes self-relevant processing (being addressed vs observing others) and so measures Perception and Understanding of Self (self-relevance/agency).

The contrast emphasizes self-involvement (ME) relative to OTHER; it is not primarily a measure of representing or reasoning about others independent of self-relevance, so it does not fit Perception/Understanding of Others as the central construct.

OTHER>ME contrasts observing others-directed behavior versus being addressed oneself, a social task probing processing of social scenes and perspective-taking, thus indexing social processing broadly.
OTHER>ME assesses perspective-taking/spatial reconstruction and does not target affiliation/attachment (no bonding or relationship measures).
OTHER>ME involves perceiving gaze and facial behavior directed to another, which is part of Social Communication (reception of face/gaze cues and their communicative significance).
OTHER>ME is focused on other-directed stimuli and the cognitive processes of third-person perspective-taking rather than self-focused processing; thus it does not meet Perception-Self criteria.

OTHER>ME directly taps processing of others' behavior directed toward a third person (perspective-taking, reconstructing scene, temporoparietal activations), which aligns with Perception and Understanding of Others (action/mental-state understanding).

The interaction SOC×ME isolates neural processes when socially relevant expressions are self-directed versus other-directed, a social-processing interaction combining self-involvement and communicative content.

Although the interaction examines self-directed social signals, it does not operationalize affiliation/attachment (no bonding or relationship measures), so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.

SOC×ME concerns when communicative facial expressions (SOC) are directed at the self, directly indexing social-communication processes (reception of facial/gaze communication in an interpersonal context).

SOC×ME specifically probes self-relevant processing in the context of social signals (how SOC differs when directed to ME vs OTHER) and therefore measures Perception and Understanding of Self (self-relevance/self-related processing).

Although SOC×ME involves perceiving others' signals, the interaction specifically isolates self-directed social processing; it is not primarily a measure of understanding others independent of self-relevance, so it is not classed here as Perception/Understanding of Others.
SOC×OTHER isolates processing of socially relevant expressions when directed to someone else, a social-processing contrast probing how social cues are represented in a third-person context.
The SOC×OTHER interaction reflects processing of social cues directed to others and spatial/perspective computations, not measures of affiliation or attachment (no bonding/cooperation indices).

SOC×OTHER concerns reception/analysis of socially communicative facial expressions when they are directed to another person, fitting the Social Communication construct (reception of facial/gaze signals).
SOC×OTHER contrasts social signals directed to others and is thus not a self-focused contrast (does not measure Self>Other processing).

SOC×OTHER explicitly targets processing of social signals when they are directed toward another, engaging perspective-taking and representations of others’ actions/intentions, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast (‘ToM’ − ‘Physical 1’) probes social cognitive processes (theory of mind) using cartoon stories requiring inference about others’ intentions; thus it measures social processing broadly.

The task contrasts involve inferring intentions and emotions but do not probe affiliation, attachment, close relationships, or loved-one vs stranger distinctions; therefore it does not measure affiliation/attachment.
The ToM task requires decoding socially relevant information (intentions/emotional cues) from visual narratives, which maps onto receptive social communication (interpretation of social signals).
The contrast focuses on reasoning about others’ mental states (ToM) rather than self-related judgments or self-referential processing; it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
The contrast explicitly targets understanding others’ mental states (Theory of Mind), matching the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct and its examples.
The (‘Empathy’ − ‘Physical 2’) contrast probes social cognitive processing of others’ emotions (empathy) using cartoon narratives, thus measuring social processing.

Although the empathy condition evokes emotional understanding, it does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close-relationship contrasts), so inclusion criteria for affiliation are not met.
The empathy contrast requires decoding emotional states and socially relevant cues from visual stimuli, aligning with receptive social communication measures (affect recognition).
The empathy contrast asks about others’ emotions (How will the main character feel better?) rather than self-related processing, so it does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
This contrast explicitly measures empathy—inferring others’ emotional states—directly matching the Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion criteria.
The conjunction identifies areas commonly active for ToM and empathy; both conditions are social tasks, so the conjunction reflects broad social processing.
The conjunction reflects shared ToM/empathy activations but does not specifically index affiliation or attachment processes or contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
Overlapping activations for ToM and empathy stem from interpreting social cues and emotions in narratives, consistent with social communication (receptive processing of social information).
The conjunction highlights processing of others’ mental and emotional states rather than self-referential judgments, so Perception/Self is not met.
The conjunction explicitly captures neural correlates common to inferring others’ intentions and emotions, directly matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The interaction (‘ToM’ − ‘Physical 1’) − (‘Empathy’ − ‘Physical 2’) identifies regions more engaged by ToM than empathy; both are social cognitive operations, so this contrast remains within broad social processing.
This interaction isolates ToM-specific activity (e.g., lateral OFC, STS) and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts, so affiliation criteria are not met.

The interaction highlights neural differences in processing social information (intentionality, agency) versus empathy, which pertains to aspects of social communication (interpretation of social signals).
The contrast emphasizes differences in processing others’ mental states (ToM > Empathy), not self-related processing, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
The interaction specifically contrasts two forms of understanding others (mentalizing > empathic processing), directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.

The interaction (‘Empathy’ − ‘Physical 2’) − (‘ToM’ − ‘Physical 1’) isolates empathy-specific activations (amygdala, cingulate, mPFC); empathy is a social process, so this reflects social processing broadly.
Although empathy is social/emotional, this contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment per se (no loved-one vs stranger or bonding measures), so affiliation criteria are not met.
Empathy-specific activations reflect decoding others’ emotional states from stimuli, consistent with receptive social communication (emotion recognition).
The contrast emphasizes understanding others’ emotions rather than self-related judgments or self-monitoring, so Perception/Self is not supported.
This contrast specifically measures empathy—inferring and processing others’ emotional states—matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast compares angry vs. neutral prosody in voices (AN+NA vs NN). This is a social-related task assessing processing of emotional social cues in voices, meeting Social Processing inclusion I1.

Contrast involves emotion recognition in voices but does not measure affiliation/attachment processes (no tasks about kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion I1.

This contrast tests recognition of emotional prosody (auditory emotion), which is a canonical Social Communication task (reception of non-facial communication). Meets Social Communication inclusion I1.
Task does not probe self-related judgments or self-awareness (no self>other comparisons), so it does not meet Perception/Self inclusion I1.

Processing and judging emotional states conveyed by others' voices maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others (awareness and assessment of others' emotional states). Meets Perception Others inclusion I1.
Contrast isolates anger prosody when it is to-be-attended vs. neutral — a social-related task assessing processing of emotional social cues in voices. Meets Social Processing I1.
Although social in nature, this contrast does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (no cooperation/relationship measures). Does not meet Affiliation/Attachment I1.
This contrast measures reception of emotional prosody (auditory emotion) while attended — directly fits Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication). Meets Social Communication I1.

Attended anger prosody reflects perceiving and evaluating another's emotional state, matching Perception and Understanding of Others inclusion I1.
Contrast examines anger prosody presented to-be-ignored vs neutral — the task still involves processing social-emotional vocal cues, so it meets Social Processing I1.
Contrast does not involve affiliation/attachment (no measures of bonding, kinship, cooperation). Does not meet Affiliation/Attachment I1.
Even when to-be-ignored, the contrast probes reception of emotional prosody (auditory emotion), fitting Social Communication inclusion I1.
No self-referential processing or self-judgments are involved in this contrast; does not meet Perception/Self I1.
Detecting emotional prosody in others' voices (even when unattended) indexes Perception and Understanding of Others; meets Perception Others I1.
This contrast directly compares anger prosody when to-be-attended vs to-be-ignored — a manipulation of socially relevant vocal emotion and attention, meeting Social Processing I1.
Although engaging social-emotional processing, the contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no relationship/bonding tasks). Does not meet Affiliation/Attachment I1.
Contrast assesses differential processing of emotional prosody (auditory reception of non-facial social signals) under attention — fits Social Communication I1.
No measures of self-awareness or self-judgment are present in this contrast; does not meet Perception/Self I1.
Comparing attended vs ignored anger prosody indexes how participants perceive and evaluate others' emotional states under attention — meets Perception Others I1.
Contrast (anger to-be-ignored vs to-be-attended) still concerns processing of emotional prosody in voices; the task is social in nature and meets Social Processing I1.
This contrast does not probe affiliation/attachment processes or related tasks (no kinship/cooperation measures). Does not meet Affiliation/Attachment I1.
The contrast evaluates reception of emotional vocal signals under different attention conditions — aligns with Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication) inclusion I1.
No self-related processing or self>other comparisons are involved; does not meet Perception/Self I1.
This contrast involves perceiving others' emotional vocalizations (here when ignored vs attended), mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others; meets Perception Others I1.

Spatial attention to right vs left ear was manipulated within a task using social stimuli (voices, emotional prosody). Although the contrast is spatial attention, the task context is social communication, so it meets Social Processing I1.
This spatial attention contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding/cooperation). Does not meet Affiliation/Attachment I1.

Even though this is a spatial attention contrast, it is derived from a voice/gender-decision task involving emotional prosody and voice perception, which falls under Social Communication (reception of non-facial communication). Meets Social Communication I1.
The contrast does not involve self-related judgments or self-awareness; Perception/Self inclusion I1 not met.

The underlying task requires perception of others' voices (and their emotional content), so contrasts of spatial attention are still within the frame of perceiving others and meet Perception Others I1.

Spatial attention to left vs right ear contrast was performed in the context of a voice-based task with emotional prosody; the overall study assesses social processing and this contrast is part of that. Meets Social Processing I1.
Contrast does not target affiliation/attachment measures (no relationship/cooperation tasks), so Affiliation/Attachment I1 is not met.
Although a spatial attention contrast, it stems from a task involving reception of vocal emotional signals (social communication). Therefore it meets Social Communication inclusion I1.
No self-referential or self-judgment components are included in this contrast; Perception/Self I1 not met.
The contrast is embedded in a task of perceiving others' voices and emotional prosody, thus indexing Perception and Understanding of Others (I1).

Task contrasts viewing unknown (distracter) faces vs scrambled baseline—this is a social-related face perception task assessing social processing of faces.
Contrast involves unfamiliar/distracter faces and a scrambled baseline; it does not probe affiliation or attachment (no loved-one vs stranger comparison).
Viewing faces (faces > scrambled) taps reception of facial communication and face-processing relevant to social communication.
This contrast does not involve self-face or self-judgment (unknown faces vs baseline), so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
Contrasts perception of other (unfamiliar) faces versus scrambled baseline, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others (face perception).
Familiar vs distracter contrast is a social task comparing personally familiar (fraternity brother) to unfamiliar faces, thus assessing social processing.
Contrast compares a personally familiar/loved (fraternity brother) face to strangers (unknown), matching the example 'Loved one vs Stranger' and probing affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Contrast involves viewing and discriminating faces (familiar vs unknown), which is reception of facial communication and fits social communication criteria.
This contrast does not involve self-face judgments (familiar vs unknown), so it does not measure perception/understanding of self.
Directly probes perception and recognition of other people (personally familiar vs unfamiliar), meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
Self vs distracter contrast is a social task (self-face recognition vs unfamiliar faces) and assesses social cognitive processing related to self/other distinctions.

The task required reading first-person sentences describing social situations and making evaluative judgments about guilt and embarrassment — clearly a social-related task probing social cognition and Theory of Mind. The contrasts (guilt vs neutral; embarrassment vs neutral) directly measure social processing related to self-conscious emotions.

The study does not assess affiliation or attachment processes (no kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts). It probes moral/self-conscious emotions and ToM, not relationship-bonding or attachment constructs.

The task does not target social communication per se (e.g., face/gaze processing, affect recognition, or production/reception of communicative signals). Stimuli were short sentences and the focus was evaluative social cognition/ToM rather than communication-specific processing.

Sentences were written in the first person and participants made judgments about how guilty/embarrassed the described (self) situations seemed, indexing self-evaluative processes and self-related appraisal — matching Perception and Understanding of Self.

The authors frame guilt and embarrassment as self-conscious emotions that require representing others' mental states (Theory of Mind). Reported activations (MPFC, posterior STS) are canonical ToM regions; contrasts therefore measure perception/understanding of others.

The contrast Cooperation vs Independent involves an explicit social interaction (cooperating with another person) and measures social processing (monitoring others' actions, joint goal pursuit).

The task explicitly manipulates cooperation (an affiliation/attachment-related behavior) and contrasts it with independent play, directly measuring affiliation-related processes as listed in the inclusion examples.

Although not a face/gaze task, the cooperation condition requires exchange of socially relevant information (action-based communication, coordinated moves), so it measures social communication between players.
The study discusses self-monitoring and agency (sense of one’s own actions) and contrasts cooperative play with independent play, which taps self-related processes and agency.
Cooperation requires representing and predicting the partner’s actions and intentions (mentalizing), so this contrast measures perception/understanding of others.
The contrast Competition vs Independent involves explicit social interaction (competing against another) and measures social processing, including monitoring and predicting the opponent.

Competition is listed as an example task under Affiliation/Attachment in the inclusion criteria; the contrast probes social relationship dynamics (competitive interaction) and thus meets the criterion.
Competition involves exchange of socially relevant signals through actions (blocking/supporting moves) and requires interpreting them, fitting the social communication construct.
The paper reports regions linked to agency and self/other distinction in competitive play (e.g., inferior parietal), indicating the contrast engages self-perception and agency processes.
Competition requires representing the opponent’s intentions and actions (mentalizing), so the contrast measures perception and understanding of others.
Cooperation vs Competition directly contrasts two social interaction states; both are social tasks and the contrast measures social processing differences between them.
This contrast contrasts cooperation (affiliation/rewarding social bond) with competition, directly probing affiliation/attachment-related neural activity as specified in the inclusion examples.
The contrast isolates neural differences in how social information is exchanged/coordinated in cooperative vs competitive contexts, thus addressing social communication processes.

Cooperation vs Competition differentially engages self-related processes (self–other merging in cooperation vs clearer self/other distinction in competition), so it measures perception/understanding of self.
The contrast probes differences in representing others (mentalizing more in competition, merging more in cooperation), directly measuring perception and understanding of others.
Competition vs Cooperation contrasts two social interaction conditions and measures social processing related to competitive stance and associated mentalizing/executive processes.

Although this contrast emphasizes competition over cooperation, it still directly pertains to affiliation/attachment constructs by comparing competitive versus affiliative interactions, matching inclusion examples.
The contrast isolates how social communicative exchanges differ when competing versus cooperating (e.g., blocking vs supporting moves), so it meets the social communication criterion.
Competition > Cooperation highlights processes of self/agency and monitoring (right inferior parietal, medial PFC activations reported), indicating self-perception is engaged in this contrast.
Competition requires representing the opponent’s intentions and maintaining separate perspectives; this contrast therefore measures perception/understanding of others (mentalizing).

The contrast compares relational (interactive) movie segments to alone segments and rest, directly probing social processing (perception and interpretation of social interactions). The task is explicitly social and the reported activations (dorsomedial PFC, precuneus, STS, IFG, fusiform) reflect social-cognitive processing beyond rest.

Half the stimuli are Communal Sharing clips (couples, family-like interactions) and the relational vs alone contrast targets relationship-related processing (affiliation/attachment). The analysis directly measures responses to affiliative interaction types.

Stimuli include socially communicative cues (faces, speech in some clips, actions) and the contrast isolates interactive segments that require processing of communicative signals; reported activation in STS and fusiform supports inclusion.

The task involved passive observation of others' social interactions (relational vs alone); subjects were not performing explicit self-related judgments or self-referential tasks. Although the discussion references self-knowledge literature, the contrast does not measure self-perception directly.

The contrast targets perception and understanding of others (observing interactions, inferring relations/mental states). The stimuli and results (activation of medial PFC, precuneus, STS) align with processes of reasoning about others and social cognition/ToM-related processing.

The contrast Affective > Neutral compares faces of cooperators and defectors (socially learned moral status) to neutral faces during an interactive social task. This directly measures social processing (perceiving, interpreting, and responding to social information).

The analysis involves cooperative and defection behavior learned during a Prisoner's Dilemma (cooperation/competition), which is a prototypical affiliation/attachment paradigm assessing social bonds and relationship-relevant learning.

The task involves viewing faces and implicit social judgments (gender judgments on faces previously encountered in social interactions). Viewing and evaluating faces falls under social communication (receptive facial communication).
This contrast evaluates perception of other people (cooperators/defectors) and not self-related processing or self-judgments; it does not meet criteria for perception/understanding of self.
The contrast directly measures representations and evaluations of others' moral/social status (cooperators/defectors vs neutral), matching examples like Cooperative > Neutral.
Cooperator > Neutral contrasts faces of socially learned cooperators with neutral faces; this probes social perception, evaluation, and learned social value, meeting social processing criteria.
This contrast isolates cooperative partners (mutual cooperation) versus neutral baseline, directly indexing affiliation/attachment and social bonding from cooperative interaction.
Participants view faces and implicitly evaluate socially relevant cues (cooperators). This fits reception of facial communication.
The contrast concerns perception of other individuals (cooperators) rather than self-referential processing or self-judgments, so it does not meet self-related inclusion criteria.
Cooperator > Neutral is an explicit example of perceiving and evaluating others (cooperative > neutral) and maps to perception/understanding of others including social valuation.
Defector > Neutral contrasts faces of learned defectors (cheaters) vs neutral faces; this assesses social evaluative processing of others within an interactive social context.
Although negative, the defector condition concerns cooperative norms and social bonds (violation of cooperation) and thus pertains to affiliation/attachment constructs (cooperation vs defection).
The analysis involves viewing faces learned through social interaction and implicitly evaluating them (receptive facial communication), satisfying social communication criteria.
This contrast targets perception/evaluation of other agents (defectors) rather than self-related processing, so it does not meet the self-related inclusion criteria.

Defector > Neutral indexes perception and evaluation of others (detection of cheaters), directly matching the examples for this construct (e.g., cooperative > neutral; here the inverse but same domain).

The Intentional > Nonintentional Cooperator contrast examines how attribution of intentionality modulates responses to cooperative faces — a core social processing manipulation (social inference, evaluation).

This contrast isolates effects of perceived intentionality on cooperative partners, directly relating to affiliation and the formation/assessment of social bonds under different social-context attributions.
The contrast involves viewing faces and implicit social inference about intentionality and cooperation, engaging reception of facial/social cues and thus social communication.
The manipulation concerns perception and attribution about others' intentionality and moral status (not self-related processing), so it does not meet self-related inclusion criteria.

Comparing intentional vs nonintentional cooperators directly probes understanding of others' mental states/intentionality and their social evaluation, matching perception_others criteria (animacy/intentionality and mental state understanding).

The analysis contrasts emotional face tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces) with a neutral control (shapes). This involves processing of social stimuli (faces) and emotion-related social information, satisfying the Social Processing inclusion criterion (I1).

The task does not probe affiliation or attachment processes (no cooperation, kinship, loved-one vs stranger contrasts or measures of bonding). It is a gender identification/emotion percept task, so it does not meet the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion (I1).

Participants viewed faces with emotional expressions (angry, happy), which constitutes reception of facial communication (affective facial cues). The analysis therefore measures Social Communication per the I1 criterion (face viewing/emotion perception).

The contrasts do not involve self-related judgments, self-other comparisons, or measures of agency/self-knowledge; they are perceptual decisions about others' faces or shapes. Thus Perception/Self inclusion criterion (I1) is not met.

Although faces are presented, the task is gender identification (implicit emotion processing) rather than an explicit measure of others' mental states, empathy, or theory-of-mind processes. It does not clearly meet the Perception/Understanding of Others inclusion examples (I1), so this annotation is not included.

This analysis contrasts gender identification of emotional faces (happy) with neutral shapes, involving social-emotional face processing. It therefore meets the Social Processing inclusion criterion (I1).

The task does not assess affiliation or attachment (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one vs stranger contrasts). It is a perceptual gender/emotion task and does not meet the Affiliation/Attachment inclusion criterion (I1).

Viewing faces with emotional expressions (happy) entails reception of facial communication (affective cue processing). The analysis therefore satisfies the Social Communication inclusion criterion (I1).
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing are present in these contrasts; the task concerns perceiving others' faces/shapes, so Perception/Self criterion (I1) is not met.

While emotional facial expressions are shown, the paradigm does not explicitly probe understanding of others' mental states (e.g., ToM, empathy). It is primarily a perceptual gender/emotion task and thus does not clearly fulfill the Perception/Understanding of Others inclusion examples (I1).

The main effect of age group is from an ANOVA of a social evaluation task (direct self, direct other, reflected self about best friend, and malleability). The task is intrinsically social, so this analysis measures social processing across groups.

The dataset includes evaluations about a personally close peer (best friend) and peer-related reflected self-evaluations, which probe affiliation/attachment processes. The age-group main effect thus derives from a paradigm that measures affiliation/attachment-relevant processing.

The task involves trait-evaluations (self, close other, reflected) rather than explicit social-communication operations (e.g., face/emotion perception, gaze, mimicry). It does not match the social-communication examples (faces, affect recognition), so exclude.

The ANOVA includes direct and reflected self-evaluations (self-judgments and judgments from a friend's perspective), so the main effect of age group is based on tasks that measure perception/understanding of self.

The task contains direct other-evaluations about the participant's best friend and reflected self-evaluations from the friend's perspective, so the analysis involves perception/understanding of others.
This analysis tests the main effect of evaluative perspective (direct self/other, reflected self, malleability) in a social-evaluative paradigm, directly indexing social processing.
Evaluative perspective includes reflected evaluations from a best friend and direct evaluations of a close other, which probe affiliation/attachment processes (peer influence, close relationships).

Although social, the contrast concerns evaluative perspectives and trait judgments rather than communicative signal reception/production (faces, gaze, emotion recognition), so it does not meet social_communication criteria.
Evaluative perspective contrasts include direct and reflected self-evaluations, which are direct measures of self-perception and self-knowledge.
This factor also includes direct other-evaluations (best friend) and reflected perspectives, engaging processes of perceiving and representing others' views, meeting perception_others criteria.
The age group × evaluative perspective interaction examines developmental differences in social-evaluative processing (self/other/reflected), which is squarely within social processing.
Evaluative perspectives involve close-peer reflected evaluations and direct other (best friend) judgments; the interaction assesses developmental differences in affiliation-related processing.
The contrast probes evaluative perspective by age, not social-communication behaviors like face or emotion perception, so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion examples.
Because the interaction specifically involves direct and reflected self-evaluations across age groups, it measures perception and understanding of self and developmental change therein.

The evaluative perspective factor includes direct other judgments and inferred perspectives of others, so the age × perspective interaction also probes perception/understanding of others across development.
The main effect of domain (academic/physical/social) is part of the social-evaluative paradigm and indexes domain-specific social processing (especially the social domain).
One domain is explicitly social (peer-related traits), and contrasts across domains probe affiliation-relevant processes (social domain vs academic/physical).
Domain contrasts concern trait content (academic/physical/social) rather than communication-specific tasks (faces, gaze, emotion recognition), so do not meet social_communication criteria.
Domain-based contrasts apply to self-evaluations (and reflected/direct), indexing how self-perception varies across academic, physical, and social domains.
Domain effects also apply to direct other and reflected judgments about the best friend; thus they involve perception and understanding of others across domains.
The age group × domain interaction examines developmental differences in domain-specific social-evaluative processing (academic/physical/social), so it is social processing relevant.
Because one domain is social and involves peer-relevant traits, the age × domain interaction captures developmental changes in affiliation/attachment-relevant processing.
This interaction contrasts domains of trait content rather than communication-specific receipt or production of social signals; it does not satisfy social_communication criteria.
Domains modulate self-evaluations (e.g., social self vs academic self), so this analysis measures aspects of self-perception across domains and ages.
Domains also modulate evaluations of the close other and reflected perspectives, engaging perception/understanding of others across domains and ages.
The evaluative perspective × domain interaction directly tests how social-evaluative perspective (self/other/reflected) varies across domains (including social), making it clearly social processing.
This interaction includes reflected social self-evaluations about a best friend and direct other-evaluations; such contrasts probe affiliation and peer-related attachment dynamics.

Although social in nature, the interaction addresses evaluative content across domains and perspectives rather than communication-specific tasks (face/emotion/gaze), so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion examples.
Because the interaction contrasts self-related perspectives (direct and reflected) across domains, it measures perception and understanding of self in different contexts.
This interaction involves direct other-evaluations and reflected perspectives (inferring others' views), so it measures perception and understanding of others.

The three-way interaction (age × evaluative perspective × domain) pinpoints developmental differences in social-evaluative processing, especially reflected social self-evaluations, and is clearly within social processing.

The reported three-way interaction localized to bilateral ventral striatum for reflected social self-evaluations about a best friend indicates affiliation/attachment processes (peer salience and close-peer influence).

This three-way interaction involves evaluative perspectives and domains (trait judgments) rather than social-communication reception/production features, so it does not meet social_communication criteria.
The interaction specifically highlights reflected self-evaluations (self from friend's perspective) and domain-specific self-processing, directly measuring self-perception mechanisms.

Because reflected self-evaluations require inferring a close other's perspective and the task includes direct other-evaluations of a best friend, the analysis engages perception/understanding of others and their influence on self-concept.

The contrast Internal > External examines attributional decisions about social events (self-responsibility vs other/situational responsibility). This directly measures broad social processing involved in interpreting social information and making social judgments.

Stimuli are interpersonal (friend/neighbor scenarios) concerning relational events (gifts, trust, visits) that tap affiliation/attachment constructs. The contrast assesses attributions about close social relationships.

The task involves reading and attributing causes for social events rather than measuring communicative processes (e.g., facial or gaze processing, receptive/expressive communication). It does not probe the subcomponents of social communication specified in the criterion.
Internal > External isolates self-responsibility attributions and thus directly probes perception/understanding of the self (agency/self-as-cause).
This contrast emphasizes internal (self) attributions over external (other/situational) attributions; it is primarily a self-focused contrast rather than one targeting representations of others.
External > Internal examines attributions to others or situations for social events, which is clearly a social processing judgment about causal responsibility in interpersonal contexts.
The stimuli concern friends and social relationships (betrayal, ignoring, insults, etc.), so attributing events externally pertains to affiliation/attachment processes within interpersonal contexts.

The contrast focuses on causal attributions in social scenarios rather than on communication-specific processes (faces, gaze, expressive/receptive communication), so it does not meet the social_communication criteria.
External > Internal emphasizes attributions to others/situations rather than self-related judgments, so it does not primarily probe perception/understanding of the self.

This contrast specifically isolates judgments that others or situational factors caused events (external attributions), directly indexing perception and understanding of others' actions/intentions (STS involvement reported supports this).

The self-serving bias contrast combines internal attributions for positive events and external attributions for negative events — a social-cognitive bias in interpreting interpersonal events — and thus indexes social processing.
The stimuli involve friend-based interpersonal scenarios and the contrast examines biased attributions within these relational contexts, implicating affiliation/attachment-related processing.
Although social, the self-serving bias contrast does not target communicative signal processing (faces, gaze, expressive/receptive exchanges) defined by the social_communication construct.
The contrast explicitly includes internal attributions for positive events (self-responsibility) and thus probes self-related representations and agency tied to self-enhancing attributions.

Because the self-serving contrast also includes external attributions for negative events (assigning blame to others/situations), it engages perception/understanding of others' actions/intentions as part of the bias.
The non-self-serving bias contrast (internal negative, external positive) examines social-cognitive attribution patterns in interpersonal scenarios and therefore measures social processing.

Scenarios are interpersonal (friends) and the contrast assesses attributional responses that impact affiliation/attachment (e.g., blaming self vs others), so it maps onto affiliation/attachment processes.

The contrast addresses attributional style rather than communication-specific processes (faces, gaze, expressive/ receptive signaling), so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.
This contrast includes internal attributions of negative events (self-blame), directly engaging perception/understanding of the self (agency, self-evaluation).
The contrast also includes external attributions of positive events (assigning credit to others/situations), engaging representations and judgments about others, thus fitting perception_others.

The self–other morph discrimination is explicitly a social task: participants judge identity (self vs familiar other) of faces, engaging social perception and self/other representations. This directly measures social processing related constructs (self/other perception, social cognition).

The control faces were personally familiar friends selected by each subject, so the contrast involves processing of personally affiliated/attached individuals (familiar other vs self). Although not an explicit attachment scale, the task uses loved/close others as stimuli, meeting the inclusion example (Loved one vs Stranger) in spirit.

The task consists of viewing faces and making identity judgements (receptive facial communication). Viewing and discriminating faces is a canonical social communication/reception paradigm and matches the examples (Viewing pictures of faces).

The self–other contrast (grouping 0/20/40% morphs > 60/80/100% morphs) directly targets perception and recognition of one's own face (Self > Other), which aligns with the Perception_Self inclusion examples.

This specific contrast tests Self > Other (increased response for self-containing stimuli) and therefore does not primarily measure perception/understanding of others; it does not match the Perception_Others inclusion condition.

The other–self contrast involves processing of familiar others versus self and engages social cognition (processing socially relevant, familiar faces). This meets the Social Processing inclusion criterion.

The contrast emphasizes responses to a personally familiar other (a friend/colleague chosen by the subject). This stimulus type likely evokes affiliation/attachment-related representations and therefore meets the stated inclusion (e.g., Loved one vs Stranger) criterion.

Viewing and evaluating familiar faces is a receptive facial-communication task (face perception and social information extraction). The contrast (Other > Self) thus measures social communication processes.
This contrast is Other > Self (activity greater for familiar other than self) and therefore does not index Perception_Self (Self > Other) as required by the inclusion examples.

The Other > Self contrast directly measures neural responses to familiar others (perception/understanding of others), matching the Perception_Others inclusion criteria (tasks measuring perception/understanding of others).

EMO involves reception of facial communication and affect recognition (selecting the emotion displayed), matching the Social Communication construct.

EMO measures representation and assessment of others' emotional states (emotion recognition), which fits Perception and Understanding of Others.

The AGE analysis uses faces and assesses implicit emotional processing (age discrimination on faces). Although the task focuses on age, it still involves social face processing and measures social perception.

Although implicit, AGE involves viewing faces and processing facial information; it taps receptive aspects of facial communication (face perception) and so meets Social Communication inclusion criteria.
AGE involves judgments about others' faces (age), not self-related judgments, and therefore does not meet Perception/Self criteria.
The AGE analysis involves perceiving and judging attributes of other people (age of faces), which is within Perception and Understanding of Others.
The EMO-AGE contrast directly assesses differences in social/emotional face processing between explicit and implicit tasks, thus indexing social processing.
The contrast examines emotion vs age discrimination in faces, not measures of affiliation/attachment or close relationships, so it does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
The contrast isolates modulation of facial affect perception (reception of facial communication) by task, fitting the Social Communication construct.
This contrast contrasts two tasks about perceiving others' faces and emotions; it does not probe self-related processing, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
EMO-AGE reflects differences in representing and evaluating others' emotional states (explicit > implicit), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The experimental tasks do not measure affiliation or attachment (no kinship, cooperation/competition, loved-one vs stranger contrasts, or bonding-related measures). Therefore the inclusion criterion for Affiliation/Attachment is not met.

The tasks do not probe self-related judgments, self-recognition, agency, or viewing the self; they focus on observing others’ actions and executing actions but not on self-perception or self-knowledge. Thus Perception/Self inclusion criteria are not met.

Control analyses include face-based trust ratings and mentalizing, which are core social communication processes.
Control contrasts do not explicitly measure self-related judgments or self-referential processing; focus is on interaction with others and outcome processing.
Control group analyses require inferring others' intentions and responses in the PDG and thus measure perception and understanding of others.
Main effect of group compares activation during a social-interaction task (PDG) between patients and controls, addressing broad social processing differences.
Group differences in cooperation-related activations (e.g., MPFC) reflect affiliation/attachment processes engaged by the PDG.
Group-level contrasts involve regions implicated in face processing, trust and mentalizing, consistent with social communication.
The main-effect-of-group contrast tests between-group differences in social task activation, not explicit self-referential processing or self>other contrasts.
Differences in MPFC and temporal regions between groups reflect altered processing of others' intentions/states, meeting perception-of-others criteria.
Main effect of condition (decision vs result) assesses different phases of a social-interaction task and therefore involves social processing.
Condition differences (choice vs outcome) modulate affiliation-related computations (cooperation dynamics), so affiliation/attachment is relevant.
Condition contrasts engage face/trust and feedback processing relevant to social communication mechanisms.
The condition contrast separates task phases (decision vs result) but does not include explicit measures of self-knowledge or self-judgment.
Decision vs result phases differentially recruit processes for interpreting others' choices and intentions, consistent with perception-of-others.
ROI main-effect-of-group targets social brain ROIs (frontal, ACC, amygdala, etc.) during the PDG, indexing social processing at ROI level.
ROI analyses focused on frontal regions implicated in cooperation and affiliation (MPFC, orbital frontal), matching affiliation/attachment constructs.
ROIs include regions supporting face and mentalizing processes; analyses relate ROI BOLD to trust and face ratings—core social communication functions.
ROI results relate to social interaction and trust processing rather than explicit self-reflection or self>other contrasts.
ROI-level correlations with trust, mentalizing and cooperative choices reflect representations of others' states/intentions (perception of others).

The contrast (increased responses to faces before treatment) arises from participants viewing faces and reflects social-relevant processing (implicit bias, salience of disfigurement). Neural effects include fusiform (face processing) and right IFG and relate to social evaluation, satisfying that the analysis measures social processing.

The task was a gender-judgement on pictures before/after surgery and the study did not measure affiliation or attachment (no kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Thus it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Participants viewed faces (reception of facial communication). The contrast examines responses to facial features (disfigurement) and face-specific visual areas (fusiform), matching the Social Communication inclusion examples (Viewing pictures of faces).
The experiment did not involve self-related judgments or viewing the participant's own face; it assessed perception of others, not self-processing, so Perception/Self criteria are not met.

The contrast targets perception and evaluation of others (disfigured vs treated faces) and the paper interprets ACC decreases as reduced empathy/mentalizing — directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast (decreased responses to faces before treatment) concerns neural responses while viewing socially salient faces and implicates regions (anterior cingulate/medial PFC) tied to social cognition and empathy, indicating the analysis measures social processing.
The contrast does not probe affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship/cooperation/loved-one comparisons); participants performed a gender judgement task unrelated to attachment.

Although this contrast highlights decreased activation (e.g., ACC) rather than face-selective cortex, the stimuli were faces and the question concerns reception of social/facial information; thus it meets Social Communication criteria (viewing faces).
No self-referential judgments or own-face processing were involved; the contrast reflects processing of others, so Perception/Self is not applicable.
The decreased activation in anterior cingulate/medial PFC is interpreted as reduced empathy/mentalizing toward disfigured others, directly indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast (dynamic facial expressions > dynamic mosaics) tests perception and processing of social stimuli (emotional facial expressions) across a large sample, directly measuring social processing.

Stimuli and contrasts probe general facial emotion processing and not affiliation/attachment constructs (no tasks involving kinship, close relationships, cooperation, or loved-one vs stranger contrasts).
Viewing and discriminating dynamic emotional faces is a canonical social communication reception task (facial affect recognition); the contrast isolates face-related communication (faces > mosaics).
Task involves passive observation of others' facial expressions, not self-related judgments or viewing of the self, so it does not measure self perception/understanding.

Processing dynamic facial expressions involves perceiving and interpreting others' emotional states and actions (empathy/theory-of-mind related perceptual processes), matching the perception_of_others construct.
This interaction tests whether social processing (expression > mosaic) differs by emotion; the base contrast is social and thus the analysis addresses social processing.
The emotion interaction examines angry vs happy expressions but does not probe affiliation/attachment constructs (no bonding or relationship tasks).
Emotion×stimulus-type interaction still pertains to reception of facial communication (how different emotions modulate face processing); meets social communication criteria.
No self-referential task or self-judgment manipulation is present in this analysis; it concerns others' faces and emotions.
Examines how perception/processing of others' emotional states (angry vs happy) modulates neural responses to dynamic faces, matching perception of others.
This interaction assesses whether social processing (expression > mosaic) differs by participant gender; it concerns social processing of faces and thus is included.
Although sex is tested, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment (no bonding or relationship-specific contrasts).
Investigates whether reception of facial communication differs by sex; falls within social communication (faces > non-faces) domain.
No self-related judgments or self-perception measures are present; analysis concerns others' facial expressions and sex differences.
Gender×stimulus-type effects probe differences in perceiving others' emotional expressions across sexes, aligning with perception of others.
Three-way interaction (stimulus×emotion×gender) still concerns social processing of facial expressions and how it may be modulated by emotion and sex; thus included.
Despite testing multiple factors, there is no measure of affiliation/attachment or relationship-specific behavior in this analysis.
The interaction examines modulation of facial communication reception by emotion and sex—still a social communication measure (faces > mosaics).
No self-related task components are present; the analysis targets perception of others' dynamic facial expressions and modulatory factors.
Targets how perception of others' emotional expressions varies with emotion and participant sex; directly matches perception and understanding of others.
Laterality analyses (original vs flipped) for expression > mosaic test hemispheric aspects of social processing of faces, so they address social processing broadly.
The laterality contrast examines hemispheric dominance for facial expression processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs or relationship-related tasks.
Laterality of face-expression processing pertains to reception of facial communication (which hemisphere is dominant for processing facial signals).
No self-referential processing is involved in the laterality analysis; it addresses perception of others' faces across hemispheres.
The hemisphere comparison addresses how perception and understanding of others' facial expressions are lateralized, fitting perception_of_others.
This analysis tests emotion×laterality for expression > mosaic and thus examines social processing of faces and its hemispheric modulation by emotion.
Although emotion and laterality are tested, the analysis does not assess affiliation/attachment or bonding-related processes.
Evaluates whether reception of facial communication (face > mosaic) lateralization differs by emotion; relevant to social communication reception.
No self-related judgments or self-referential processing present; analysis focuses on others' facial emotion and hemispheric effects.
Investigates lateralized perception/understanding of others' emotional expressions as a function of emotion, matching perception of others.
Sex×laterality interaction for expression > mosaic assesses social processing and its hemispheric modulation across sexes, so it's within social processing.
This analysis probes sex differences in lateralized face processing, not affiliation/attachment constructs like bonding or cooperation.
Tests whether reception of facial communication lateralization differs by participant sex; fits social communication reception category.
No measures of self-perception or self-judgment are included; focus is on others' facial expressions and sex-related lateralization.
Assesses how perception and understanding of others' expressions are lateralized across sexes, aligning with perception_of_others.
The four-way interaction including laterality, emotion, and sex still addresses social processing of dynamic facial expressions and their modulators, so included.
Even in the full interaction, there is no assessment of affiliation/attachment behaviors or relational tasks; not applicable.
This comprehensive interaction remains within reception of facial communication (how emotion, sex, and laterality modulate face processing).
No self-related tasks are present in the four-way interaction; it concerns perception of others' expressions under various modulators.
Addresses complex modulators of perceiving others' emotional expressions (emotion, sex, laterality), fitting perception_of_others.

The contrast comes from a cyberball social exclusion task and tests how emotional (touch) support modulates neural responses to exclusion (reduced right AI). This directly measures social processing.

Cyberball exclusion and the emotional support manipulation (comforting touch from a friend) probe affiliation/attachment processes and bonding; the contrast assesses changes after affiliative support.
The task involves interpersonal exchange (ball-tossing) and nonverbal communicative touch as support; the contrast examines how this social communication modulates neural responses.
Participants provide self-reported emotional ratings and the contrast shows modulation of affect-related self-processing (AI), indicating measurement of self-perception/affect.
Although this contrast primarily engages affective regions, the cyberball paradigm requires representing others' actions (who passes the ball), so it taps processes related to understanding others.

This contrast derives from the cyberball exclusion task with appraisal (informational) support and probes changes in neural responses (TPJ) to a social manipulation, therefore measuring social processing.
The contrast examines effects of informational/appraisal support on reactions to social exclusion, which relates to affiliation and peer relations (changes in unpleasantness and neural response).

Appraisal support was delivered as text messages (communicative content) and the task involves interpersonal exchange; the contrast captures effects of this social communication on neural activity (TPJ).

Behavioral ratings of unpleasantness change after appraisal support and the contrast links neural changes to subjective self-reported emotion (subsequent analyses correlate brain and self-report), indicating self-perception measurement.
The contrast shows modulation in TPJ, a core ToM/other-understanding region, and appraisal support provides information about others; this directly targets perception/understanding of others.

This contrast (exclusion run2 > run1 after appraisal support) assesses neural responses (increased subACC) to a social exclusion manipulation following social support, thus measuring social processing.

Appraisal support altered affective response to exclusion (increased unpleasantness and subACC activity), reflecting processes tied to affiliation and how social information affects bonding-related emotions.
The manipulation uses communicative text messages from a friend; the contrast captures how that social communication modulates subsequent neural responses to exclusion.

The contrast links increased subACC activation to increased self-reported unpleasantness after appraisal support (brain–behavior correlation), indicating measurement of self-related affective perception.

Appraisal support was informational about others and earlier contrasts showed TPJ involvement; the run2>run1 contrast reflects altered processing of social information about others as part of the task.

The task is a dyadic interactive social-exchange game (cooperation vs competition; concurrent vs turn-based) and the contrasts (Cooperation > Competition) directly probe social processing (interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies).
The contrast contrasts cooperative versus competitive interactions, which directly indexes affiliation/attachment-related processes (cooperation is an affiliation construct).

Although not an explicit verbal/face communication task, the paradigm involves exchange of socially relevant actions and intent signaling between partners; the contrast probes interpersonal exchange and information transfer (iBBDs), fitting social communication inclusion criteria.

The contrasts probe responses to a partner's behavior and inter-brain dependencies rather than explicit self-judgment, self-referential processing, or contrasts of Self > Other. No self-focused task/contrast is present.

The contrast measures reactions to another person’s moves and inferring intentions (mentalizing), directly indexing perception and understanding of others (e.g., Cooperative > Competitive engages other-oriented reward and mentalizing systems).
Competition > Cooperation contrasts probe social interaction dynamics and neural responses to others' behavior during competitive exchange, thus measuring social processing broadly.

The contrast compares competitive versus cooperative contexts; although emphasizing competition, it is still directly about affiliation/attachment dimensions of social exchange and their neural correlates.

Competitive interactions involve exchange of action-based signals and intent inference; the contrast examines interpersonal information exchange and adaptive responding, consistent with social communication processes.
No explicit self-focused contrast or self-judgment is present; the analysis models reactions to another’s moves rather than Self > Other processes.
This contrast isolates neural responses to another person’s behavior in competitive contexts (e.g., pre-SMA, insula), indexing perception/understanding of others and their actions/intentions.
CN > TB contrasts compare concurrent versus turn-based interaction structures in a dyadic social task; this directly probes social processing of different interaction modes.
Interaction structure (concurrent vs turn-based) modulates cooperative/competitive behavior and affiliation dynamics; the contrast evaluates social exchange modes relevant to affiliation/attachment.
Concurrent exchanges require real-time exchange of action-based signals and mutual adaptation (information transmission), so CN > TB probes social communication processes in interaction.
The contrast examines interaction structure effects on responses to others’ moves rather than explicit self-referential judgments or Self > Other contrasts.
CN > TB revealed greater iBBDs in temporoparietal regions and STS, consistent with increased mentalizing/action-perception of others; thus it measures perception/understanding of others.

This contrast tests whether the goal-related effect (Cooperation>Competition) differs by interaction mode (TB vs CN) — a higher-order social interaction contrast directly addressing social processing.
It assesses how affiliation-related neural responses (cooperation > competition) vary with interaction structure; this directly pertains to affiliation/attachment processes.

By comparing how cooperative vs competitive effects differ across TB and CN, this contrast probes differences in interpersonal information exchange dynamics and adaptive communicative signaling across interaction types.
The contrast focuses on interaction-by-goal effects on responses to partners’ actions, not explicit self-focused processing or Self > Other comparisons.

This interaction contrast isolates modulation of responses to others’ behavior by interaction structure and goal, indexing perception and understanding of others (e.g., stronger competitive iBBDs in SMA/precentral areas during CN).
This role-by-goal contrast (Builder (COO>COM) > Other (COO>COM)) examines role-specific social processing during cooperative vs competitive exchanges and therefore probes social processing broadly.

The contrast compares how affiliation-related effects (cooperation>competition) differ between enacted roles (Builder vs Other), directly relevant to affiliation/attachment processes within dyadic exchange.

Role-specific differences in responses to a partner’s moves reflect differences in interpersonal signaling and interpretation; this contrast probes communicative aspects of the interaction (how information is used differently by roles).

Although role differences may involve self-other distinction processes, the contrast does not constitute an explicit self-focused task (no Self > Other contrast); primary focus remains on responses to others’ behavior.

This contrast isolates differences in how Builders versus Others react to co-player behavior in cooperative vs competitive contexts, indexing perception/understanding of others’ actions and intentions.
Other (COO>COM) > Builder (COO>COM) similarly probes role-specific social processing during cooperative vs competitive interaction and thus meets social processing criteria.
This contrast assesses affiliation-related neural effects (cooperation>competition) more strongly expressed in Others than Builders, directly addressing affiliation/attachment dynamics in roles.

Contrasting Others vs Builders in their cooperative>competitive responses indexes differences in how communicative signals are generated and interpreted by different roles, fitting social communication.
No explicit self-referential contrast or Self > Other judgment is present; the analysis focuses on reactions to another’s behavior rather than self-focused processing.
This contrast identifies how Others’ neural reactions to partners during cooperation vs competition differ from Builders’, directly indexing perception/understanding of others and their intentions.
