The study examines perception and integration of emotional expressions from faces and voices—clearly a social-related task measuring social processing (emotion recognition, multisensory social cues). The analysis (unnamed table but from this study) relates to these contrasts and thus measures social processing.
The study and this analysis probe emotional expression integration and congruency, not affiliation, bonding, or attachment processes (no cooperation/kinship/loved-one vs stranger contrasts).

Tasks involve exchanging socially relevant information (face and voice emotional signals, audiovisual emotion perception and congruency), matching the Social Communication construct (receptive facial and non-facial communication).
Analyses concern perception of others' emotional expressions (faces/voices), not self-related judgments, agency, or self-knowledge.
The contrasts assess representations and judgments about others' emotional states (fearful vs neutral, congruency/incongruency), which maps onto Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast (BIMODAL > UNIMODAL FACES) ∩ (BIMODAL > UNIMODAL VOICES) tests multisensory integration of emotional face/voice signals — a social task measuring social processing (emotion perception/integration).
This contrast tests multisensory emotion integration, not affiliation/attachment or relationship-related processing (no kinship/cooperation comparisons).
The contrast probes reception and integration of facial and vocal communicative signals (emotional expressions), matching Social Communication (receptive facial/non-facial communication).
Contrast concerns perception of external agents' emotions rather than self-related processing or self-judgments.
This multisensory contrast evaluates recognizing others' emotional states and integrating cues across modalities (fearful vs neutral), fitting Perception and Understanding of Others.
INCONGRUENT > CONGRUENT examines how conflicting facial and vocal emotional signals are processed — a social task measuring social processing (conflict in social-emotional communication).
The contrast addresses conflict in emotion signals, not affiliation/attachment, bonding, or relationship metrics.
Incongruency between face and voice taps receptive social communication processes (processing and integration of facial and vocal emotional cues), meeting Social Communication criteria.
This contrast targets perception of others' expressions and conflict processing, not self-related judgments or agency.
The incongruency contrast evaluates participants' processing and understanding of others' emotional states when cues conflict, mapping to Perception and Understanding of Others.

The task explicitly probes recalling interpersonal/relationship episodes about self and others, which is a social-cognitive task assessing social processing (self- and other-referencing, autobiographical relationship memory). This matches the Social Processing domain.

Participants generated and recalled formative relationship episodes tied to recurrent interpersonal behavior and attachment-related internal working models; the stimuli and contrasts probe relationship-related affiliation/attachment processes rather than non-social content.

The contrast (self-relevant > control) targets autobiographical recall and self-referential/affective processing of relationship episodes, not explicit social communication (e.g., face perception, gaze, or communicative exchange). Thus it does not meet Social Communication criteria.

The contrast contrasts self-relevant autobiographical recall against control images, directly tapping self-referential processing (thinking about/putting oneself back into personal relationship episodes). This fits Perception and Understanding of Self (Self > Control).

This specific contrast is self-relevant > control and does not index perception/understanding of others. Although the study includes an other condition elsewhere, this analysis does not measure other-referential processing.

The contrast Happy (own) > Neutral (own) is a facial emotion recognition task involving one's own child and clearly taps broad social processing (perception and interpretation of social-emotional cues). It measures social processing across affiliation, emotion recognition, and empathic/mentalizing processes.

The analysis examines neural responses to the mother's own child's happy vs neutral faces, which directly involves parent–child bonding/attachment and affiliation-relevant processing (processing of a loved one's affect). Although it is a within-own contrast, it indexes attachment-related sensitivity to the child's positive cues.

This is a facial affect recognition task (viewing and classifying faces), i.e., reception of facial communication. The contrast isolates processing of an emotional facial signal (happy) versus neutral, meeting the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The task presents the child's faces and requires emotion classification of another person (the child); there is no self-referential or self-judgement component (no Self > Other contrast or viewing of the mother’s own face).

The contrast measures perception and understanding of another's emotional state (the mother's own child), engaging mentalizing/empathy-related processing, directly meeting the Perception of Others criteria.
This contrast isolates the ELM group-specific effect for Happy (own) > Neutral (own), probing group differences in social-emotional processing of one's child. It clearly assesses social processing.

The masked, group-specific contrast reflects differential neural processing of a mother's own child's positive affect in mothers with ELM versus controls — a comparison that is directly relevant to affiliation/attachment (response to a loved one's cues).
The analysis concerns reception of facial emotional communication (happy vs neutral) and tests group-specific modulation of that processing, fitting Social Communication inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns perception of the child's emotions and group differences; it does not involve self-focused judgments or viewing the participant's own face and therefore does not assess Perception/Self constructs.

This group-masked contrast evaluates how mothers perceive and neurally represent their child's emotional states (happy vs neutral) differently by ELM status, directly mapping onto Perception and Understanding of Others (empathy/mentalizing).
